3
of 31 expected
Project Overview
  • The Elang Mine is a new copper-gold mining project being developed by PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT), located 60 km east of the existing Batu Hijau Mine. [p. 451]
  • The project will require an additional 3,000 workers during peak construction and will retain approximately 6,000 workers during operations, primarily local Indonesian. [p. 365]
  • The Elang project involves site preparation for the mining pit and supporting facilities on Elang Block, as well as a conveyor route. [p. 340]
  • The nearest settlement, Lawin Village in Roppang District, is more than 5 km away from the Elang pit. [p. 317]
  • Restricted access to economic copper deposits and the overland conveyor alignment is a legal risk due to Protected Forest areas and the Forest Moratorium 2 overlay. [p. 41]
  • The project includes a new coal-fired power plant, which will require a through flow of 20 mÂ³/sec for its once-through seawater cooling system. [p. 113]
Environmental & Social Baseline
  • The ecological boundary for the project encompasses areas where impacts may occur, including downstream watersheds and atmospheric distribution from coal-fired power plant emissions. [p. 277]
  • Air emissions from power plants and vehicles are predicted to result in only minor changes to ambient air quality at residential receptors. [p. 313]
  • Surface water quality and quantity impacts during operation are generally temporary and minor for most receptors. [p. 326]
  • The social boundary includes villages where community members are likely to be affected directly or indirectly by Elang project activities. [p. 278]
  • Monitoring results from 16 years of Batu Hijau operations show no impact to coral reefs, beaches, fish, or other coastal environments. [p. 348]
  • Some forest areas within the project's scope are included in the latest Forest Moratorium 2 overlay. [p. 41]
Major Anticipated Impacts
  • Sedimentation caused by erosion on site has the potential for significant impacts on Brang Kuning and downstream receiving waters prior to mitigation. [p. 322]
  • Site preparation, including land clearing for the mining pit and supporting facilities on Elang Block and the conveyor route, is a potential impact for biodiversity and habitat. [p. 340]
  • Impacts from dust are considered temporary and negligible, with the nearest settlement over 5 km from the Elang pit. [p. 317]
  • Impacts on surface water quality and quantity during operation are generally temporary and minor for most receptors. [p. 326]
  • Emissions to air are expected to be minor, with no appreciable change in ambient air quality at residential sensitive receptors. [p. 313]
  • The Deep Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) associated with Project Elang will represent a small change to the existing environmental condition, resulting in a minor impact. [p. 335]
  • Legal issues related to mining in Protected Forest areas and areas under the Forest Moratorium 2 overlay pose a risk to access for copper deposits and the conveyor alignment. [p. 41]
Mitigation & Management Measures
  • Measures
  • Potential sediment discharges into Brang Kuning and downstream waters will be eliminated through design mitigation strategies proven at Batu Hijau Operations. [p. 322]
  • The AMNT Waste Management Plan will manage waste, reducing environmental impacts to negligible levels and offering business opportunities to local contractors. [p. 352]
  • The Elang project will establish a grievance mechanism to receive and facilitate the resolution of concerns from Affected Communities, in compliance with IFC PS 1. [p. 295]
  • The project aims for avoidance of impacts as the preferred option, followed by minimization, restoration/remediation, and compensation or offset for residual impacts. [p. 287]
  • A management plan will be prepared for unavoidable residual impacts to ensure compliance with applicable laws and standards. [p. 287]
  • The project must comply with both applicable discharge limits and ambient water environmental quality standards as per Government Regulation No 82 of 2001. [p. 80]
Residual Risks & Compliance
  • and Compliance
  • Restricted access to economic copper deposits and the overland conveyor alignment due to Protected Forest areas and the Forest Moratorium 2 overlay remains a legal risk. [p. 41]
  • The Elang project must comply with IFC Performance Standard (PS) 2 regarding the safe and fair employment of workers. [p. 365]
  • The project is required to comply with Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 on Water Quality Management and Water Pollution Control, specifically Article 41. [p. 80]
  • The project's management plan for residual impacts is designed to ensure compliance with applicable laws and standards. [p. 287]
  • Analytical studies on biodiversity components are limited to habitats and do not specifically address impacts on species, indicating a data gap regarding priority species. [p. 340]
p. 1 None

Original Text
08 19 Environmental and Social Impact Assessment Elang Project Indonesia PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara PROJECT NUMBER #2019-03-05-01
p. 28 INTRODUCTION
5 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project ESIA document provides an overview of project objectives, benefits, proponent, location, components, and implementation phases.
  • Mineral exploration by Newmont Mining Corporation in 1990 on Sumbawa Island led to the discovery of copper and gold mineralization.
  • Mine construction at Batu Hijau was completed in 1999, and copper ore production commenced in 2000.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Elang Project ESIA document provides an overview of project objectives, benefits, proponent, location, components, and implementation phases.
  • Mineral exploration by Newmont Mining Corporation in 1990 on Sumbawa Island led to the discovery of copper and gold mineralization.
  • Mine construction at Batu Hijau was completed in 1999, and copper ore production commenced in 2000.
  • The Batu Hijau Mine has produced approximately 3.6 million tonnes of copper and 8 million ounces of gold.
  • The Batu Hijau Mine has an estimated six years of remaining Life of Mine.
Original Text
Chapter 1 provides an overview of the Elang Project (objectives and benefits; project proponent and location; project components and implementation phases) and of the content and structure of this Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) document.
In 1990 mineral exploration by Newmont Mining Corporation (through its subsidiary PT Newmont Nusa Tenggara or NNT) on the island of Sumbawa resulted in the discovery of copper (and gold) mineralization that led to the development of the Batu Hijau Mine (Figure 1-1). In 1999 mine construction at Batu Hijau was completed and copper ore production commenced in 2000. Since then the Batu Hijau Mine, owned and operated by NNT, has produced approximately 3.6 million...
p. 29 Project Benefits for the Government of Indonesia
6 facts â–¼
  • Project benefits for the Government of Indonesia include maintaining/increasing Indonesia's share of copper production in the world market.
  • The project aims to increase Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in Indonesia.
  • The project is expected to increase GoI income from taxes and royalties.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Project benefits for the Government of Indonesia include maintaining/increasing Indonesia's share of copper production in the world market.
  • The project aims to increase Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in Indonesia.
  • The project is expected to increase GoI income from taxes and royalties.
  • The project will contribute to the development of the local economy.
  • AMNT operates a 25,000 ha copper and gold mining IUPK area on Sumbawa Island, Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia.
  • The AMNT Contract of Work (CoW) covers four blocks: Batu Hijau (exploitation), Elang (planning), Agam (exploration), and Rinti (exploration).
Original Text
â–ª Maintaining/increasing the Indonesian share of copper production in the world market and meet global demand; â–ª Increasing Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in Indonesia; â–ª Increasing GoI income from taxes and royalties; and â–ª Contributing to the development of the local economy.
AMNT operates a 25,000 ha copper and gold mining IUPK area located on the Island of Sumbawa, Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia. According to IUPK-OP of Year 2016, the Contract of Work (CoW) of AMNT covers four blocks of copper and gold mineralization: Batu Hijau (in exploitation), Elang (this Project, in planning), and Agam and Rinti (the latter two in exploration). AMNT is headquartered in Jakarta, Indonesia.
PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) Energy Building, 28 th Floor SCBD Lot 11A Jalan Jend. Sudirman Kav. 52-53 Kebayoran Baru Jakarta 12190 Indonesia Phone: +62 21 5799 4600 (Hunting) Fax: +62 21 576 1464
p. 30 Responsible Person (ESIA) and Project Location
6 facts â–¼
  • Potro Soeprapto is the Senior Manager Government Relations and Permitting for AMNT.
  • The Elang deposit is located on Sumbawa Island, West Nusa Tenggara province, approximately 60 km east of Batu Hijau.
  • The Elang deposit is administratively located in the Sumbawa Regency.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Potro Soeprapto is the Senior Manager Government Relations and Permitting for AMNT.
  • The Elang deposit is located on Sumbawa Island, West Nusa Tenggara province, approximately 60 km east of Batu Hijau.
  • The Elang deposit is administratively located in the Sumbawa Regency.
  • The Batu Hijau Mine and its supporting facilities are located in the West Sumbawa Regency.
  • Project access from Jakarta involves a 1.5-hour flight to Mataram on Lombok Island.
  • From Lombok, access to Benete Bay (Batu Hijau Mine's logistic port) is via a 20-minute company-operated seaplane flight or a 2-3 hour ferry transport.
Original Text
Potro Soeprapto Senior Manager Government Relations and Permitting Phone: +62 21 5799 4600 (Hunting) Email: Potro.Soeprapto@amnt.co.id
The Elang deposit is located on the Indonesian island of Sumbawa in the province of West Nusa Tenggara, about 60 km east of the Batu Hijau and about 1,530 km east of Jakarta (Figure 1-2). Adminstratively, the Elang deposit falls in the Sumbawa Regency; Batu Hijau Mine and its supporting facilities fall under the West Sumbawa Regency.
Project access from Jakarta is initially via plane to Mataram on the Island of Lombok (about 1.5 hrs air travelling). From Lombok, two options exist to reach Benete Bay, the logistic port of the Batu Hijau Mine: (1) by company-operated sea plane (flight time of about 20 min); or (2) by ferry transport (public or company-operated) from Lombok to Benete Bay across the Alas Strait separating Lombok and Sumbawa (both islands form part of the West Nusa Tenggara province) (about 2 to 3 hr...
p. 31 Project Components and Associated Facilities
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project plans to utilize existing mineral processing and supporting infrastructure at Batu Hijau where feasible.
  • A major component of the Elang Project is a single large open pit for mining the Elang mineralization.
  • The open pit will be up to 800 m deep at the pit exit and 1,000 m deep to the highest wall (to the west).
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang Project plans to utilize existing mineral processing and supporting infrastructure at Batu Hijau where feasible.
  • A major component of the Elang Project is a single large open pit for mining the Elang mineralization.
  • The open pit will be up to 800 m deep at the pit exit and 1,000 m deep to the highest wall (to the west).
  • Another major component is a single large Waste Rock Dump (WRD), sediment pond, and topsoil stockpile located southwest of the open pit.
Original Text
Copper mining and ore processing are supported by a wide range of infrastructure. As much as feasible the Elang Project plans to take advantage of the existing mineral processing and supporting infrastructure at Batu Hijau (as indicated in italic in listing below). The major components for the Elang Project are as follows: â–ª A single large open pit to mine the Elang mineralization, up to 800 m deep at the pit exit and 1,000 m deep to the highest wall (to the west); â–ª A single large ...
p. 32 1.1.5 Project Schedule
7 facts â–¼
  • The pre-construction stage, including planning, permits, engineering, and site preparation, is expected to be completed by the end of 2020.
  • Construction activities are scheduled to last approximately 36 months.
  • Two years of pre-strip, involving approximately 90 Mtpa, will follow construction at the Elang deposit.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The pre-construction stage, including planning, permits, engineering, and site preparation, is expected to be completed by the end of 2020.
  • Construction activities are scheduled to last approximately 36 months.
  • Two years of pre-strip, involving approximately 90 Mtpa, will follow construction at the Elang deposit.
  • Production schedules allow for 18 to 24 years of production, including pre-strip.
  • Year 1 of production targets a pre-strip of about 40 Mt.
  • Year 2 of production targets a pre-strip of about 50 Mt.
  • Year 3 marks the commencement of ore production, with 50 Mt of ore processed in this year.
Original Text
The pre-construction stage comprises project planning, permit, engineering, and site preparation and is expected to be completed by the end of 2020. Construction activities are scheduled to last about 36 months followed by two years of pre-strip of approximately 90 Mtpa at the Elang deposit (Figure 1-5). Production schedules allow for 18 to 24 years of production (including pre-strip) achieving the following targets: Â· Year 1: pre-strip of about 40 Mt; Â· Year 2: pre-strip ...
p. 33 1.1.6 Workforce Requirements
4 facts â–¼
  • The current exploration phase employs approximately 450 workers.
  • Mine construction activities will employ a maximum of 3,000 workers.
  • Workforce numbers will fluctuate throughout the construction phase, following a typical bell curve.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The current exploration phase employs approximately 450 workers.
  • Mine construction activities will employ a maximum of 3,000 workers.
  • Workforce numbers will fluctuate throughout the construction phase, following a typical bell curve.
  • Most of the construction workforce will consist of blue-collar workers recruited locally.
Original Text
During the current exploration the workforce totals approximately 450 workers. Mine construction activities will employ a maximum of 3,000 workers. The workforce numbers will vary over time, depending on the activities such as site preparation, foundations, buildings erection, electrical, piping, etc. The workforce numbers will follow a typical bell curve -being fewer at the beginning and at the end of the construction phase. Most of the construction workforce required wil...
p. 34 1.1.7 Project Alternatives
4 facts â–¼
  • Project alternatives considered include a 'No action' scenario.
  • A 'Stand-alone project' alternative involves Elang having its own processing, power generation, tailings disposal, and concentrate handling facilities...
  • An alternative considered is the expansion of the existing Batu Hijau concentrator and transport of ore from Elang to Batu Hijau.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Project alternatives considered include a 'No action' scenario.
  • A 'Stand-alone project' alternative involves Elang having its own processing, power generation, tailings disposal, and concentrate handling facilities.
  • An alternative considered is the expansion of the existing Batu Hijau concentrator and transport of ore from Elang to Batu Hijau.
  • Methodologies for ore transportation considered include conveyor systems, truck haulage, slurry pipeline, light rail, standard rail, and 'Railveyor'.
Original Text
A wide range and variety of alternatives have been considered for development of the Elang copper-gold deposit. The main alternatives include: â–ª No action: a decision not to proceed with the project; â–ª Stand-alone project: Elang would have its own processing, power generation, tailings disposal and concentrate handling facilities; â–ª Expansion of the existing Batu Hijau concentrator and transport of the ore from Elang to Batu Hijau. â–ª Methodology for ore transportation: conveyor (various systems)...
p. 36 1.2.1 Regulatory Requirements
9 facts â–¼
  • Project compliance with applicable Indonesian laws and regulations is mandatory.
  • AMDAL documents for the project will follow the Regulation of the Ministry of Environment No 16 Year 2012.
  • Indonesian Act No 5 of Year 1990 regulates the protection of flora, fauna, ecosystems, and conservation areas.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • Project compliance with applicable Indonesian laws and regulations is mandatory.
  • AMDAL documents for the project will follow the Regulation of the Ministry of Environment No 16 Year 2012.
  • Indonesian Act No 5 of Year 1990 regulates the protection of flora, fauna, ecosystems, and conservation areas.
  • Indonesian Act No 32 of Year 2009 provides basic provisions for environmental management, government roles, permits, and penalties.
  • Indonesian Act No 11 of Year 2010 stipulates basic criteria for cultural heritage, ownership, discovery, registration, conservation, monitoring, and investigation.
  • Government Regulation No 41 of Year 1999 provides general standards for ambient air quality, including NOX, SO2, particulates, and dust.
  • Ministry of Environment Regulation No 08 of Year 2006 outlines types of environmental permits and application processes.
  • Environmental permits can be in the form of UKL/UPL or AMDAL, with AMDAL commonly applying to mining projects.
  • AMDAL documents include the Terms of Reference (KA) and the Environmental Impact Analysis (Analisis Dampak Lingkungan - ANDAL).
Original Text
Project compliance with applicable Indonesian laws and regulations is mandatory. The format of the AMDAL documents for the Project will follow the Regulation of the Ministry of Environment (MoE) No 16 Year 2012 regarding Guidelines for the Preparation of Environmental Documents. Other key regulations of the Government of Indonesia with respect to the environmental and social aspects of the Elang project as follow:
This Act regulates the protection of flora and fauna and the accompanying ecosystems, protection of conservation areas and buffer zones, and requirements for activities to preserve and protect these items.
This act provides the basic provisions for environmental management of projects, the role of government agencies, permits and studies that are required and penalties in the case of noncompliance with the associated regulations.
This Act stipulates the basic criteria for cultural heritage, ownership and authorization, discovery and observation, national registration, conservation, monitoring, and investigation.
This regulation provides the general standards for ambient air quality, e.g. NOX, SO2, particulates, and dust.
This regulation outlines the types of environmental permits and details related to the application processes. Environmental permits are in form of Environmental Management or Monitoring Efforts ( Upaya Pengelolaan/Pemantauan Lingkungan -UKL/UPL) or Environmental Impact Assessments ( Analisis Mengenai Dampak Lingkungan -AMDAL). The type of permit is based on the size of the activity or business and the related impacts. The AMDAL process commonly applies to mining projects. AMDAL docum...
p. 37 Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 regarding Hazardous a...
11 facts â–¼
  • Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 identifies hazardous and toxic wastes (B3 wastes) based on source, characteristic, and/or toxicology tests.
  • B3 wastes are categorized as derived from unspecific or specific sources, including unused chemicals, spills, and packaging.
  • Characteristics of B3 wastes tested include explosivity, combustibility, reactivity, toxicity, infectiousness, and corrosivity.
  • + 8 more facts...
  • Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 identifies hazardous and toxic wastes (B3 wastes) based on source, characteristic, and/or toxicology tests.
  • B3 wastes are categorized as derived from unspecific or specific sources, including unused chemicals, spills, and packaging.
  • Characteristics of B3 wastes tested include explosivity, combustibility, reactivity, toxicity, infectiousness, and corrosivity.
  • Ministry of Environment Decree No 48 of Year 1996 stipulates noise level standards for various activities, workspaces, and environments.
  • Ministry of Environment Regulation No 07 of Year 2007 provides emission standards for thermal power plants, including NOx, SO2, particulates, and opacity.
  • Ministry of Environment Decree No 202 of Year 2004 sets wastewater discharge standards for copper/gold mines and processing activities.
  • Ministry of Environment Regulation No 12 of Year 2011 concerns wastewater discharge to the sea from mining and oil industries, defining location requirements and quality standards for tailings.
  • Tailings are categorized under B406 code based on Government Regulation No 101 of Year 2014.
  • Ministry of Environment and Forestry Regulation No P.106/MENLHK/SETJEN/KUM.1/12/2018 provides the most recent list of protected species in Indonesia.
  • Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Decree No 1827 Year 2018 provides guidelines for environmental, health, and safety management in mining, mine reclamation, and mine closure.
  • Regional Regulation of Sumbawa Regency No 6 Year 2013 addresses Corporate Social Responsibility.
Original Text
This regulation identifies hazardous and toxic wastes (referred to B3 wastes in Indonesia) based on source and characteristic and/or toxicology tests. B3 wastes are categorized as derived from either unspecific or specific sources, and can include unused chemicals, spills, packaging and other unspecified waste materials. The characteristics of B3 wastes are tested for explosivity, combustibility, reactivity, toxicity, infectiousness and corrosivity. Toxicology tests consid...
This decree stipulates noise level standards for a number of activities, work spaces and environments.
This regulation provides the emission standards from thermal power plants including CoalFired Power Plants (CFPP) e.g. NOx, SO2, particulates and opacity. Two sets of emissions standards are provided based on the monitoring systems, either manual or Continuous Emissions Monitoring System (CEMS).
The decree sets wastewater discharge standards for copper/gold mines and processing activities.
This regulation is concerned with wastewater discharge to the sea from mining and oil industries. It defines location requirements and quality standards specifically for tailings (Based on Government Regulation No 101 of Year 2014, tailings categorization falls under B406 code).
This decree provides the most recent list of protected species in Indonesia and refers to Act No 5 of Year 1990 regarding requirements on conservation of protected species. Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Decree No 1827 Year 2018 regarding Guidelines for The Implementation of Technical Standards for Good Mining Practices This decree provides, among others, guidelines for environmental, health and safety management in mining, mine reclamation and mine closure. Regional Regulat...

p. 39 Geographic Scope
4 facts â–¼
  • The ESIA covers environmental and social impacts of the Elang project throughout its entire project cycle.
  • The Area of Influence (AOI) includes the surrounding region affected by direct, indirect, and/or cumulative impacts from transportation, supply chain,...
  • The AOI encompasses the geographic area likely to be affected by the Elang project and its associated facilities.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The ESIA covers environmental and social impacts of the Elang project throughout its entire project cycle.
  • The Area of Influence (AOI) includes the surrounding region affected by direct, indirect, and/or cumulative impacts from transportation, supply chain, and other project aspects.
  • The AOI encompasses the geographic area likely to be affected by the Elang project and its associated facilities.
  • The AOI also considers impacts from unplanned but predictable developments caused by the Elang project that occur later or at different locations.
Original Text
The ESIA addresses environmental and social impacts associated with Elang throughout the project cycle. It also includes the surrounding region affected and impacted by direct, indirect and/or cumulative impacts from transportation, supply chain and other aspects of the Elang project (defined as Area of Influence or AOI). The AOI relates to the geographic scope of the area likely to be affected by the Elang project and its associated facilities; impacts from unplanned but predictable development...
p. 40 Applicability of Lenders' Safeguards Policies to the Project
7 facts â–¼
  • Compliance with IFC requirements is considered Good International Industry Practices (GIIP) for international commercial lenders.
  • This ESIA derives GIIP from various IFC guidelines, including IFC Performance Standards.
  • The ESIA also uses IFC General EHS Guidelines.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • Compliance with IFC requirements is considered Good International Industry Practices (GIIP) for international commercial lenders.
  • This ESIA derives GIIP from various IFC guidelines, including IFC Performance Standards.
  • The ESIA also uses IFC General EHS Guidelines.
  • Specific IFC EHS Guidelines for Mining are applied.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Ports, Harbors and Terminals are relevant.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Thermal Power are considered.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Electric Power Transmission and Distribution are also referenced.
Original Text
Compliance with IFC requirements is considered to be Good International Industry Practices (GIIP), commonly acceptable to international commercial lenders involved in project financing. As such, this ESIA derives GIIP from various IFC guidelines, specifically the following: â–ª IFC Performance Standards; â–ª IFC General EHS Guidelines; â–ª IFC EHS Guidelines for Mining; â–ª IFC EHS Guidelines for Ports, Harbors and Terminals; â–ª IFC EHS Guidelines for Thermal Power; and â–ª IFC EHS Guidelines for E...
p. 41 Environmental and Social Project Categorization
7 facts â–¼
  • IFC categorizes projects based on the magnitude of environmental and social risks and impacts.
  • Category A projects are expected to have significant adverse social and/or environmental impacts that are diverse, irreversible, or unprecedented.
  • Category B projects are expected to have limited adverse impacts that can be readily addressed.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • IFC categorizes projects based on the magnitude of environmental and social risks and impacts.
  • Category A projects are expected to have significant adverse social and/or environmental impacts that are diverse, irreversible, or unprecedented.
  • Category B projects are expected to have limited adverse impacts that can be readily addressed.
  • Greencorp identified legal issues related to mining in forest areas based on available information and experience in Indonesia.
  • Restricted access to economic copper deposits and the overland conveyor alignment is due to Protected Forest areas.
  • Some forest areas included in the latest Forest Moratorium 2 overlay with the proposed mine pit.
  • Indonesia's Presidential Instruction No. 10/2011 on 'The postponement of issuance of new licenses and improving govern' was released on May 20, 2011.
Original Text
As part of the review of environmental and social risks and the impacts of a proposed investment, IFC uses environmental and social categorization to reflect the magnitude of risks and impacts. The resulting category determines the level of environmental assessment and disclosure requirements. IFC categorization follows: â–ª Category A: Projects expected to have significant adverse social and/or environmental impacts that are diverse, irreversible, or unprecedented; â–ª Cate...
Based on a review of available information and experience with similar development projects in Indonesia, Greencorp has identified the following risks and issues: Legal Issues related to Mining in Forest Areas â–ª Restricted access to economic copper deposits and to the overland conveyor alignment due to Protected Forest areas. â–ª Some forest areas included in the latest Forest Moratorium 2 overlay with the proposed mine pit (Map 1-2). 2 On 20 May 2011, the Government of Indonesia released Presiden...

p. 47 CHAPTER 2
1 facts â–¼

Original Text
Environmental and Social Impact Assessment Elang Project Indonesia
p. 48 Environmental and Social Risks and Impacts Framework
5 facts â–¼
  • Chapter 2 provides an overview of the Project's Health, Safety, Environment and Quality (HSEQ) management system, Environmental and Social Policy, org...
  • The Project's environmental and social management during construction is summarized in Chapter 2.
  • The Project has adopted an integrated risk-based HSEQ management system based on business processes from the Batu Hijau mining operation.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Chapter 2 provides an overview of the Project's Health, Safety, Environment and Quality (HSEQ) management system, Environmental and Social Policy, organizational capacity, competence, and emergency preparedness and response.
  • The Project's environmental and social management during construction is summarized in Chapter 2.
  • The Project has adopted an integrated risk-based HSEQ management system based on business processes from the Batu Hijau mining operation.
  • The HSEQ management system includes HSEQ Policies, HSEQ Manual, Environmental and Social Management Plans, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), Work Instructions (WIs), Job Safety Analysis (JSAs), and supporting forms.
  • The HSEQ Management System captures close to 20 years of operational experience from the Batu Hijau Mine, which has been in operation since 2000.
Original Text
Chapter 2 provides an overview of the Project's Health, Safety, Environment and Quality (HSEQ) management system, Environmental and Social Policy, organizational capacity and competence, and emergency preparedness and response. Given the Project implementation phase at the time of the ESIA compilation, Chapter 2 also s ummarizes the Project's environmental and social management during construction.
The Project has adopted the integrated risk-based HSEQ management system based on business processes as applied to the Batu Hijau mining operation. It consists of overarching HSEQ Policies, HSEQ Manual, Environmental and Social Management Plans, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), Work Instructions (WIs) and Job Safety Analysis (JSAs), and supporting forms. Forms are used to record implementation of the management system to make it traceable and auditable. Given ...

  • The AMNT Policy was issued and signed by top management, specifically the President Director and the General Operation Manager.
  • The Statement of Commitment signifies top management's intention and commitment to AMNT's health, safety, environmental, and social responsibilities.
  • AMNT has developed an overarching integrated HSEQ Policy, known as the Statement of Commitment, as required by IFC Performance Standards and ISO 14001.

  • The Statement of Commitment signifies top management's intention and commitment to AMNT's health, safety, environmental, and social responsibilities.

p. 59 Emergency Preparedness and Response
5 facts â–¼
  • The Project has developed and maintains an emergency preparedness and response system to prevent and mitigate harm to people and the environment.
  • The system identifies areas where accidents and emergency situations may occur and stakeholders that may be impacted.
  • Response procedures, provision of equipment and resources, designation of responsibilities, and communication are included in the system.
  • + 2 more facts...

  • The system identifies areas where accidents and emergency situations may occur and stakeholders that may be impacted.
  • Response procedures, provision of equipment and resources, designation of responsibilities, and communication are included in the system.
  • Communication with potentially affected stakeholders is a component of the emergency response system.
  • Periodic training is part of the emergency preparedness and response system.

  • The Chief Mine Engineer (Kepala Teknik Tambang or KTT), who is the top HSEQ Officer, oversees the monitoring program.
  • The KTT role is required and recognized by the Government.

  • The Project conducts regular inspections and audits to identify issues and verify compliance and progress.
  • Information records are maintained to track performance and establish operational control.

p. 63 Environmental Design Criteria and Regulatory Framework
8 facts â–¼
  • Environmental Design Criteria (EDC) set detailed binding and non-binding environmental performance standards to minimize impacts, drive resource effic...
  • EDC aims to meet Government of Indonesia regulations and Good International Industry Practice (GIIP).
  • Qualitative EDC cannot be measured and focus on preventing or lessening potential environmental impacts.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Environmental Design Criteria (EDC) set detailed binding and non-binding environmental performance standards to minimize impacts, drive resource efficiency, limit waste, and assure compliance.
  • EDC aims to meet Government of Indonesia regulations and Good International Industry Practice (GIIP).
  • Qualitative EDC cannot be measured and focus on preventing or lessening potential environmental impacts.
  • Quantitative EDC represent defined allowable limit values established in national and/or international regulations.
  • Chapter 3.1 lists applicable company policies, Government of Indonesia (GoI) laws and regulations, international conventions, and IFC EHS Guidelines.
  • AMNT is committed to upholding the AMNT HSE Statement of Commitment (Chapter 2.2).
  • The regulatory administrative framework includes Indonesian laws, the environmental assessment of the Elang project, social and land use regulations, and international treaties.
  • Indonesia is divided into five administrative layers, including 33 provinces.
Original Text
To minimize environmental impacts, drive resource efficiency, and limit waste, as well as assure compliance with Government of Indonesia regulations and meet Good International Industry Practice (GIIP), Environmental Design Criteria (EDC) set detailed binding and nonbinding environmental performance standards. Qualitative EDC cannot be measured and aim to prevent or lessen potential environmental impacts (i.e., Overarching Principles). Quantitative EDC represent de...
Chapter 3.1 lists applicable company policies, Government of Indonesia (GoI) laws and regulations, international conventions and GIIP, predominantly in form of the IFC EHS Guidelines.
AMNT is committed to upholding the AMNT HSE Statement of Commitment (Chapter 2.2).
The regulatory administrative framework comprises Indonesian laws and regulations applicable to the Project, the regulatory environmental assessment of the Elang project (still in process at the time of this ESIA the compilation), social and land use regulations, and international treaties and agreements to which Indonesia is a signatory. Indonesia is divided into five administrative layers (Figure 3-1). At the top level is the nation, the Republic of Indonesia, which consis...
p. 64 Indonesian Regulatory Framework
4 facts â–¼
  • The Central Government issues laws and regulations governing environmental management and protection in Indonesia.
  • Environmental regulations at province and regency levels complement central national legislation, sometimes with contradictions.
  • The Elang project must comply with both national and local regulations.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Central Government issues laws and regulations governing environmental management and protection in Indonesia.
  • Environmental regulations at province and regency levels complement central national legislation, sometimes with contradictions.
  • The Elang project must comply with both national and local regulations.
  • Relevant national regulations governing air quality, noise, and vibration are specified.
Original Text
The Central Government issues laws and regulations relating to or directly governing environmental management and protection in Indonesia. These are complemented by environmental regulations at province and regency levels that at times directly contradict central national legislation or nationally-issued regulations. The Elang project must comply with both national and local regulations. 3.1.2.1 Indonesia Regulations Governing Air Quality, Noise and Vibration Relevant nationa...
p. 65 Indonesia Regulations Governing Waste and Hazardous Waste Ma...
8 facts â–¼
  • Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 governs Hazardous and Toxic Waste Management in Indonesia.
  • Minister of Home Affairs Regulation No 33 Year 2010 provides guidelines for Waste Management.
  • Minister of Environment Regulation No 18 Year 2009 details Permit Procedures for Hazardous Waste Management.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 governs Hazardous and Toxic Waste Management in Indonesia.
  • Minister of Home Affairs Regulation No 33 Year 2010 provides guidelines for Waste Management.
  • Minister of Environment Regulation No 18 Year 2009 details Permit Procedures for Hazardous Waste Management.
  • Act No 18 Year 2008 is a key regulation on Waste Management.
  • Government Regulation No 74 Year 2001 addresses Hazardous Material Management.
  • Indonesia ratified the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change via Law No 6 of 1994.
  • The Kyoto Protocol was ratified by Indonesia through Presidential Decree PP No 92 of 1998.
  • Indonesia has also ratified the Paris Agreement to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.
Original Text
Relevant national regulations governing waste management include: â–ª Government Regulation No 101 Year 2014 on Hazardous and Toxic Waste Management; â–ª Minister of Home Affairs Regulation No 33 Year 2010 on Guidelines for Waste Management; â–ª Minister of Environment Regulation No 18 Year 2009 on Permit Procedures for Hazardous Waste Management; â–ª Minister of Environment Regulation No 2 Year 2008 on Hazardous Waste Utilization â–ª Act No 18 Year 2008 on Waste Management; â–ª Government Regul...

p. 69 Good International Industry Practices
5 facts â–¼
  • The IFC EHS Guidelines are technical reference documents for Good International Industry Practice (GIIP) as defined in IFC Performance Standard (PS) 3...
  • Compliance with IFC requirements is considered GIIP and is commonly acceptable to International Financial Institutions.
  • Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) are kept on file and available for all reagents, chemicals, and hazardous materials stored and used on site.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The IFC EHS Guidelines are technical reference documents for Good International Industry Practice (GIIP) as defined in IFC Performance Standard (PS) 3.
  • Compliance with IFC requirements is considered GIIP and is commonly acceptable to International Financial Institutions.
  • Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) are kept on file and available for all reagents, chemicals, and hazardous materials stored and used on site.
  • Engineering design explicitly aims for a clean plant to reduce spillage probability, ensure adequate containment, and facilitate collection of spilled materials.
  • The design approach for spill containment and minimization includes equipment protection from spillage and management of highly toxic materials.
Original Text
The IFC EHS Guidelines are technical reference documents with general and industry-specific examples of Good International Industry Practice (GIIP), as defined in IFC Performance Standard (PS) 3: Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention. The IFC EHS Guidelines contain the performance levels and measures that are normally acceptable to IFC and that are generally considered to be achievable in new facilities at reasonable costs by existing technology. Compli...
This section addresses EDC for a general approach to spill containment and minimization, equipment protection from spillage, and management of highly toxic materials.
A fundamental design aims to eliminate spillage sources and to remove the need for clean-up tasks. A clean plant is an explicit aim of engineering design, to: â–ª Reduce the probability of spillages; â–ª Ensure adequate containment of any potential spillages; and â–ª Ensure ease of collection of any spilled materials/contaminants. For each operation, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) are kept on file and available upon request for each reagent/chemical and other hazardous materials (e.g., fuels, sulf...
p. 70 Equipment Protection from Spillage
6 facts â–¼
  • Equipment location must consider 'what is located above what' to prevent spillage impacts.
  • Switchgear, instrumentation, and electric motors not in dry environments will be weather- and water-proof to prevent electric shock.
  • Switchgear will be capable of being locked out for electrical isolation of relevant equipment.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Equipment location must consider 'what is located above what' to prevent spillage impacts.
  • Switchgear, instrumentation, and electric motors not in dry environments will be weather- and water-proof to prevent electric shock.
  • Switchgear will be capable of being locked out for electrical isolation of relevant equipment.
  • Special considerations apply to chemicals that can cause highly toxic material concentrations, which are immediately dangerous to life and health, or are carcinogens.
  • Facilities containing highly toxic materials must consider proximity to other facilities and access ways.
  • Appropriate construction material and fabrication are required where there is potential for significant release of highly toxic materials.
Original Text
The location of equipment needs to be considered from the viewpoint of 'what is located above what'. Any switchgear, instrumentation, or electric motors not specifically protected by virtue of placement in a dry environment (e.g., switch room, operator's b ooth) will be weather- and water-proof to avoid the risk of electric shock. Switchgear will be capable of being locked out to electrically isolate relevant equipment.
Special considerations apply to any chemicals that can cause a concentration of highly toxic materials that will be immediately dangerous to life and health, or that are carcinogens (e.g., poly-aromatic hydrocarbons associated with diesel exhaust particulates). The following principles apply to the management of these materials: â–ª The location of facilities containing highly toxic materials consider the proximity to other facilities and access ways; â–ª Where there is a potential for signifi...
p. 71 Emissions to Air
5 facts â–¼
  • This section details point source emissions to air and applicable Ambient Air Quality Standards (AAQS), including ambient noise levels.
  • Odors are excluded from this section as they are not commonly an impact in mining activities.
  • Indonesian environmental policies combine emission controls and ambient environmental quality standards.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • This section details point source emissions to air and applicable Ambient Air Quality Standards (AAQS), including ambient noise levels.
  • Odors are excluded from this section as they are not commonly an impact in mining activities.
  • Indonesian environmental policies combine emission controls and ambient environmental quality standards.
  • SO2 emissions are capped by emission standards, while permissible ambient SO2 concentrations are regulated by AAQS.
  • Environmental Design Criteria (EDC) must consider both emission limits and ambient environmental quality.
Original Text
This section contains EDC for point source emissions to air and details of applicable Ambient Air Quality Standards (AAQS) including ambient noise levels. Odors are excluded because they are commonly not an impact in mining activities. In Indonesia, most environmental policies involve some combination of emission controls and ambient environmental quality standards. For instance, SO2 emissions are capped by emission standards while permissible ambient SO2 concentrations are regulated by AAQS (Fi...
p. 72 Point Source Emission Limits
8 facts â–¼
  • Point source emission limits restrict contaminant concentration at the stack, typically measured in mg/mÂ³.
  • Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP) for emission limits is 1 atmosphere pressure and 25Â°C temperature, consistent with Indonesian regulations.
  • Point source emissions originate from coal-fired and diesel power plants.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Point source emission limits restrict contaminant concentration at the stack, typically measured in mg/mÂ³.
  • Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP) for emission limits is 1 atmosphere pressure and 25Â°C temperature, consistent with Indonesian regulations.
  • Point source emissions originate from coal-fired and diesel power plants.
  • Table 3-2 compares emission limits based on Minister of Environment Regulation No. 21 of 2008 and IFC General EHS Guidelines.
  • Indonesian regulation for Particulate Matter (PM) from Diesel Fuel (Generator Set) is 120 mg/NmÂ³.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Particulate Matter (PM) from Liquid Fuel Engine (3MWth - 50 MWth) is 50 mg/NmÂ³, or up to 100 mg/NmÂ³ if justified.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Particulate Matter (PM) from Solid Fuel Boiler is 50 mg/NmÂ³, or up to 150 mg/NmÂ³ if justified.
  • Indonesian regulation for Carbon Monoxide from Diesel Fuel (Generator Set) is 540 mg/NmÂ³.
Original Text
Point source emission limits are restrictions on the concentration of contaminants at the point source (stack). Gaseous concentrations are usually measured and documented in units such as milligrams per cubic meter of gas (mg/m ) under specified conditions such as temperature, 3 pressure, and averaging period. Convention, or Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP), is 1 atmosphere pressure and 25 C temperature (which also applies to limits stated in o Indonesian regulations). Point s...

p. 73 Emissions from Coal Fired Power Plants
5 facts â–¼
  • Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx), and particulates (PM) from coal-fired power plants will be controlled to comply with regulat...
  • Control methods include low NOx burners, use of low sulphur coal, flue gas desulphurization (FGD), electrostatic precipitation (ESP), and/or a baghous...
  • Ministry of Environment Regulations No 21 of 2008 - Attachment 1B sets a maximum allowance of 510 mg/Nm3 for NOx emissions from coal sources.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx), and particulates (PM) from coal-fired power plants will be controlled to comply with regulatory standards.
  • Control methods include low NOx burners, use of low sulphur coal, flue gas desulphurization (FGD), electrostatic precipitation (ESP), and/or a baghouse.
  • Ministry of Environment Regulations No 21 of 2008 - Attachment 1B sets a maximum allowance of 510 mg/Nm3 for NOx emissions from coal sources.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Thermal Power Plants (Solid Fuels, Plant > 50 MWth to <600 MWth) in a non-degraded airshed set a NOx limit of 750 mg/Nm3.
  • FGD systems may consume between 0.5% and 1.6% of the electricity generated by the plant.
Original Text
Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx) and particulates (PM) will be controlled to comply with the applicable regulatory standards (Table 3-2) by means of low NOx burners, use of low sulphur coal, flue gas desulphurization (FGD), electrostatic precipitation (ESP) and/or a baghouse. p. 74 Dust Emissions
6 facts â–¼
  • Copper-gold mining activities generate dust from land clearing, drilling, blasting, material transport, and dumping.
  • Minimization of dust is crucial for improved worker health.
  • Indonesia Government Regulations No. 41 Year 1999 on air quality control sets a Total Suspended Particulate (TSP) emission standard of 23 Âµg/Nm3.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Copper-gold mining activities generate dust from land clearing, drilling, blasting, material transport, and dumping.
  • Minimization of dust is crucial for improved worker health.
  • Indonesia Government Regulations No. 41 Year 1999 on air quality control sets a Total Suspended Particulate (TSP) emission standard of 23 Âµg/Nm3.
  • There are no specific Indonesian Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emission standards currently.
  • IFC Performance Standard 3 requires quantification and reporting of GHG emissions.
  • IFC Guidance Note 3 mandates that projects expected to produce more than 100,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent annually must quantify direct and indirect emissions.
Original Text
Copper-gold mining activities typically generate dust (particulates), particularly from land clearing, drilling, blasting, material transport and dumping. Minimization of dust is key to improved worker health. No specific limits apply for emissions of particulate matter from coal mining operations, with the exception that ambient air quality standards must be met. According to Indonesia regulations on air quality control (Indonesia Government Regulations No. 41...
Though Indonesia has a climate change action program and goals, there are no specific Indonesian Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emission standards at this time. IFC Performance Standard 3 Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention does not regulate GHG emissions as such but does require quantification and reporting. IFC Guidance Note 3 requires that projects expected to produce more than 100,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent annually will quantify direct emissions from the facili...
p. 75 Ambient Air Quality Standards
4 facts â–¼
  • Ambient air quality standards (AAQS) ensure communities and protected areas are not adversely affected by project emissions.
  • Concentrations are measured in milligrams per cubic meter of gas (mg/m3) over specified averaging periods.
  • AAQS include various thresholds for different averaging periods, all of which must be met.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Ambient air quality standards (AAQS) ensure communities and protected areas are not adversely affected by project emissions.
  • Concentrations are measured in milligrams per cubic meter of gas (mg/m3) over specified averaging periods.
  • AAQS include various thresholds for different averaging periods, all of which must be met.
  • The regulation does not specify where limits apply (site boundary, receptor, or maximum point of impingement).
Original Text
Ambient air quality standards (AAQS) are provided to ensure that communities and protected areas around the facility are not adversely affected by project emissions. Concentrations are measured and documented in milligrams per cubic meter of gas (mg/m ) over specified 3 averaging periods. AAQS include various thresholds for different averaging periods, all of which must be met. The regulation does not specify where limits apply: at site boundary, at the receptor, or at the...
p. 76 Ambient Air Quality Standards
6 facts â–¼
  • Indonesian Regulation (GR 41 of 1999) sets a dust deposition limit of 10 tonnes/km2/month for residential areas over a 30-day averaging period.
  • IFC General EHS Guidelines require projects with significant air emission sources to prevent or minimize impacts by ensuring emissions do not exceed r...
  • Minister of Environment Decree No 48/MENLH/11/1996 defines national noise emission standards based on area designation.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Indonesian Regulation (GR 41 of 1999) sets a dust deposition limit of 10 tonnes/km2/month for residential areas over a 30-day averaging period.
  • IFC General EHS Guidelines require projects with significant air emission sources to prevent or minimize impacts by ensuring emissions do not exceed relevant ambient quality guidelines and standards.
  • Minister of Environment Decree No 48/MENLH/11/1996 defines national noise emission standards based on area designation.
  • Lower noise limits are set for residential and natural areas compared to industrial and commercial areas.
  • IFC General EHS Guidelines on Noise reference World Health Organization Guidelines for Community Noise (1999).
  • In Indonesia, noise level measurements are taken off-site at specific times over a day, with a 24-hour weighted average calculated.
Original Text

1 Value stated are in the 99th percentile 2 Reference temperature is local ambient temperature at time of sampling. 3 The use of PM2.5 guideline value is generally preferred over the PM10 value; however, the PM10 value can be used in the absence of PM2.5. Minister of Environment Decree No 48/MENLH/11/1996 on Noise Standards defines national noise emission standards dependent on the area designation, with lower limits for residential and natural areas compared to industrial and commercial areas (Table 3-4). The IFC General EHS Guidelines on Noise presented in Table 3-4 is from World Health Organization Guidelines for Community Noise (1999). p. 77 Noise Level Standards in dBA
7 facts â–¼
  • For houses and residential areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 sets a noise limit of 55 dBA.
  • IFC guidelines for houses and residential areas specify 55 dBA for daytime (7:00 to 22:00) and 45 dBA for nighttime (22:00 to 07:00).
  • For trade and services areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 sets a noise limit of 70 dBA.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • For houses and residential areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 sets a noise limit of 55 dBA.
  • IFC guidelines for houses and residential areas specify 55 dBA for daytime (7:00 to 22:00) and 45 dBA for nighttime (22:00 to 07:00).
  • For trade and services areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 sets a noise limit of 70 dBA.
  • IFC guidelines for trade and services areas specify 70 dBA for both daytime and nighttime.
  • For offices and trade areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 sets a noise limit of 65 dBA.
  • This section also introduces Effluent Discharge Controls (EDC) for water discharges and applicable Ambient Water Quality Standards (AWQS).
  • The impact of effluent discharges on the receiving environment is commonly estimated using mathematical or numerical modeling during the design phase.
Original Text
Houses and residential areas, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 = 55. Houses and residential areas, IFC 1 = 55 Daytime (7:00 to 22:00) 45 Nighttime (22:00 to 07:00). Houses and residential areas, Stringent Limit = 55 45. Trade and services, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 = 70. Trade and services, IFC 1 = 70 Daytime (07:00 to 22:00) 70 Nighttime (22:00 to 07:00). Trade and services, Stringent Limit = 70. Offices and trade, MoE Decree No 48 of 1996 = 65. Offices and trade, IFC 1 = 70 Daytime (07:00 to 22:00) 70 ...
This section contains EDC for discharges to water and details applicable Ambient Water Quality Standards (AWQS). As is true for discharges to air, environmental policies involve a combination of effluent discharge controls and ambient environmental quality standards (Figure 3-3)It follows that EDC have to consider both discharge limits and ambient environmental quality standards. p. 78 Domestic Wastewater
10 facts â–¼
  • Sewage is defined as wastewater containing human excrement and/or household wastewater from sanitary conveniences, excluding storm water or industrial...
  • Minister of Environment Decree No. 112 of 2003 defines domestic wastewater as originating from business, resident activity, restaurants, offices, comm...
  • Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 sets a pH standard of 6-9 for domestic wastewater.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Sewage is defined as wastewater containing human excrement and/or household wastewater from sanitary conveniences, excluding storm water or industrial effluents.
  • Minister of Environment Decree No. 112 of 2003 defines domestic wastewater as originating from business, resident activity, restaurants, offices, commerce, apartments, and dormitories.
  • Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 sets a pH standard of 6-9 for domestic wastewater.
  • IFC standards for domestic wastewater also set a pH range of 6-9.
  • Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 sets a BOD limit of 100 mg/l for domestic wastewater.
  • IFC standards set a BOD limit of 30 mg/l for domestic wastewater.
  • Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 sets a Total Suspended Solids (TSS) limit of 100 mg/l for domestic wastewater.
  • IFC standards set a Total Suspended Solids (TSS) limit of 50 mg/l for domestic wastewater.
  • Both Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 and IFC standards set an Oil and Grease limit of 10 mg/l for domestic wastewater.
  • IFC standards set a COD limit of 125 mg/l for domestic wastewater, while the Indonesian decree does not specify one.
Original Text
This document defines sewage as wastewater containing human excrement and/or household wastewater that originate from sanitary conveniences of a dwelling, business, building, or industrial facility. It does not include storm water or industrial effluents. Minister of Environment Decree ( Keputusan Menteri Lingkungan Hidup ) No. 112 of 2003 on Domestic Wastewater Quality Standards defines domestic wastewater as wastewater originating from business and/or resident activity (real estate), r...
pH, Units = pH. pH, Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 = 6 - 9. pH, IFC 1 = 6 - 9. BOD, Units = mg/l. BOD, Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 = 100. BOD, IFC 1 = 30. Total Suspended Solids (TSS), Units = mg/l. Total Suspended Solids (TSS), Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 = 100. Total Suspended Solids (TSS), IFC 1 = 50. Oil and Grease, Units = mg/l. Oil and Grease, Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 2003 = 10. Oil and Grease, IFC 1 = 10. COD, Units = mg/l. COD, Indonesia MoE Decree No 112 of 20...
p. 79 Stormwater Discharge
3 facts â–¼
  • Stormwater runoff will be separated from undisturbed and disturbed areas at the mine and infrastructure sites.
  • Clean water, runoff from undisturbed land, will be channeled away from Elang project areas into the natural watershed.
  • Dirty water, runoff affected by mining operations, processing plants, haul roads, and ancillary activities, will be discharged to a settling pond syst...
  • Stormwater runoff will be separated from undisturbed and disturbed areas at the mine and infrastructure sites.
  • Clean water, runoff from undisturbed land, will be channeled away from Elang project areas into the natural watershed.
  • Dirty water, runoff affected by mining operations, processing plants, haul roads, and ancillary activities, will be discharged to a settling pond system.
Original Text
Stormwater runoff will be separated from undisturbed and disturbed areas at the mine and infrastructure sites. Water can be classed into three types as follow: â–ª Clean Water: water runoff from undisturbed land. Clean water will be channelled away from areas affected by the Elang project and directed into the natural watershed; â–ª Dirty Water: runoff affected by mining operation, processing plant, haul roads and ancillary activities. p. 80 Ambient Water Quality Standard and Waste Management
7 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project must comply with both applicable discharge limits and ambient water environmental quality standards.
  • Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 on Water Quality Management and Water Pollution Control applies to fresh water quality after the mixing zone.
  • Article 41 of Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 requires an assessment of wastewater discharge effects on receiving water resources, considering fis...
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The Elang project must comply with both applicable discharge limits and ambient water environmental quality standards.
  • Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 on Water Quality Management and Water Pollution Control applies to fresh water quality after the mixing zone.
  • Article 41 of Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 requires an assessment of wastewater discharge effects on receiving water resources, considering fish, cattle, plants, soil, and groundwater.
  • The waste management strategy for non-hazardous waste will use colored bins for source segregation.
  • Sorted non-hazardous waste will be stored at a designated area for re-use or recycling.
  • Remaining non-hazardous waste will be disposed of at an authorized engineered landfill according to Law No 18/2008 on Municipal Solid Waste.
  • Hazardous waste (B3) in Indonesia is defined as waste from non-specific sources, expired chemicals, specific sources, or waste with explosive, combustible, reactive, toxic, infectious, or corrosive properties.
Original Text
The Elang project must comply with both applicable discharge limits and ambient water environmental quality standards. Government Regulation No 82 of 2001 on Water Quality Management and Water Pollution Control applies to fresh water quality after mixing zone and defines expected water quality based on defined water usage (Class I to IV). Article 41 requires that the Elang project shall perform an assessment of the effects of wastewater discharge on the receiving water resource consi...
Chapter 3.5 summarizes applicable laws and regulations to waste management, differentiating between non-hazardous and hazardous waste.
The waste management strategy for non-hazardous waste (food scraps, paper wastes, plastic wrap, etc.) will incorporate the use of coloured bins for the purpose of segregating waste, at the source, according to waste type, where it will be temporarily stored. Sorting of waste will be carried out at a designated waste storage area where material can be sorted for re-use or recycling (i.e., scrap metal, cardboard, scrap wood, etc.). Remainder of waste will be disposed at an authorized engineered la...
Based on Indonesia regulations, waste is considered to be hazardous waste (abbreviated Bahan Berbahaya dan Beracun or B3) if it is derived from: â–ª A listed hazardous waste from non-specific source; â–ª Expired chemical products or hazardous product rejects that do not meet specifications; â–ª A listed hazardous waste from specific source (general specific source and specific source); or â–ª A waste that has one or more of the following properties: Explosive, Combustible, Reactiv...
p. 81 Deep Sea Tailing Placement (DSTP)
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project proposes to continue the Deep-Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) practice, successfully adopted by the Batu Hijau Mine for 20 years.
  • The AMNT DSTP scheme is adopted in Government Regulation Number 101 of 2014, Attachment I Table 4, which defines DSTP requirements.
  • Tailings are categorized as B3 waste from a specific source with B3 waste code B416 and hazard category 2.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang project proposes to continue the Deep-Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) practice, successfully adopted by the Batu Hijau Mine for 20 years.
  • The AMNT DSTP scheme is adopted in Government Regulation Number 101 of 2014, Attachment I Table 4, which defines DSTP requirements.
  • Tailings are categorized as B3 waste from a specific source with B3 waste code B416 and hazard category 2.
  • Ministry of Environment and Forestry No 12 of 2018 provides further directives regarding requirements and procedures for waste dumping to the sea.
Original Text
The Elang project proposes to continue the successful Deep-Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) practice adopted by the Batu Hijau Mine for the last 20 years. AMNT DSTP scheme has been adopted in Government Regulation Number 101 of 2014 concerning the Toxic and Hazardous Waste Management Attachment I Table 4, which defines the requirements for DSTP; tailings are categorized as B3 waste from specific source with B3 waste code of B416 and hazard category 2. p. 82 Waste Rock Management and Water Availability
6 facts â–¼
  • Waste rock is excavated material to reach the ore, with the amount depending on ore body geometry, mining method, and rock composition/stability.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Mining recommend planning waste rock dumps with appropriate terrace and lift height specifications to minimize erosion and redu...
  • Management of Potentially Acid Generating (PAG) wastes should be implemented.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Waste rock is excavated material to reach the ore, with the amount depending on ore body geometry, mining method, and rock composition/stability.
  • IFC EHS Guidelines for Mining recommend planning waste rock dumps with appropriate terrace and lift height specifications to minimize erosion and reduce safety risks.
  • Management of Potentially Acid Generating (PAG) wastes should be implemented.
  • The Elang project commits to not compromising water availability for host communities, considering future increases in demand.
  • The overall target for water availability for host communities and workers is 100 liters per person per day.
  • The Minister of Home Affairs No 23 of 2006 specifies the standard for basic potable water needs as 10 mÂ³/head of family/month or 60 liters per person per day.
Original Text
Waste rock is the rock that is excavated to reach the ore. The amount of waste rock that needs to be removed depends on the geometry and location of the ore body, along with the mining method used and the composition and stability of the rocks. The IFC EHS Guidelines for Mining recommends the following management of WRS: â–ª Dumps should be planned with appropriate terrace and lift height specifications based on the nature of the material and local geotechnical considerations to minimiz...
The Elang project will not compromise the availability of water for host communities taking into account future increases in water demand. The overall target of water availability for host communities and workers is 100 liters per person per day although only lower levels may be achievable (WHO, 2003). The Minister of Home Affairs No 23 of 2006 regarding Technical Guidelines and Water Tariff Regulation at Regional Water Companies ( Perusahaan Daerah Air Minum PDAM -) specifies the...
p. 85 Project Description
8 facts â–¼
  • PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) plans to develop the Elang Copper Gold mining project.
  • The Elang project will replace production from the existing Batu Hijau Copper Gold project, which has been operational since 2000.
  • The new open pit mine will be located 60 km east of Batu Hijau.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) plans to develop the Elang Copper Gold mining project.
  • The Elang project will replace production from the existing Batu Hijau Copper Gold project, which has been operational since 2000.
  • The new open pit mine will be located 60 km east of Batu Hijau.
  • The Elang mine is planned to produce 68.3 million metric tons per year of ore.
  • The total ore production over the mine life is estimated to be 1,000 to 1,500 million metric tons.
  • The mine life for the Elang project is projected to be 18 to 24 years.
  • Ore from Elang will be transported by a new overland conveyor to Batu Hijau for processing.
  • Processing at Batu Hijau will produce approximately 800,000 metric tons per year of copper concentrate.
Original Text
Chapter 4 describes the AMNT Elang project elements and its associated facilities. The chapter also provides the considered project alternatives for the Elang mine development.
PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) is planning to develop the Elang Copper Gold mining project to replace production from its existing Batu Hijau Copper Gold project, which has been in production since 2000. The new open pit mine, to be located 60 km east of Batu Hijau, is planned to produce 68.3 million metric tons per year of ore, amounting to around 1,000 to 1,500 million metric tons over an 18 to 24 year mine life. The ore will be transported by a new overland conveyor to Batu Hij...
p. 87 Project Stages
6 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project will comprise four main stages: Pre-construction, Construction, Operation, and Closure/Post-closure.
  • Pre-construction activities include socialization, survey studies, land acquisition, and exploration.
  • Construction activities involve workforce recruitment, site preparation (land clearing), earthworks, equipment mobilization, and building main mining ...
  • + 3 more facts...
  • The Elang Project will comprise four main stages: Pre-construction, Construction, Operation, and Closure/Post-closure.
  • Pre-construction activities include socialization, survey studies, land acquisition, and exploration.
  • Construction activities involve workforce recruitment, site preparation (land clearing), earthworks, equipment mobilization, and building main mining and supporting facilities.
  • The Elang copper-gold orebody will be mined in six stages.
  • The mining period for the Elang orebody is 18-24 years.
  • The final open pit dimensions will be approximately 2,500 m in length, 1,875 m in width, and 785 m to 1,000 m in depth (rim to floor).
Original Text
The Elang Project will comprise four stages and can be seen in Table 4-1. Table 4-1 Elang Project Stages Pre-construction, Project Activity = â–ª Socialization program â–ª Survey study â–ª Land acquisition â–ª Exploration. Construction, Project Activity = â–ª Construction workforce recruitment and mobilization â–ª Site Preparation (Land Clearing) â–ª Earthworks â–ª Mobilization of equipment and materials â–ª Construction of the main mining facilities (e.g. mining, ore processing, waste rock storage, overland con...
The Elang copper-gold orebody will be mined in six stages over a 18-24 year period to produce a large open pit with the following final dimensions: - â–ª Length: 2,500 m; â–ª Width: 1,875 m; â–ª Depth (rim to floor): 785 m to 1,000 m.
p. 88 Geology and Mineral Resources
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang orebody contains copper mineralization, primarily chalcopyrite.
  • The mineralization is hosted in Pliocene-age tonalites that intrude Miocene-age andesitic volcanic rocks and diorite-dacite intrusives.
  • Copper-gold porphyry mineralization developed from porphyry intrusions, quartz veining, hypogene alteration, and along intrusive contacts and faults.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang orebody contains copper mineralization, primarily chalcopyrite.
  • The mineralization is hosted in Pliocene-age tonalites that intrude Miocene-age andesitic volcanic rocks and diorite-dacite intrusives.
  • Copper-gold porphyry mineralization developed from porphyry intrusions, quartz veining, hypogene alteration, and along intrusive contacts and faults.
  • Three distinct mineralization domains are present: Elang, Gerbang, and Ladam.
Original Text
The Elang orebody comprises copper mineralization, mainly chalcopyrite, hosted in a complex of tonalites of Pliocene age, that intrude andesitic volcanic rocks of Miocene age and dioritedacite intrusives. Copper-gold porphyry mineralization has developed from emplacement of porphyry intrusions where quartz veining and hypogene alteration has occurred as well as along intrusive contacts and faults. Three domains of mineralization are present, each with slightly different ore characteristics. Thes...
p. 89 Mine Design and Mining Stages
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang pit wall slopes were designed based on geotechnical study recommendations (Golder, 2018a).
  • Multiple design sectors were delineated based on slope direction, rock type, and degree of weathering.
  • Bench heights, widths, and face angles were selected for each material type and sector to achieve acceptable safety factors.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang pit wall slopes were designed based on geotechnical study recommendations (Golder, 2018a).
  • Multiple design sectors were delineated based on slope direction, rock type, and degree of weathering.
  • Bench heights, widths, and face angles were selected for each material type and sector to achieve acceptable safety factors.
  • Selected safety factors include 1.1 for temporary benches, 1.3 for a final bench adjacent to a haulage ramp, and 2.0 for the overall pit slope.
Original Text
The Elang pit design is shown in plan view on Figure 4-3. Figure 4-3 Elang Pit Design The pit wall slopes have been designed in accordance with geotechnical study recommendations (Golder, 2018a). Multiple design sectors were delineated, based on slope direction, rock type, and degree of weathering. For each material type in each sector, bench heights, bench widths and bench face (batter) angles were selected in order to achieve acceptable safety factors. Selected safety factors incl...
p. 93 Mining Methods
3 facts â–¼
  • Mining at Elang will utilize conventional drill and blast, truck and shovel methods, similar to Batu Hijau.
  • Mining equipment from Batu Hijau is intended to be transferred to Elang as production at Batu Hijau decreases.
  • The mining equipment fleet at Batu Hijau in 2019 included P&H 4100 excavators (5 units, 5 t/hr capacity), Hitachi 5500 excavators (2 units, 3.4 t/hr c...
  • Mining at Elang will utilize conventional drill and blast, truck and shovel methods, similar to Batu Hijau.
  • Mining equipment from Batu Hijau is intended to be transferred to Elang as production at Batu Hijau decreases.
  • The mining equipment fleet at Batu Hijau in 2019 included P&H 4100 excavators (5 units, 5 t/hr capacity), Hitachi 5500 excavators (2 units, 3.4 t/hr capacity), and Hitachi 3600 excavators.
Original Text
As is the case at Batu Hijau, mining will be carried out using conventional drill and blast, truck and shovel methods. In fact, it is intended that, as mine production at Batu Hijau winds down, the equipment will be transferred to Elang. The fleet of mining equipment at Batu Hijau is listed in Table 4-2.
