p. 94 Mine Dewatering and Crusher Pad
7 facts â–¼
  • The water table at the Elang mine ranges between RL 300 and RL 500 m, with a gradient towards the Dodo River.
  • Mine dewatering is required for slope stabilization and to manage groundwater inflows and rainfall runoff in the pit.
  • Hydrogeological studies (Golder, 2018b) evaluated required pumping rates for mine dewatering.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The water table at the Elang mine ranges between RL 300 and RL 500 m, with a gradient towards the Dodo River.
  • Mine dewatering is required for slope stabilization and to manage groundwater inflows and rainfall runoff in the pit.
  • Hydrogeological studies (Golder, 2018b) evaluated required pumping rates for mine dewatering.
  • A Crusher Pad, measuring 180m by 120m, will be constructed at RL 400m adjacent to the Elang Pit exit.
  • The Crusher Pad will require placement of up to 65m of compacted fill after removing weak foundation materials.
  • The Crusher Pad will support two independent dumping and crushing circuits, each serving two 300T dump trucks.
  • Ore will be crushed from -1000mm to -200mm by Gyratory crushers.
Original Text
The water table at the Elang mine location follows a subdued version of the topography with elevations ranging between RL 300 and RL 500 m and an overall gradient toward the Dodo River. As most of the Elang ore is located below the water table, dewatering will be required for slope stabilization. In addition, groundwater inflows as well as rainfall runoff will need to be pumped from the pit in order to maintain access to the pit floor. Hydrogeological studies have been carried out (Golder, 2018b...
A Crusher Pad will be constructed adjacent to the exit from the Elang Pit. This will require the placement of compacted waste rock to form a flat bench at RL 400m. Following the removal of weak foundation materials, this will require placement of up to 65m of compacted fill. Within this bench, the Crusher Pad will occupy 180m by 120m and will support two independent dumping and crushing circuits. Dumping will utilize two hoppers, each of which can simultaneously serve two 300T dum...
p. 95 Waste Rock Storage
5 facts â–¼
  • A single Waste Rock Storage (WRS) is planned to store up to 600 million BCM (approximately 700 million loose cubic metres) of waste rock.
  • The WRS will occupy an area of approximately 700 ha, located southwest of the Elang pit.
  • The WRS area will also provide temporary storage for topsoil.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • A single Waste Rock Storage (WRS) is planned to store up to 600 million BCM (approximately 700 million loose cubic metres) of waste rock.
  • The WRS will occupy an area of approximately 700 ha, located southwest of the Elang pit.
  • The WRS area will also provide temporary storage for topsoil.
  • Current planning does not require a low-grade ore stockpile, but the WRS could accommodate it if needed.
  • The WRS will be constructed by 'bottom up' placement of compacted waste rock.
Original Text
A single, large Waste Rock Storage (WRS) is planned, that will store up to 600 million BCM of waste rock (approximately 700 million loose cubic metres), within an area of approximately 700 ha, part of a broad valley of relatively low relief, located to the southwest of the Elang pit as shown on Figure 4-8. The WRS area will also provide temporary storage for topsoil. Current planning does not require a low-grade ore stockpile; however, this could also be accommodated within the overall WRS sho...
p. 96 Design of the WRS
4 facts â–¼
  • Golder Associates (Golder, 2018c) provided the design for the WRS following a geotechnical investigation.
  • The final WRS footprint covers approximately 70% of the catchment area of the valley.
  • The WRS crest will be at RL 600 m, with a toe to crest height of 320 m, resulting in a maximum thickness of 280m.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Golder Associates (Golder, 2018c) provided the design for the WRS following a geotechnical investigation.
  • The final WRS footprint covers approximately 70% of the catchment area of the valley.
  • The WRS crest will be at RL 600 m, with a toe to crest height of 320 m, resulting in a maximum thickness of 280m.
  • The geometric parameters for the WRS configuration include an Angle of Repose of 37Â° (1.3H:1V).
Original Text
Following a geotechnical investigation, Golder Associates (Golder, 2018c) provided the design for the WRS. The final dump footprint covers approximately 70% of the catchment area of the valley in which it is located. With its crest at RL 600 m and a toe to crest height of 320 m the final waste rock storage will have a maximum thickness of 280m. A cross-section through the WRS is shown on Figure 4-9. Source: Golder 2018c Waste Rock Dump Study Figure 4-9 Cross-section Through Waste Rock Storage Th...
p. 98 WRS Construction and Stability
11 facts â–¼
  • The WRS will be constructed up to RL 400 m in the first 5 years (Stage 1).
  • In Stage 2, dumping will commence along the northern boundary up to RL 600 m, then proceed south.
  • The WRS has been designed for a static stability factor of safety of 1.3.
  • + 8 more facts...
  • The WRS will be constructed up to RL 400 m in the first 5 years (Stage 1).
  • In Stage 2, dumping will commence along the northern boundary up to RL 600 m, then proceed south.
  • The WRS has been designed for a static stability factor of safety of 1.3.
  • The WRS has a factor of safety of 1.0 for stability under maximum earthquake loading.
  • Up to 9 m of weak colluvium and weathered volcanic material will be removed from the toe of the WRS.
  • A 20 m high buttress of waste rock, approximately 65 m long and 20 m wide, will be constructed at the WRS toe.
  • Additional weak material will be removed from the base of the WRS for a further 200 m to a depth of 1 to 2 m.
  • Topsoil will be stripped from the entire WRS area to a nominal depth of 30 cm and stored temporarily within WRS limits.
  • Rehabilitation will be progressive, with topsoil added and revegetation commencing as each WRS layer is completed.
  • Potentially acid-forming waste rock (PAF) will be encapsulated by compacted non-acid-forming (NAF) material to minimize acid rock drainage (ARD).
  • The precise arrangement and thicknesses of encapsulating layers for PAF material will be finalized based on NAF material availability.
Original Text
The WRS will be constructed up to RL 400 m in the first 5 years (Stage 1); then in Stage 2 dumping will commence along the northern boundary up to RL 600 m, then proceed south. The WRS has been designed for a factor of safety for static stability of 1.3, and a factor of safety of 1.0 for stability under maximum earthquake loading.
The stability of the WRS will depend partly on the strength of the foundation materials. As the foundations include weak colluvium and weathered volcanic material, up to 9 m of weak material will be removed from the toe of the WRS, after which a 20 m high buttress of waste rock will be constructed with a length of around 65 m and a width of 20 m. Additional weak material will be removed from the base of the WRS for a further 200 m from the buttress to a depth of 1 to 2 m. Material excavated from...
Topsoil will be stripped from the entire WRS area to a nominal depth of 30 cm, and will be stored temporarily within the WRS limits, until it is required for rehabilitation. Rehabilitation will be 'progressive', meaning that, as each layer of the WRS is co mpleted (following trimming and compaction of the bench face), topsoil will be added, and revegetation will commence. The application of topsoil will be scheduled so that freshly excavated or recently excavated topsoil is placed on the bench f...
In order to minimize acid rock drainage (ARD), potentially acid-forming waste rock (PAF) will be encapsulated by compacted non-acid-forming material, meaning that NAF material will be present or be placed below, adjacent to and above the PAF material. The purpose is to minimize ingress of air and water into the PAF material. This is established practice at Batu Hijau. The precise arrangement, including the locations of encapsulated material and thicknesses of encapsulati...
p. 99 Drainage and Erosion Control
7 facts â–¼
  • The WRS will occupy 70% of its sub-catchment area.
  • A temporary diversion channel is proposed for the first 3 to 5 years of operation to reduce runoff to the WRS.
  • Runoff not diverted from upslope areas will discharge onto the WRS and be drained to the Sediment Pond.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The WRS will occupy 70% of its sub-catchment area.
  • A temporary diversion channel is proposed for the first 3 to 5 years of operation to reduce runoff to the WRS.
  • Runoff not diverted from upslope areas will discharge onto the WRS and be drained to the Sediment Pond.
  • Minor drainage channels will be constructed along and between WRS benches to convey runoff.
  • Stepped structures will be constructed in excessively steep diversion channels to minimize flow velocities and scour risk.
  • Erosion protection will be provided in channels where flow velocities are estimated to exceed 2 m/s.
  • Channels along the pit benches will be concrete-lined.
Original Text
As noted previously, the WRS will occupy most (70%) of the sub-catchment area in which it will be located. However, in the early years it will occupy much less. Therefore, a temporary diversion channel is proposed to reduce runoff to the WRS for the first 3 to 5 years of operation. The location of this diversion channel is shown on Figure 4-11.
Runoff that cannot be diverted from areas upslope of the WRS will discharge onto the WRS from where it will be drained to the Sediment Pond. Minor drainage channels will be constructed to convey runoff along and between benches. Where vertical alignments of the diversion channels are excessively steep, stepped structures will be constructed to minimise flow velocities and the risk of scour/damage. Erosion protection will be provided within channels where flow velociti...
p. 100 Rehabilitation and Sediment Pond
11 facts â–¼
  • Rehabilitation will commence as soon as final Waste Rock Storage (WRS) surfaces become available, starting with the Buttress outslope.
  • Topsoil will be placed at a nominal thickness of 30 cm, followed by planting of vegetation using the prescription developed at Batu Hijau.
  • A Sediment Pond is planned on Brang Kuning, downstream of the WRS, to collect runoff and seepage and receive water pumped from the Elang pit.
  • + 8 more facts...
  • Rehabilitation will commence as soon as final Waste Rock Storage (WRS) surfaces become available, starting with the Buttress outslope.
  • Topsoil will be placed at a nominal thickness of 30 cm, followed by planting of vegetation using the prescription developed at Batu Hijau.
  • A Sediment Pond is planned on Brang Kuning, downstream of the WRS, to collect runoff and seepage and receive water pumped from the Elang pit.
  • The Sediment Pond design is based on geotechnical, hydrological, and hydrogeological investigations (Golder 2018c, Golder 2018d).
  • A 40 m high embankment with a crest at RL 280 m will impound approximately 1,910 ML (1.91 million mÂ³) of water.
  • The Sediment Pond's full supply level will be at RL 277, with a minimum operating freeboard of 2.0m.
  • An emergency spillway, 60m wide and 3m deep, with an invert at RL 277, is planned for the Sediment Pond.
  • The Sediment Pond embankment will have a crest length of 140 m and a crest width of 11.0 m.
  • The upstream and downstream slopes of the embankment will both be 1.0V : 2.0H.
  • The maximum height of the embankment above natural surface will be 40m.
  • The Sediment Pond embankment will be constructed mainly from compacted waste rock, including a clay core, internal drain, and upstream rip rap protection.
Original Text
As mentioned, rehabilitation will commence as soon as final WRS surfaces become available, commencing with the Buttress outslope, followed by each successively higher bench face and berm. Following final compaction, topsoil will be placed at a nominal thickness of 30 cm, followed by planting of vegetation. The prescription for establishing vegetation developed at Batu Hijau will be used. This involves the following procedures. â–ª Surface preparation, including removal of rocks and branches â–ª Row ...
A Sediment Pond is planned on Brang Kuning, downstream of the WRS, to collect all runoff and any seepage from the WRS and is also sized to receive water pumped from the Elang pit. The Sediment Pond design has been based on geotechnical, hydrological and hydrogeological investigations (Golder 2018c, Golder 2018d). A 40 m high embankment will be constructed with a crest at RL 280 m to impound around 1,910 ML (1.91 million m ) of water with a full 3 supply level at RL 277. Operating freeboard...
The proposed Sediment Pond embankment is shown in plan and cross-section on Figure 4-12. The embankment will have the following dimensions: â–ª Crest Length: 140 m â–ª Crest Width: 11.0 m â–ª Upstream Slope: 1.0V : 2.0H â–ª Downstream Slope: 1.0V : 2.0H - â–ª Maximum Height (above natural surface): 40m Figure 4-12 Sediment Pond Embankment -Plan and Section The Sediment Pond embankment will be constructed mainly from compacted waste rock, but will also have a clay core, internal drain and upstream rip rap ...
p. 101 Sediment Pond Operation
5 facts â–¼
  • Deposited sediment will be periodically removed from the upstream basin of the Sediment Pond to maintain its capacity.
  • Recovered sediment from the pond will be placed in the Waste Rock Storage (WRS).
  • Preliminary studies suggest up to 150,000 mÂ³/day of water could enter the Sediment Pond under worst-case rainfall conditions.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Deposited sediment will be periodically removed from the upstream basin of the Sediment Pond to maintain its capacity.
  • Recovered sediment from the pond will be placed in the Waste Rock Storage (WRS).
  • Preliminary studies suggest up to 150,000 mÂ³/day of water could enter the Sediment Pond under worst-case rainfall conditions.
  • Flows into the Sediment Pond will be significantly reduced by the mid-dry season due to strong seasonality of rainfall.
  • Uncontaminated water from upstream of the Elang Pit and WRS will be diverted into Brang Dodo to minimize rainfall runoff to the Sediment Pond.
Original Text
Suspended sediment entering the Sediment Pond will deposit within the pond. In order to maintain the capacity of the pond it will be necessary, periodically, to remove deposited sediment from the upstream basin. Sediment recovered from the pond will be placed in the WRS.
The strong seasonality of rainfall and the changes in water balance as mining proceeds mean that stormwater, pit water and seepage flows will vary considerably, both seasonally and over the Elang project life span. Preliminary studies suggest that up to 150,000 m /day of water 3 could enter the Sediment Pond under worst case rainfall conditions. However, late by the middry season, flows will be much reduced. In order to minimize rainfall runoff to the Sediment Pond, uncontaminated water from u...
p. 102 Ancillary Facilities at Elang
5 facts â–¼
  • Ancillary facilities at Elang will include a Mine workshop and storage, administration facilities, mining facilities, and electrical facilities.
  • The existing 25 km access track from Lunyuk to Elang will be upgraded to form the main Lunyuk Access Road during construction.
  • A 9-hectare area located 2 km west of the Elang pit has been selected for the Workshop facilities.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Ancillary facilities at Elang will include a Mine workshop and storage, administration facilities, mining facilities, and electrical facilities.
  • The existing 25 km access track from Lunyuk to Elang will be upgraded to form the main Lunyuk Access Road during construction.
  • A 9-hectare area located 2 km west of the Elang pit has been selected for the Workshop facilities.
  • Workshop facilities will include a truck and heavy equipment workshop, truck washdown area, shovel laydown area, welding shop, body shop, crusher workshop, tire shop, electrical sub-station, fuel and lube storage, maintenance warehouse, and offices and training facilities.
  • Administration facilities will include offices, a mess hall, training facilities, a mosque, a parking area, a water treatment plant, a warehouse and laydown area, a security gate, a concrete batch plant and aggregate crushing plant, a soil laboratory, a small vehicle fuel station, a weather station, and an electrical sub-station.
Original Text
Facilities to support the Elang mining operation will include: Mine workshop and storage; administration facilities; mining facilities and electrical facilities. The main components included are listed below.
There is an existing access track from Lunyuk to Elang, a distance of around 25 km. This track will be upgraded during the construction stage to form the main Lunyuk Access Road, linking Lunyuk, the accommodation area and mining operations.
A 9-ha area located 2 km west of the Elang pit has been selected as the site for the Workshop facilities which will include: â–ª Truck and heavy equipment workshop; â–ª Truck washdown area; â–ª Shovel laydown area; â–ª Welding shop; â–ª Body shop; â–ª Crusher workshop; â–ª Tire shop; â–ª Electrical sub-station; â–ª Fuel and lube storage; â–ª Maintenance warehouse; and â–ª Offices and training facilities.
Administration facilities will include: â–ª Offices, mess hall, training, mosque, and parking area; â–ª Water treatment plant; â–ª Warehouse and laydown area; â–ª Security gate; â–ª Concrete batch plant and aggregate crushing plant; â–ª Soil laboratory; and â–ª Small vehicle fuel station; â–ª Weather station; and â–ª Electrical sub-station.
p. 103 Mining Facilities and Logistics
4 facts â–¼
  • Mining facilities will be located close to the Crushing Plant.
  • Mining facilities will include offices, a core shed, an explosive batching area, a detonator magazine and security post, crib rooms and ablutions, a c...
  • Construction of a new port on the south coast of Sumbawa for Elang operations was deemed highly expensive due to oceanographic conditions.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Mining facilities will be located close to the Crushing Plant.
  • Mining facilities will include offices, a core shed, an explosive batching area, a detonator magazine and security post, crib rooms and ablutions, a crusher dispatch tower, a crusher control room, a fuel station, a water truck filling stand, and parking and laydown areas.
  • Construction of a new port on the south coast of Sumbawa for Elang operations was deemed highly expensive due to oceanographic conditions.
  • Supplies for Elang will be delivered to the existing Benete Port on the west coast of Sumbawa and transferred to Elang by road.
Original Text
Mining facilities will be located close to the Crushing Plant and will include: â–ª Offices; â–ª Core shed; â–ª Explosive batching area, detonator magazine and security post; â–ª Crib rooms and ablutions; â–ª Crusher dispatch tower; â–ª Crusher control room; â–ª Fuel station; â–ª Water truck filling stand; â–ª Parking and laydown areas.
There are no existing port facilities close to the Elang mine. The feasibility of constructing a port on the south coast of Sumbawa to serve the Elang operations has been investigated. However, the oceanographic conditions include a rapidly shelving sea-bed from the shoreline to depth, and a high energy wave climate for much of the year. Accordingly, a port in this situation would be highly expensive. It is therefore proposed that supplies for Elang will be delivered to the existing Benete Port ...
p. 104 Workforce Accommodation and Ore Transport
8 facts â–¼
  • Many mine workers from Batu Hijau will be transferred to Elang as mining there concludes.
  • Additional workers will be recruited from Lunyuk and will commute by bus.
  • Accommodation will be provided on-site for a workforce of 750, including company staff and contractor workers.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Many mine workers from Batu Hijau will be transferred to Elang as mining there concludes.
  • Additional workers will be recruited from Lunyuk and will commute by bus.
  • Accommodation will be provided on-site for a workforce of 750, including company staff and contractor workers.
  • Workforce accommodations and associated facilities will occupy an area of 60 hectares.
  • Two sites are being considered for accommodation: one about 3 km from the port site and another to the northwest of the mine site.
  • An Overland Conveyor (OLC) has been selected as the most practical and cost-effective option for transporting ore from Elang to Batu Hijau.
  • Two alternative OLC routes were evaluated: a direct route of 56.7 km and a southern route of 74.7 km that avoids Protected Forest (Hutan Lindung).
  • The direct OLC route is preferred due to a smaller footprint, reduced earthworks, avoidance of local communities, and lower capital and operating costs.
Original Text
As mining at Batu Hijau draws to a close, many of the mine workers will be transferred to Elang. Additional workers will be recruited from Lunyuk. Those from Lunyuk will travel to and from the site by bus. Workers from elsewhere will be accommodated on site during their rostered work periods. Accommodation will be provided for a workforce of 750, including company staff and contractor workers. The accommodations and associated facilities will occupy an area of 60ha. Two sites are being ...
After considering a variety of alternatives for transport of ore from Elang to Batu Hijau, an Overland Conveyor (OLC) has been selected as the most practical and cost-effective option. Two alternative routes, shown on Figure 4-13, have been evaluated: a direct route, 56.7 km in length; and a southern route, 74.7 km in length, that avoids Protected Forest ( Hutan Lindung ). The direct route is preferred on the basis of smaller footprint, reduced earthworks, avoidance of local commun...
p. 107 Additions to Batu Hijau Processing Facilities
5 facts â–¼
  • The existing Batu Hijau processing facilities include two parallel grinding circuits and a single pebble crushing facility.
  • The processing facilities will be substantially expanded to handle additional ore from Elang.
  • New facilities will include a new grinding circuit with two SAG mills, each paired with a single ball mill, similar to existing mills but with higher ...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The existing Batu Hijau processing facilities include two parallel grinding circuits and a single pebble crushing facility.
  • The processing facilities will be substantially expanded to handle additional ore from Elang.
  • New facilities will include a new grinding circuit with two SAG mills, each paired with a single ball mill, similar to existing mills but with higher installed power.
  • Tailings from the Batu Hijau process plant are currently discharged via a Deep-Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) system.
  • The DSTP system involves a 3.2 km seabed pipeline discharging into a submarine canyon at a depth of around 13 meters.
Original Text
The existing processing facilities at Batu Hijau comprise two parallel grinding circuits, each with a SAG mill and two ball mills. A single pebble crushing facility is included. There are five trains of 10 rougher and scavenger flotation cells followed by a regrind and cleaner flotation circuit. These processing facilities will be substantially expanded to handle the additional ore supply from Elang. The following new facilities will be constructed: â–ª A new grinding circuit comprising two SAG mi...

p. 111 Additional Coal Fired Power Plant
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project will increase electric power demand from 112 MW to approximately 365 MW by 2025.
  • Existing power is supplied by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators (total 136 MW) and nine 5 MW diesel generators (total 45 MW).
  • Two options for additional power generation are being considered: a subcritical Pulverised Coal Injection Coal Fired Power Plant (CFPP) or a Gas fired...
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang project will increase electric power demand from 112 MW to approximately 365 MW by 2025.
  • Existing power is supplied by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators (total 136 MW) and nine 5 MW diesel generators (total 45 MW).
  • Two options for additional power generation are being considered: a subcritical Pulverised Coal Injection Coal Fired Power Plant (CFPP) or a Gas fired Combined Cycle Power Plant (CCPP).
  • Changes to the layout of existing facilities at Benete Bay will be required for the addition of new CFPPs or CCPPs.
Original Text
The new mining, ore transportation and processing facilities to be constructed for the Elang project will increase the electric power demand from the existing base of around 112 MW, to around 365 MW by 2025. The existing power is provided by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators with a total capacity of 136 MW, plus nine 5 MW diesel generators with a combined capacity of 45 MW. Two options for additional power generation are being considered: â–ª CFPP -Coal Fired Power Plant. Th...
For the addition of two new CFPPs or CCPPs changes will be required to the layout of existing facilities at Benete Bay. The layout of existing and new power generation facilities is shown on Figure 4-19. Source: Aurecon Coal Fired Power Plant Study, 2018 Figure 4-19 Layout of Existing and New Power Generation Facilities at Benete Bay
p. 112 Emission Controls
4 facts â–¼
  • Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx), and particulates (PM) will be controlled to comply with applicable regulatory standards.
  • NOx will be controlled using low NOx burners, with a MoE Regulation limit of 750 mg/Nm3 and IFC EHS Guideline limit of 510 mg/Nm3.
  • SOx will be controlled by using low sulphur coal and/or flue gas desulphurization (FGD).
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx), and particulates (PM) will be controlled to comply with applicable regulatory standards.
  • NOx will be controlled using low NOx burners, with a MoE Regulation limit of 750 mg/Nm3 and IFC EHS Guideline limit of 510 mg/Nm3.
  • SOx will be controlled by using low sulphur coal and/or flue gas desulphurization (FGD).
  • Particulates will be controlled by electrostatic precipitation (ESP).
Original Text
Emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx) and particulates (PM) will be controlled to comply with the applicable regulatory standards (Table 4-3), by means of low NOx burners, use of low sulphur coal, and either flue gas desulphurization (FGD) or electrostatic precipitation (ESP), respectively. Table 4-3 Flue Gas Standards for Coal Fired Power Plants Parameter, 1 = MoE Regulations 1 (mg/Nm 3 ). Parameter, 2 = IFC EHS Guidelines - Thermal Power Plant 2. Ni...
p. 113 Cooling Water Management
14 facts â–¼
  • The new CFPP will use a once-through seawater cooling system, utilizing the same intake and discharge locations as the existing CFPP.
  • A through-flow of 20 m3/sec is required for the new CFPP's cooling water.
  • Further studies are planned to model the heated water discharge plume to ensure compliance with a maximum 40Â°C discharge temperature and a maximum tem...
  • + 11 more facts...
  • The new CFPP will use a once-through seawater cooling system, utilizing the same intake and discharge locations as the existing CFPP.
  • A through-flow of 20 m3/sec is required for the new CFPP's cooling water.
  • Further studies are planned to model the heated water discharge plume to ensure compliance with a maximum 40Â°C discharge temperature and a maximum temperature increase (Î”T) of 2Â°C outside the mixing zone.
  • Coal consumption is estimated at approximately 1.2 million t/y, based on a burn rate of 72 t/h per unit.
  • Coal will be delivered to the existing Coal Jetty at Benete Bay by vessels with capacities between 10,000 DWT and 45,000 DWT.
  • A new coal stockpile and conveyor facilities will be developed for additional coal storage.
  • Fly ash and bottom ash from CFPPs are designated as 'B3' (hazardous wastes) by Indonesian authorities.
  • Indicative quantities of ash produced are 28,000 t/y for fly ash and 8,000 t/y for bottom ash.
  • Additional ash storage will be required to accommodate up to 100 days of ash production.
  • Batu Hijau operations have a B3 waste permit to dispose of fly ash in Waste Rock Storage facilities, which is also a possibility for Elang.
  • A new 150 kV overhead power transmission line, 20.5 km long, will connect Benete to Batu Hijau mine.
  • The transmission line will extend an additional 74.6 km to the new Elang mine.
  • The power line will consist of approximately 218 galvanized steel monopole towers, each 33 m tall.
  • Ten substations will be located along the OLC route to supply drive motors.
Original Text
The existing CFPP uses a once through sea water cooling system and it is planned that the new CFPP will use the same locations as the existing CFPP for cooling water intake and cooling water discharge. A through flow of 20 m /sec is required for the new CFPP. Further studies 3 are planned to model the heated water discharge plume. Depending on the results, the intake and outfall locations may need to be changed so as to meet the maximum 40Â°C discharge temperature (Ministry of Environment Dec...
Coal consumption is estimated at around 1.2 million t/y, based on a burn rate of 72 t/h for each unit. As is the case at present, coal will be delivered to the existing Coal Jetty at Benete Bay by bulk cargo vessels/barges with capacities between 10,000 DWT and 45,000 DWT. A new coal stockpile and conveyor facilities will be developed to accommodate the additional coal storage requirement.
Fly ash and bottom ash from CFPPs are designated as Bahan Berbahaya dan Beracun or ' B3 ' (hazardous wastes) by Indonesian authorities. The quantities of ash that will be produced will depend on the quality of the coal, with indicative quantities shown below: â€¢ Fly ash: 28,000 t/y; â€¢ Bottom ash: 8,000 t/y Additional ash storage will be required to accommodate up to 100 days of ash production. The Batu Hijau operations have obtained a B3 waste permit to dispose of fly ash in the WRSs where it pro...
A new 150 kV overhead power transmission line will be constructed to connect the upgraded interconnection switchyard at Benete to the existing Batu Hijau mine (a distance of 20.5 km) and thence to the new Elang mine (a distance of 74.6 km). The power line will be strung between 33 m tall galvanized steel monopole towers and will follow a route close to the OLC and Service Road. Around 218 towers will be required. In addition, 10 substations will be located along the OLC route to supply the driv...
p. 114 Storm Water Management and Project Workforce
15 facts â–¼
  • New facilities at Batu Hijau and Benete will integrate storm water drainage into existing systems.
  • Storm water management measures will be installed in areas for mine services, administration, and accommodation.
  • Drains, culverts, and bridges will be designed based on design rainfall intensity with controlled discharge.
  • + 12 more facts...
  • New facilities at Batu Hijau and Benete will integrate storm water drainage into existing systems.
  • Storm water management measures will be installed in areas for mine services, administration, and accommodation.
  • Drains, culverts, and bridges will be designed based on design rainfall intensity with controlled discharge.
  • The Seaplane service between Mataram and Benete will continue.
  • Mine workers and visitors will be transported along an upgraded 7-m wide asphalt provincial road or Primary Access Road.
  • Communications systems will be established between Batu Hijau and Elang, including for OLC operation and monitoring.
  • A construction workforce of around 3,000 people may be required for new facilities, OLC, and Elang port, mine, and town.
  • Contract provisions will ensure contractors observe AMNT environmental standards and employee Code of Conduct.
  • The current Batu Hijau workforce, including contractors, totals around 6,000.
  • The Elang mining workforce is anticipated to absorb the Batu Hijau mining workforce.
  • Additional processing activities at Batu Hijau, the new CFPP at Benete, and OLC operations will generate an estimated 800 new jobs.
  • The most recent Mine Closure Plan (MCP) for Batu Hijau was approved in January 2019.
  • Processing facilities, power plants, and tailings disposal facilities for Elang are included in the Batu Hijau MCP.
  • Post-mining bonds deposited include US$161,952,507 in 2011 and US$31,580,738.70 in 2018.
  • A Mine Closure Plan for Elang will be prepared at the outset of the project and updated periodically.
Original Text
The new facilities to be constructed at Batu Hijau and Benete will be located within or adjacent to existing facilities. The storm water drainage for these new facilities will be integrated into the existing storm water drainage system. Storm water management measures will be installed in areas developed for the mine services, administration and accommodation facilities. Drains, culverts and bridges (if required) will be designed based on design rainfall intensity, with cont...
The Seaplane service between Mataram and Benete will continue. Mine workers and visitors will be transported from Benete to Elang and return, along an upgraded 7-m wide, asphalt provincial road or along the Primary Access Road. Communications systems will be established between Batu Hijau and Elang. The Benete -Elang transmission line will include communications facilities required for operating and monitoring the OLC.
Based on other comparable mine construction projects in Indonesia, a construction workforce of around 3,000 people may be required to construct the new facilities at Benete and Batu Hihau as well as the OLC and Elang port, mine and town facilities. While the contractors will be responsible for providing accommodation and subsistence for their employees, contract provisions will be included to ensure that contractors observe applicable AMNT environmental standards, including the employee Code of ...
The current Batu Hijau workforce, including contractor's employees, totals around 6,000. It is anticipated that the Elang mining workforce will absorb the Batu Hijau mining workforce as production from Batu Hijau draws to a close. The overall mining workforce is therefore likely to increase only slightly. The additional processing activities at Batu Hijau, the new CFPP at Benete, and the OLC operations will generate an estimated 800 new jobs.
The most recent Mine Closure Plan (MCP) for Batu Hijau was submitted in 2018 (Amman Mineral, 2018) and approved in January 2019. The processing facilities, power plants and tailings disposal facilities that will be used for Elang are included in the Batu Hijau MCP. Postmining bonds that have been deposited to date include US$161,952,507 in 2011 and US$31,580,738.70 in 2018. A schedule for further post-mining bonds has been agreed. A Mine Closure Plan for Elang will be pre...

p. 116 Estimated Outputs and Project Alternatives
10 facts â–¼
  • Annual concentrate production is estimated at 878,000 tonnes (average).
  • Annual copper production is estimated at up to 200,000 tonnes.
  • Waste rock annual production is 100 million tonnes in Year 1, 60 to 70 million tonnes in Years 2 to 17, and declining after Year 17.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Annual concentrate production is estimated at 878,000 tonnes (average).
  • Annual copper production is estimated at up to 200,000 tonnes.
  • Waste rock annual production is 100 million tonnes in Year 1, 60 to 70 million tonnes in Years 2 to 17, and declining after Year 17.
  • Annual tailings production is estimated at up to 75 million tonnes.
  • Used oil will be added to coal for power generation.
  • Calculated quantities for new CFPPs particulate emissions assume the same emissions per tonne as existing CFPPs.
  • The 'No action' alternative would result in no adverse environmental impacts but loss of government revenues and employment.
  • The 'Stand-alone project' alternative would involve Elang having its own processing, power generation, tailings disposal, and concentrate handling facilities.
  • Conveyor systems for ore transportation are considered quiet, dust easily controlled, and have relatively low operating costs.
  • The 'No action' scenario would lead to a loss of around 6000 jobs when the Batu Hijau project finishes.

A wide range and variety of alternatives have been considered for development of the Elang copper-gold deposits. p. 121 Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention
6 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project is designed to comply with applicable Indonesian laws and regulations, and Good International Industry Practice (GIIP) standards, in...
  • AMNT will integrate clean production principles, conserving raw materials, energy, and water, into Project design and production processes.
  • AMNT adopts financially, technically feasible, and cost-effective measures to improve efficiency in energy, water, and other resource consumption.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • The Elang project is designed to comply with applicable Indonesian laws and regulations, and Good International Industry Practice (GIIP) standards, including the IFC EHS Guidelines.
  • AMNT will integrate clean production principles, conserving raw materials, energy, and water, into Project design and production processes.
  • AMNT adopts financially, technically feasible, and cost-effective measures to improve efficiency in energy, water, and other resource consumption.
  • The key natural resource used by the Elang Project is copper-gold ore.
  • The most efficient approach to exploiting the Elang ore body is open-pit mining.
  • The Elang ore body consists of 2.373 billion metric tonnes of ore at an average grade of 0.32% copper.
Original Text
Chapter 3 describes the IFC Performance Standard 3 (PS3) on Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention which dictates that project proponents (in this case, AMNT) should consider any principles and techniques that could impact human health and the environment be should be avoided or, if avoidance is impossible, the impact should be minimized. In this context, it is important to note that the Elang project is designed to comply with applicable Indonesian laws and regulati...
Throughout the Elang Project life cycle, AMNT will integrate principles of clean production -conserving raw materials, energy, and water -into Project design and the associated production processes. AMNT adopts financially, technically feasible and cost-effective measures to improve efficiency in the consumption of energy and water, as well as the use of other resources that are considered core to the business activities. Current resource usage for the AMNT operations are summa...
The key natural resource used by the Elang Project (and the Batu Hijau operations as well) is copper-gold ore. As is the case at the Batu Hijau Mine, the most efficient approach to exploiting the Elang ore body is open-pit mining, as described in some detail in Chapter 4. The design configuration of the mining pit is determined by the structure of the ore body, which (as defined in Chapter 4 Project Description (Subsection 4.3.1.1)) consists of 2.373 billion metric ton...
p. 123 Other Raw Materials and Energy Resources
10 facts â–¼
  • Beyond energy fuel resources, no other raw materials are used in mining operations.
  • Various chemical and other commodities, such as lime for power plant scrubbers, are used in maintenance and support activities.
  • The smelter, an associated facility, will require lime and other auxiliary input materials, besides copper concentrate.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Beyond energy fuel resources, no other raw materials are used in mining operations.
  • Various chemical and other commodities, such as lime for power plant scrubbers, are used in maintenance and support activities.
  • The smelter, an associated facility, will require lime and other auxiliary input materials, besides copper concentrate.
  • The land occupied, topsoil, and forest resources disturbed or destroyed by the Elang project are considered important resources.
  • Terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems disturbed, disrupted, or potentially destroyed are also of importance.
  • Efficiency in resource use is a focus of the ESIA process, including the regulatory AMDAL process.
  • The energy resources utilized for the mining Project are electricity and fossil fuels.
  • In 2017, Batu Hijau operations used 919,101 Megawatt-hours (MWh) of electricity, increasing to 943,013 MWh in 2018.
  • Diesel fuel powers transportation, heavy equipment, small generators, and pumps.
  • Aviation turbine fuel (ATF or Avtur) is used for helicopters and the seaplane.
Original Text
Outside of energy fuel resources, described in the appropriate subsection below, there are no other raw materials used in the mining operations. Various chemical and other commodities are used in maintenance and support activities, such as lime in the power plant scrubbers. The smelter, an associated facility, will also require lime and other auxiliary input materials, beside copper concentrate, as discussed in the separate copper smelter environmental and social impact assessment.
The land occupied by the mining operations, as well as the topsoil and forest resources disturbed or effectively destroyed by the Elang project, are other resources that need to be considered. The terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems disturbed, disrupted, or potentially destroyed are also of importance. Efficiency in use of these resources is the focus of the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment process, including the regulatory AMDAL process. In...
The energy resources utilized for the mining Project are electricity and fossil fuels. As discussed in Subsection 5.2.1, the combination of coal- and diesel-fired generating stations in 2017 provided the Batu Hijau operation with 919,101 Megawatt-hours (MWh) of electricity, increasing to 943,013 MWh in 2018. Diesel fuel is also used to power transportation, heavy equipment, small generators, and pumps. Aviation turbine fuel (ATF or Avtur) is used to power helicopters and the seaplan...
p. 124 Water Resources and Air Quality
7 facts â–¼
  • Water supply at Batu Hijau primarily comes from groundwater aquifers in two watersheds.
  • Water consumption at Batu Hijau and Elang Blocks was over 3.5 million cubic meters in 2017 and continued at similar rates in the first half of 2018.
  • Numerous Project activities discharge effluent into surface water and seawater.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • Water supply at Batu Hijau primarily comes from groundwater aquifers in two watersheds.
  • Water consumption at Batu Hijau and Elang Blocks was over 3.5 million cubic meters in 2017 and continued at similar rates in the first half of 2018.
  • Numerous Project activities discharge effluent into surface water and seawater.
  • The Sumbawa airsheds are generally pristine, but dust problems can occur during the long dry season.
  • Occasional smoke and haze from forest and land fires are noted in the Sumbawa airsheds.
  • Existing air pollutant sources in the Elang project Area of Influence include dust from open land and emissions from vehicles and heavy equipment.
  • The 140 MW coal-fired power plant (CFPP) on Benete Bay is a major existing emission source.
Original Text
Water supply at Batu Hijau is largely from groundwater aquifers in two watersheds. Subsection 5.3 presents available data on water supply and consumption at Batu Hijau and Elang Blocks. These figures indicate water consumption was somewhat greater than 3.5 million cubic meters (m ) in 2017, and continued at comparable rates in the first half of 2018. 3 Numerous Project activities are sources of effluent discharge to surface water and seawater, as summarized in Subsections ...
The Sumbawa airsheds are generally pristine, though in the long dry season dust problems can arise, with occasional issues of smoke and haze from forest and land fires. As summarized in Subsection 11.3.1, existing sources of air pollutants within the Elang project Area of Influence include dust from open land, emissions from vehicles and heavy equipment, and notably the emissions from the existing power plants owned and operated by AMNT (described in Subsection 4.4). At ...
p. 125 Greenhouse Gases
4 facts â–¼
  • Batu Hijau and Elang mines emit greenhouse gases (GHGs), with carbon dioxide (CO2) being the most significant.
  • The ESIA adopts the WBCSD Greenhouse Gas Protocol's 'Project Accounting and Reporting Standard' for GHG emissions.
  • Scope 1 emissions are direct GHGs from sources within Project boundaries and activities.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Batu Hijau and Elang mines emit greenhouse gases (GHGs), with carbon dioxide (CO2) being the most significant.
  • The ESIA adopts the WBCSD Greenhouse Gas Protocol's 'Project Accounting and Reporting Standard' for GHG emissions.
  • Scope 1 emissions are direct GHGs from sources within Project boundaries and activities.
  • Scope 2 emissions are indirect GHGs from the energy production of electricity, heat, and steam consumed by the facility.
Original Text
Batu Hijau and Elang mines have emitted and will emit greenhouse gases (GHGs), the most significant of these being carbon dioxide, CO2. This ESIA adopts the emissions categories of the international reporting framework of WBCSDDGreenhouse Gas Protocol: 'Project Accounting and Reporting Standard,' to elaborate on Project -related GHGs emissions: â–ª Scope 1 -Direct emissions of GHG from sources in the Project boundaries and from Project activities; â–ª Scope 2 -Indirect emissions ...
p. 127 Coal Combustion for Electricity Generation and GHG
3 facts â–¼
  • New mining, ore transportation, and processing facilities for the Elang Project will increase electric power demand from 112 MW to approximately 365 M...
  • Existing coal combustion electric power is provided by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators, totaling 112 MW capacity.
  • The proposed new coal-fired power plant (CFPP) will consist of at least three 100 MW units, interconnected with existing generators.
  • New mining, ore transportation, and processing facilities for the Elang Project will increase electric power demand from 112 MW to approximately 365 MW by 2025.
  • Existing coal combustion electric power is provided by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators, totaling 112 MW capacity.
  • The proposed new coal-fired power plant (CFPP) will consist of at least three 100 MW units, interconnected with existing generators.

The existing coal combustion electric power is provided by four 28 MW coal-fired steam generators with a total capacity of 112 MW. 6 facts â–¼
  • AMNT operates nine 5 MW diesel generators at the Batu Hijau Mine, with a combined capacity of 45 MW.
  • No new diesel generators are planned for the Elang Mine, as expanded coal-fired capacity will be sufficient.

  • + 3 more facts...
  • AMNT operates nine 5 MW diesel generators at the Batu Hijau Mine, with a combined capacity of 45 MW.
  • No new diesel generators are planned for the Elang Mine, as expanded coal-fired capacity will be sufficient.
  • Annual generation from diesel-fired power plants at Batu Hijau Mine was 34,237 MWh in 2017.
  • Diesel fuel consumption and corresponding GHG emissions for heavy equipment at Batu Hijau mine are presented in Table 5-4.
  • Diesel fuel consumption for heavy equipment at Elang Mine is assumed to be similar to Batu Hijau for comparable open pit mining operations.
  • Diesel fuel consumption for heavy equipment is recognized to increase significantly over the life of the Elang mine as the pit deepens.
Original Text
AMNT operates 9 x 5 MW diesel generators at the Batu Hijau Mine, with a combined capacity of 45 MW. New diesel generators are not planned for the Elang Mine, as the expanded coalfired capacity will be adequate and may even replace existing diesel fired generators. p. 130 Fugitive GHG Emissions from Refrigerant Usage
4 facts â–¼
  • Refrigerants have very high Global Warming Potential (GWP) compared to carbon dioxide.
  • Batu Hijau 4 project used 1305.6 kg/yr of refrigerant across 96 units in 2017-2018.
  • Scope 3 emissions include indirect emissions from third-party operations, such as the AMIN Copper Smelter.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Refrigerants have very high Global Warming Potential (GWP) compared to carbon dioxide.
  • Batu Hijau 4 project used 1305.6 kg/yr of refrigerant across 96 units in 2017-2018.
  • Scope 3 emissions include indirect emissions from third-party operations, such as the AMIN Copper Smelter.
  • The AMIN Copper Smelter is a key associated facility in planning for the Elang project.
Original Text
Refrigerants, though used in fairly small quantities, have very high Global Warming Potential (GWP) as compared to carbon dioxide. Each cylinder consumed to refill refrigerant gases is assumed to be replacing the same amount of fugitive emissions from that equipment. Available recent data and estimat1ed emissions are tabulated in Table 5-8. Table 5-8 Refrigerant Usage and Emissions by AMNT, 2017-2018 Batu Hijau 4, Year = . Batu Hijau 4, Refrigerant Type = Total. The Scope 3 reporting category includes all other indirect emissions that are a consequence of an organization's activities but are not from sources owned, or directly controlled, by the organization (i.e., produced by third-party operations outside or within the Project Area). Scope 3 emissions considered for purposes of this preliminary inventory is a key associated facility that are in planning, the AMIN Copper Smelter. p. 133 Particulate Emissions and Mining (Dust)
3 facts â–¼
  • Dust emissions will occur throughout the mine cycle, including exploration, development, construction, and operation.
  • Main sources of fugitive dust from mining activity include blasting, exposed surfaces (stockpiles, waste dumps, haul roads), and infrastructure.
  • Particulate emissions will be generated by site preparation, earthworks, exploration, and construction of main mining and supporting facilities.
  • Dust emissions will occur throughout the mine cycle, including exploration, development, construction, and operation.
  • Main sources of fugitive dust from mining activity include blasting, exposed surfaces (stockpiles, waste dumps, haul roads), and infrastructure.
  • Particulate emissions will be generated by site preparation, earthworks, exploration, and construction of main mining and supporting facilities.
Original Text
Dust emissions will occur through the mine cycle, for instance, exploration, development, construction, and mine operation. A main pollutant from the mining activity is fugitive dust from blasting and exposed surfaces (e.g., stockpiles, waste dumps, haul roads and infrastructure). More specifically particulate emissions will be generated by (Subsection 10.1.1): â–ª Site preparation â–ª Earthworks â–ª Exploration â–ª Construction of main mining facilities e.g., ore mining, ore processing...
p. 134 Coal Combustion for Electricity Generation
5 facts â–¼
  • Continuous Emissions Monitoring (CEM) automatically records SO2, NOx, and particulate emissions at the existing coal-fired power plant at Benete Bay.
  • The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted an average of 952 tons of SO2 annually.
  • The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted an average of 1,800 tons of NOx annually.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Continuous Emissions Monitoring (CEM) automatically records SO2, NOx, and particulate emissions at the existing coal-fired power plant at Benete Bay.
  • The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted an average of 952 tons of SO2 annually.
  • The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted an average of 1,800 tons of NOx annually.
  • The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted an average of 227 tons of particulates annually.
  • These emission values from the existing plant will be used to estimate annual gaseous and particulate emissions from the proposed 2 x 150 MW coal-fired power plant.
Original Text
Continuous Emissions Monitoring (CEM) automatically records the emissions of SO2, NOx and particulates at the existing coal-fired power plant at Benete Bay. The resulting data is then regularly updated in AMNT's environmental monitoring reports for the Batu Hijau mine . The existing 4 x 28 MW coal-fired power plant emitted, on average, 952 ton of SO2, 1,800 ton of NOx and 227 ton of particulate every year. These values could reasonably be used as a reference to estimate the annual gaseous and pa...

4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project operates the Batu Hijau mine and is in the exploration phase for the Elang block.

  • Water for mining activities can be of lower quality if there are no contamination risks.

  • Water consumption is primarily for washing heavy equipment, road spraying for dust suppression, and domestic uses at camps and offices.
  • Water for mining activities can be of lower quality if there are no contamination risks.
  • High quality potable water is required for domestic purposes.

At this point in time, the Elang project operates Batu Hijau mine to produce copper and gold and is in the midst of the Exploration phase for Elang block. Water consumption in these two blocks are mainly for washing heavy equipment at the workshops, road spraying to suppress dust and domestic uses at camps and offices. p. 139 Current Water Conservation Programs
10 facts â–¼
  • AMNT has implemented water conservation programs and annually allocates a budget for them.
  • Water from the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is reused for boiler makeup, watering golf courses, irrigation, road spraying, washing heavy equipmen...
  • The Elang project considers comprehensive strategies and adopts measures to avoid or mitigate negative environmental impacts.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • AMNT has implemented water conservation programs and annually allocates a budget for them.
  • Water from the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is reused for boiler makeup, watering golf courses, irrigation, road spraying, washing heavy equipment, and as process water.
  • The Elang project considers comprehensive strategies and adopts measures to avoid or mitigate negative environmental impacts.
  • The project will avoid releasing pollutants to environmental media or mitigate/control their intensity when avoidance is not feasible.
  • Pollution releases to air, water, and land from routine, non-routine, and accidental circumstances will be managed.
  • Existing soil or groundwater contamination will be addressed according to National law or international best practices.
  • The Elang Project will inevitably affect both surface and groundwater quality.
  • Notable impacts on water quality are expected from land clearing, mining of ore and waste rock disposal, and various supporting facilities.
  • Increased run-off water volumes in disturbed areas will increase erosion and silt/sediment content in streams.
  • Increased turbidity and concentrations of suspended and dissolved solids can cause river water quality to deteriorate.
Original Text
AMNT has implemented a number of water conservation programs. Water pollution prevention and control programs, described below, are in many instances closely associated with water conservation, as water quality of specific water streams is suitable for some uses. AMNT annually allocates budget for water conservation programs that include: â–ª Reuse of water from the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) for boiler makeup; â–ª Reuse of water from the WWTP for watering golf course, irrigation,...
To address potential adverse impacts on existing ambient conditions, the Elang project considers comprehensive strategies and adopts measures to avoid or mitigate negative environmental impacts.
As much as practicable, the Elang project will avoid the release of pollutants to environmental media or, when avoidance is not feasible, mitigate and/or control the intensity of mass flow of the release. This applies to the release of pollutants to air, water, and land due to routine, non-routine, and accidental circumstances with potential for local, regional, and transboundary impacts. Where pollution such as soil or groundwater contamination exist, these issues will be responded to in ...
As described in Subsection 10.5, the Elang Project will inevitably affect both surface and ground water quality, with notable impacts from: â–ª Land clearing for construction of mining and supporting facilities, â–ª Mining of ore and waste rock disposal, â–ª Various supporting facilities Increased run-off water volumes in disturbed areas will increase erosion and increase the silt/sediment content of streams. Increased turbidity and concentrations of suspended as well as dissolved solid...
p. 140 Waste Management
6 facts â–¼
  • The greatest volumes of waste are waste rock from open pit mining and mill tailings.
  • A wide variety of other non-hazardous and hazardous wastes are produced in large mining operations.
  • Open pit mines, like the Elang Project, typically produce larger quantities of waste rock than underground mines of similar production.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • The greatest volumes of waste are waste rock from open pit mining and mill tailings.
  • A wide variety of other non-hazardous and hazardous wastes are produced in large mining operations.
  • Open pit mines, like the Elang Project, typically produce larger quantities of waste rock than underground mines of similar production.
  • Potential impacts from waste rock disposal include loss of land, potential for erosion, and acid mine drainage.
  • Acid mine drainage poses the highest risk of environmental damage among waste rock disposal impacts.
  • In the Batu Hijau mine, waste rock is dumped at Tongoloka, Kan.
Original Text
As noted above, the greatest volumes of waste are the waste rock from open pit mining. Disposal of mill tailings also involves very large volumes. A wide variety of other nonhazardous and hazardous wastes are produced in a large mining operation. Subsections 3.5, 4.9, and 5.5 in this Chapter provide information on this.
As mentioned in Subsection 5.11 Ore Resources, the mine design and ore cut-off grade determine the amount of waste rock produced during mining. Typically, an open pit mine -like the Elang Project -produces larger quantities than an underground mine of similar production. There are several potential impacts posed by waste rock disposal: i) loss of land; ii) potential for erosion, and; iii) acid mine drainage. Among these impacts, acid mine drainage poses the highest risk o...
p. 141 Tailings Disposal
4 facts â–¼
  • Tailings waste from ore processing at Batu Hijau is classified as hazardous and toxic (B3) waste in Indonesia, specifically waste code B416 and hazard...
  • Deep Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) is utilized at Batu Hijau for high-volume tailings disposal.
  • The DSTP system involves a 3.2 km seabed pipeline discharging into a submarine canyon at approximately 130 meters depth.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Tailings waste from ore processing at Batu Hijau is classified as hazardous and toxic (B3) waste in Indonesia, specifically waste code B416 and hazard category 2.
  • Deep Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) is utilized at Batu Hijau for high-volume tailings disposal.
  • The DSTP system involves a 3.2 km seabed pipeline discharging into a submarine canyon at approximately 130 meters depth.
  • The DSTP system was integral to the original mine development and essential for operational feasibility.
Original Text
The tailings waste stream from ore processing at Batu Hijau is categorized as a hazardous and toxic (B3) waste in Indonesia. Specifically, it is B3 waste from a specific source with waste code B416 and hazard category 2. Deep Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) is used at Batu Hijau to safely and economically handle the high volumes of tailings. This involves a 3.2 km seabed pipeline discharging into a submarine canyon at a depth of around 130 meters. The DSTP system was a major feature of the origina...
p. 142 Hazardous Waste Management
3 facts â–¼
  • Key hazardous materials management efforts at AMNT focus on hazardous and toxic wastes (B3 wastes) as defined in Indonesian Government Regulation No 1...
  • Hazardous waste is defined as any waste that could directly or indirectly contaminate environmental media, posing ecological and/or health risks.
  • The Elang project prioritizes avoidance of hazardous waste and mitigates impacts when avoidance is not possible.
  • Key hazardous materials management efforts at AMNT focus on hazardous and toxic wastes (B3 wastes) as defined in Indonesian Government Regulation No 101 of 2014.
  • Hazardous waste is defined as any waste that could directly or indirectly contaminate environmental media, posing ecological and/or health risks.
  • The Elang project prioritizes avoidance of hazardous waste and mitigates impacts when avoidance is not possible.
Original Text
While certain small volumes of fuels, corrosive and toxic industrial chemicals are handled by the AMNT operation, the key hazardous materials management efforts are concerned with hazardous and toxic wastes (abbreviated B3 wastes in Indonesian). Under Government Regulation No 101 of 2014 on Management of Hazardous Waste, hazardous waste is any type of waste that could directly or indirectly contaminate environmental media, and thus poses ecological risks and/or health risks to humans a...
p. 144 Hazardous Waste Management
5 facts â–¼

  • No medical waste was sent to third parties in either 2017 or 2018.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • In 2017, 46.2 tonnes of grease, 0.23 tonnes of incinerator ash, 39.3 tonnes of fire assay waste, 32.0 tonnes of battery acid, 15.5 tonnes of paint waste, 37.4 tonnes of used coolant, and expired chemicals were sent to third parties.
  • In 2018, 52.1 tonnes of grease, 0.1 tonnes of incinerator ash, 26.0 tonnes of fire assay waste, 23.3 tonnes of battery acid, 12.6 tonnes of paint waste, and 41.6 tonnes of used coolant were sent to third parties.
  • No medical waste was sent to third parties in either 2017 or 2018.
  • AMNT produced 8,154 tonnes of non-hazardous waste in 2018, a reduction from 11,293 tonnes in 2017.
  • In 2018, 98.3 tonnes of non-hazardous wastes were beneficially re-used within AMNT operations.
Original Text

Nonhazardous waste from any mining project will be generated by employees' daily activities, and include putrescible ('organic') food waste and scrap plastic and cardboard and paper packaging, with similar paper and plastic waste from offices. Mining projects also generate industrial wastes such as scrap wood, metals, and plastics (such as scrap from HDPE pipes). p. 146 Pesticide Use and Management
2 facts â–¼
  • Pesticides are substances designed to kill, repel, or mitigate pests, including insecticides, rodenticides, fungicides, herbicides, and antimicrobials...
  • Pesticides can cause a wide range of health problems if not used in accordance with good practices.
  • Pesticides are substances designed to kill, repel, or mitigate pests, including insecticides, rodenticides, fungicides, herbicides, and antimicrobials.
  • Pesticides can cause a wide range of health problems if not used in accordance with good practices.
Original Text
Pesticides are substances designed to kill, repel, or mitigate pests. They include a number of chemical and biological agents to control a broad range of pests: insecticides (for insects, including cockroaches, ants, and termites), rodenticides (for mice and rats), fungicides (for mould and fungi), herbicides (for weeds and undesirable plants), and antimicrobials (for bacteria and viruses). Besides the positive effects of pesticide use, some negative impacts also occur when pesticide ...

  • Indonesian labor regulations are comprehensive and conform to International Labour Organization (ILO) conventions and recommendations.
  • AMNT has developed Human Resources Policies and procedures in accordance with national labor regulations, detailed in a formal Company Handbook.
  • The Company Handbook, approved by management and the Government of Indonesia, details Working Conditions and Terms of Employment and is communicated to employees.
  • Indonesia has ratified ILO Convention 87 on Freedom of Association.

p. 150 Human Resource Policies and Procedures
8 facts â–¼
  • PT AMNT's human resource policies and procedures are consistent with Indonesian Law No 13 of 2003 on Labor and IFC Performance Standard 2.
  • Company policies cover worker rights including hours of work, wages, overtime, compensation, and benefits.
  • AMNT respects workers who are parties to a collective bargaining agreement.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • PT AMNT's human resource policies and procedures are consistent with Indonesian Law No 13 of 2003 on Labor and IFC Performance Standard 2.
  • Company policies cover worker rights including hours of work, wages, overtime, compensation, and benefits.
  • AMNT respects workers who are parties to a collective bargaining agreement.
  • Migrant and non-migrant workers carrying out similar work are treated with equivalent terms and conditions.
  • AMNT maintains policies on the quality and management of accommodation and provision of basic services consistent with Performance Standards for required accommodation services.
  • Accommodation services are provided consistent with principles of non-discrimination and equal opportunity.
  • Workers are free to meet and discuss workplace issues on premise during scheduled breaks and before and after work.
  • Workers are allowed to choose representatives to speak with management and inspect working conditions.
Original Text
As a mature global company operating in Indonesia since 2000, PT AMNT has robust human resource policies and procedures that are consistent with national law (i.e., Indonesian Law No 13 of 2003 on Labor) and international standards (i.e., IFC Performance Standard 2). Company policies and procedures are clear and understandable and comprehensively cover worker rights under national labor and employment law and applicable collective agreements, including rights related to hours of work, wages, ove...
AMNT respects those workers who are parties to a collective bargaining agreement. AMNT treats migrant and non-migrant workers carrying out similar work with equivalent terms and conditions. Where accommodation services are required (as in this Project), AMNT maintains policies on the quality and management of accommodation and provision of basic services consistent with the Performance Standards. In addition, services are provided in a manner consistent with the principles of non-discrimination ...
Worker's organization is representative of the work force and act pursuant to the principles of fair representation of workers. Workers are free to meet and discuss workplace issues on the premise during schedule breaks and before and after work. p. 151 Non-discrimination and Equal Opportunity
11 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project makes employment decisions based on job requirements, not personal characteristics.
  • The Elang project's employee relationship is based on equal opportunity and fair treatment, prohibiting discrimination in employment.
  • Discrimination is prohibited in recruitment, hiring, compensation, working conditions, training access, job assignment, promotion, termination, retire...
  • + 8 more facts...
  • The Elang project makes employment decisions based on job requirements, not personal characteristics.
  • The Elang project's employee relationship is based on equal opportunity and fair treatment, prohibiting discrimination in employment.
  • Discrimination is prohibited in recruitment, hiring, compensation, working conditions, training access, job assignment, promotion, termination, retirement, and disciplinary practices.
  • Prior to collective dismissals, the Elang project analyzes alternatives to retrenchment.
  • If no viable alternatives to retrenchment are identified, a retrenchment plan will be developed to reduce adverse impacts on workers.
  • Retrenchment plans are based on non-discrimination and reflect consultation with workers, their organizations, and the government.
  • The Elang project complies with legal and contractual requirements regarding retrenchment.
  • A grievance mechanism is provided for workers and their organizations to raise workplace concerns.
  • Workers are made aware of the grievance mechanism at recruitment and throughout employment.
  • The grievance mechanism is easily accessible, involves management, addresses concerns promptly, and provides timely feedback.
  • The mechanism allows for anonymous complaints and does not impede access to other judicial or administrative remedies.
Original Text
The Elang project does not make employment decisions on the basis of personal characteristics unrelated to job requirements. The Elang project-employee relationship is based on the principle of equal opportunity and fair treatment and does not discriminate in the employment relationship, such as recruitment and hiring, compensation (including wages and benefits), working conditions and terms of employment, access to training, job assignment, promotion, termination o...
Prior to implementing any collective dismissals, the Elang project carries out an analysis of alternatives to retrenchment. If the analysis does not identify viable alternatives to retrenchment, a retrenchment plan will be developed and implemented to reduce the adverse impacts of retrenchment on workers. Retrenchment plans are based on the principle of non-discrimination and reflect consultation with workers, their organizations, and the government, and comply wi...
The Elang project provides a grievance mechanism for workers (and their organizations) to raise workplace concerns. The Elang project makes workers aware of the grievance mechanism at the time of recruitment and throughout employment, making it easily accessible. The mechanism involves management and addresses concerns promptly, using an understandable and transparent process that provides timely feedback to those concerned, without any retribution. The mechanism also allows...

  • The Elang project will identify the presence of all persons under the age of 18.
  • Where employment of minors is allowed under Indonesian law, the Elang project will follow applicable laws.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • The Elang project does not employ children in any manner that is economically exploitative, hazardous, interferes with education, or harms their development.
  • The Elang project will identify the presence of all persons under the age of 18.
  • Where employment of minors is allowed under Indonesian law, the Elang project will follow applicable laws.
  • Children under the age of 18 will not be employed in hazardous work.
  • All work of persons under 18 is subject to specific conditions.
  • The Elang project does not employ forced labor of any kind, including involuntary or compulsory labor.
  • The Elang project does not employ trafficked persons.
  • AMNT is committed to providing a safe and healthy work environment, considering inherent risks including physical, chemical, biological, and radiological hazards.
  • The Elang project takes steps to prevent accidents, injury, and disease by minimizing causes of hazards.
  • PT AMNT maintains comprehensive occupational health programs to assess and control exposure to occupational health hazards.

The Elang project does not, and will not employ forced labor of any kind under any circumstances, including any kind of involuntary or compulsory labor (e.g., indentured labor, bonded labor, or similar labor-contracting arrangements). The Elang project does not, and will not employ trafficked persons.

  • Third parties are required to have appropriate Environmental and Social Management Systems (ESMS) consistent with IFC Performance Standard 2.
  • The Elang Project has established policies and procedures for managing and monitoring the performance of third-party employers related to Performance Standard 2.
  • The Elang Project will review its supply chain for potential adverse impacts and identify risks as part of the assessment process.
  • The assessment will address labor issues, particularly child labor and forced labor, as specified in Performance Standard 2.
  • AMNT has contractor management procedures and mitigation measures to ensure suppliers address high-risk safety issues.
