p. 156 Primary Data Collection and Climate
11 facts â–¼
  • Project-specific primary data were collected by Greencorp in July 2019 within and around the Elang project area.
  • Data collection addressed physical-chemical components including air quality, noise, vibration, groundwater quality, and surface water quality.
  • Terrestrial and riverine biodiversity components were assessed, detailed in Appendix 7 Critical Habitat Report.
  • + 8 more facts...
  • Project-specific primary data were collected by Greencorp in July 2019 within and around the Elang project area.
  • Data collection addressed physical-chemical components including air quality, noise, vibration, groundwater quality, and surface water quality.
  • Terrestrial and riverine biodiversity components were assessed, detailed in Appendix 7 Critical Habitat Report.
  • Social, economic, cultural, and public health components were covered by a socio-economic census (Appendix 4).
  • A community survey involved questionnaire-interviews and in-depth interviews.
  • Eastern Indonesia, including Sumbawa Island, experiences two distinct seasons: a dry season (April-October) and a wet season (November-March).
  • Over 85% of average rainfall occurs during the wet season, also known as the west monsoon.
  • AMNT monitors meteorological conditions (wind speed, direction, humidity, temperature, pressure) at weather stations WS-1B and WS-2A.
  • Average monthly temperature at WS-1B ranged between 20-23 degrees Celsius.
  • Average monthly temperature at WS-2A station was higher, ranging from 26-28 degrees Celsius.
  • Average monthly temperatures peaked in May and December at both WS-1B and WS-2A stations.
Original Text
Project-specific primary data were collected by Greencorp in July 2019 within and around the Elang project area and addressed the following components: 1. Physical-chemical components (Appendix 5 Technical Memorandum of Field Survey); â–ª Air quality; â–ª Noise and Vibration; â–ª Groundwater quality; â–ª Surface water quality. 2. Terrestrial and riverine biodiversity components (Appendix 7 Critical Habitat Report); 3. Social, economic, cultural and public health components (Appendix 4 Socio-econo...
The climate of eastern Indonesia, including Sumbawa Island, can generally be categorized into two distinct seasons, due to the influence of monsoon and trade winds. Dry south-easterly trade winds from April to October result in the dry season. The wet season, from November to March, is due to north-westerly winds originating from mainland Asia and Indo-west Pacific Ocean carrying air masses (McGregor et al., 2016). Over 85% of average rainfall occurs during the wet season, also referred to as th...
AMNT monitors meteorological conditions (wind speed, wind direction, relative humidity, temperature, and pressure) at weather stations WS-1B and WS-2A (Figure 7-1). Figure 7-2 shows that average monthly temperature at WS-1B ranged between 20-23 degrees Celsius ( o C). At WS-2A station, average monthly temperature was higher at 26-28 C. At both stations, o the average monthly temperature peaked in May and December. Figure 7-1 Weather Station Locations for Monitoring Meteorological Conditions in ...
p. 158 Humidity Monitoring
3 facts â–¼
  • AMNT monitored relative humidity (RH) at Batu Hijau and Elang project area weather stations.
  • WS-1B station experienced higher monthly relative humidity than WS-2A station, attributed to cooler air at its higher altitude.
  • Average relative humidity at WS-E1 in the Elang project area was high, ranging from 85% to 95%.
  • AMNT monitored relative humidity (RH) at Batu Hijau and Elang project area weather stations.
  • WS-1B station experienced higher monthly relative humidity than WS-2A station, attributed to cooler air at its higher altitude.
  • Average relative humidity at WS-E1 in the Elang project area was high, ranging from 85% to 95%.
Original Text
AMNT also monitored relative humidity (RH) at the Batu Hijau and Elang project area weather station (Figure 7-5) over the same time period as temperature. On average, the WS-1B station experienced higher monthly relative humidity than the WS-2A station. Higher relative humidity was attributed to cooler air at WS-1B, which is located at a higher altitude. Similar to WS-1B, average relative humidity at WS-E1 in Elang project area tended to be high, ranging from 85% to 95%. (a) WS-1B (b) ...
p. 159 Rainfall Monitoring
4 facts â–¼
  • AMNT has collected rainfall data in the Batu Hijau mine area since 1994.
  • Rainfall data are used to calculate the frequency and intensity of heavy storms and floods for determining storage capacity.
  • AMNT operates 14 automatic rain gauges in and around the Batu Hijau mine operation areas.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • AMNT has collected rainfall data in the Batu Hijau mine area since 1994.
  • Rainfall data are used to calculate the frequency and intensity of heavy storms and floods for determining storage capacity.
  • AMNT operates 14 automatic rain gauges in and around the Batu Hijau mine operation areas.
  • Three monitoring stations are located at different elevations: RF2A (Brang Tartalorka) at 120 m above mean sea level (msl), RF4 (Brang Rengit) at 325 m, and RFEV3 (Concentrator).
Original Text
AMNT has been collecting rainfall data in the Batu Hijau mine area since 1994, for the purpose of calculating the frequency and intensity of heavy storms and floods. These data are important to determine the building storage capacity against possible floods. AMNT operates 14 automatic rain gauges in and around the Batu Hijau mine operation areas. Figure 7-6 shows 3 of these monitoring stations, each located at a different elevation: RF2A (Brang Tartalorka) is located at 120 meter (...
p. 161 Air Quality Monitoring
5 facts â–¼
  • AMNT monitors ambient air quality once a year, as required by their RKL-RPL (Environmental Monitoring and Management) document.
  • Three air quality monitoring stations are located in the nearby villages of Sekongkang and Serojong, and at the Benete Port Facility.
  • Parameters sampled include sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), and total suspended particulates (TSP).
  • + 2 more facts...
  • AMNT monitors ambient air quality once a year, as required by their RKL-RPL (Environmental Monitoring and Management) document.
  • Three air quality monitoring stations are located in the nearby villages of Sekongkang and Serojong, and at the Benete Port Facility.
  • Parameters sampled include sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), and total suspended particulates (TSP).
  • All parameters are measured and averaged over a 1-hour period, except for TSP which is averaged over a 24-hour period.
  • Monitoring results are compared against Indonesian national standards.
Original Text
AMNT monitors ambient air quality once a year, consistent with the requirements of their RKL-RPL (Environmental Monitoring and Management) document. Three of the monitoring stations are within the nearby villages of Sekongkang and Serojong, as well as the Benete Port Facility, as shown in Figure 7-10. The parameters sampled are sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), and total suspended particulates (TSP). All parameters are measured and averaged over a 1-hour period,...

  • One TSP (24-hr) reading was 30,000 ug/Nm3.
  • Another TSP (24-hr) reading was 230 ug/Nm3.

  • Several TSP (24-hr) readings were below 1,000 ug/Nm3, specifically 48, 85, 13, 56, and 70 ug/Nm3.
  • Monitoring station AMSEJ (Sejorong) recorded a TSP (24-hr) value of 30,000 ug/Nm3.

p. 165 Wind Baseline
5 facts â–¼
  • Wind speed was monitored at two stations, WS-1B and WS-2A, at the Batu Hijau Project area from 2013-2018.
  • Average monthly wind speeds peaked in September.
  • At WS-1B, wind speeds ranged from 1.2 m/s to 3.7 m/s.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Wind speed was monitored at two stations, WS-1B and WS-2A, at the Batu Hijau Project area from 2013-2018.
  • Average monthly wind speeds peaked in September.
  • At WS-1B, wind speeds ranged from 1.2 m/s to 3.7 m/s.
  • At WS-2A, wind speeds ranged from 0.5 m/s to 3.0 m/s.
  • The dominant wind direction at both locations was from the southeast.
Original Text
Wind speed was monitored at two monitoring stations at Batu Hijau Project area from 20132018: WS-1B and WS-2A (see Figure 7-1 for monitoring locations, and Figure 7-13 for wind monitoring results). Average monthly wind speeds tended to cycle regularly, with peaks occurring in September. At WS-1B, wind speeds ranged from a high of 3.7 m/s to a low of 1.2 m/s. At WS-2A, wind speed ranged from a high of 3.0 m/s to a low of 0.5 m/s. In both locations, the dominant win...
p. 166 Geomorphology and Topography
4 facts â–¼
  • The proposed Elang mine site is located in steep terrain dominated by dense forests.
  • Elevation at the Elang mine site ranges from approximately 400-600 m.
  • Areas north of the mine site reach elevations up to 1000 m.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The proposed Elang mine site is located in steep terrain dominated by dense forests.
  • Elevation at the Elang mine site ranges from approximately 400-600 m.
  • Areas north of the mine site reach elevations up to 1000 m.
  • The Overland Conveyor (OLC) will pass through mountainous areas and low-elevation areas (<200 m) where local villages are located.
Original Text
The proposed Elang mine site is located in steep terrain dominated by dense forests (Figure 7-14). There are several tributary streams passing through the mine site, flowing from the adjacent to the eastern perimeter of the mine site. Elevation in the Elang block ranges from approximately 400-600 m at the Elang mine site, up to 1000 m in the areas north of the mine site. p. 167 Geology and Seismicity
8 facts â–¼
  • The main geologic units in Batu Hijau are tertiary andesitic metavolcanics, including ash, lapilli tuff, and breccias.
  • Small areas of sedimentary limestone are present north of Batu Hijau in the Brang Jereweh catchment.
  • The southern part of Sumbawa Island, where Batu Hijau is located, is bounded by a flat to gently sloping coastal fringe.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • The main geologic units in Batu Hijau are tertiary andesitic metavolcanics, including ash, lapilli tuff, and breccias.
  • Small areas of sedimentary limestone are present north of Batu Hijau in the Brang Jereweh catchment.
  • The southern part of Sumbawa Island, where Batu Hijau is located, is bounded by a flat to gently sloping coastal fringe.
  • The terrace near the Batu Hijau mine was formed by uplifted coral reefs, a process continuing at several millimeters per year.
  • Indonesia is within the 'Ring of Fire', known for volcanic eruptions and earthquakes.
  • Sumbawa island has several inactive volcanoes and one active volcano, Mount Tambora.
  • Mount Tambora erupted in 1815, causing an estimated death toll of 70,000.
  • Sangeang Api, another active volcano, is approximately 7 km northeast of the island.
Original Text
The main geologic units in Batu Hijau are tertiary andesitic metavolcanics, including ash, lapilli tuff, and breccias. Small areas of sedimentary limestone are also present in the north of Batu Hijau, in the Brang Jereweh catchment. Based on the 1996 AMDAL performed by NNT, the southern part of Sumbawa Island, where Batu Hijau is located, is bounded by a flat to gently sloping coastal fringe. Particularly close to the Batu Hijau mine, the terrace was formed by uplifted coral reefs, a process...
Indonesia lies within the 'Ring of Fire', an area known for volcanic eruptions and earthquakes due to frequent collisions between tectonic plates, particularly subduction. On Sumbawa island, there are several inactive volcanoes and one active volcano, known as Mount Tambora. Mt. Tambora erupted in 1815, causing volcanic ash rains as far away as Borneo and an estimated death toll of 70,000. Approximately 7 kms northeast of the Island, there is another active volcano cal...
p. 168 Earthquake Hazard
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project area is located in Zone 5, with a peak ground acceleration (PGA) of 0.25 g - 0.30 g.
  • This PGA is based on an eruption probability of 10% within 50 years.
  • Peak ground acceleration (PGA) is the maximum absolute acceleration at a site during a seismicity event.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang project area is located in Zone 5, with a peak ground acceleration (PGA) of 0.25 g - 0.30 g.
  • This PGA is based on an eruption probability of 10% within 50 years.
  • Peak ground acceleration (PGA) is the maximum absolute acceleration at a site during a seismicity event.
  • PGA is compared to the Modified Mercalli (MM) Intensity Scale.
Original Text
Consistent with the Earthquake Hazard in Indonesia Book (Geotek LIPI or the Center of Geotechnical Research Indonesia, 2017), the Elang project area is located in Zone 5 (peak ground acceleration of 0.25 g -0.30 g), assuming an eruption probability of 10% within 50 years. Peak ground acceleration (PGA) is defined as the maximum absolute acceleration at a particular site during a seismicity event. The PGA is then compared to the Modified Mercalli (MM) Intensity Scale, which is freque...
p. 169 Lithology
3 facts â–¼
  • A geotechnical study by Golder (2018) at the proposed Elang pit identified a copper-gold deposit within a NE-NNE trending corridor.
  • The Elang site's lithology includes tonalities intruding an older andesitic volcanic sequence and diorite, or diorite intrusion.
  • Dacite and diatremes postdate mineralization and hypogene alteration at the Elang site.
  • A geotechnical study by Golder (2018) at the proposed Elang pit identified a copper-gold deposit within a NE-NNE trending corridor.
  • The Elang site's lithology includes tonalities intruding an older andesitic volcanic sequence and diorite, or diorite intrusion.
  • Dacite and diatremes postdate mineralization and hypogene alteration at the Elang site.
Original Text
Golder (2018) conducted a geotechnical study at the proposed Elang pit. The Elang site consists of a copper-gold deposit within a NE-NNE trending corridor. A number of tonalities intrude an older andesitic volcanic sequence and diorite (Elang domain) or diorite intrusion (Gerbang domain). Dacite and diatremes postdate mineralization and hypogene alteration (Golder 2018). Figure 7-14 provides the stratigraphy of the proposed Elang Mine deposit. Source: Golder 2018(b) Geotechnical Ope...
p. 170 Lithography of the Elang Mine deposit
3 facts â–¼
  • Soil conditions at the proposed Waste Rock Facility (WRF) are generally dominated by clay and silt on bedrock, according to Golder (2018).
  • Two borehole locations at the WRF show the presence of alluvium and colluvium, attributed to landslides.
  • Golder (2018) installed eight boreholes for their geotechnical and hydrogeology study at the WRF between September 20 and October 26, 2018.
  • Soil conditions at the proposed Waste Rock Facility (WRF) are generally dominated by clay and silt on bedrock, according to Golder (2018).
  • Two borehole locations at the WRF show the presence of alluvium and colluvium, attributed to landslides.
  • Golder (2018) installed eight boreholes for their geotechnical and hydrogeology study at the WRF between September 20 and October 26, 2018.
Original Text
Based on the Golder (2018) Geotechnical and Hydrogeology Study for the Waste Rock Facility (WRF), soil conditions at the proposed WRF is generally dominated by clay and silt on bedrock. Two borehole locations, however, show presence of alluvium and colluvium due to landslides. In their survey, Golder (2018) installed eight boreholes from 20 September 2018 to 26 October 2018 (Figure 7-15). Figure 7-15 Locations of Geotechnical Boreholes at the Proposed Waste Rock Facility Site The Waste Rock Faci...
p. 172 Water Catchment Area
3 facts â–¼
  • The proposed Elang pit is located within the Panas Watershed.
  • Five other watersheds (Babar, Lampit, Presa, Mentajo, Sedu) surround the mine, proposed Waste Rock Storage (WRS), and supporting facilities.
  • The Overland Conveyor (OLC) intersects with Panas, Lampit, Babar, Beh, Rinti, and unnamed watersheds around Brang Tongoloka and Brang Sejorong rivers.
  • The proposed Elang pit is located within the Panas Watershed.
  • Five other watersheds (Babar, Lampit, Presa, Mentajo, Sedu) surround the mine, proposed Waste Rock Storage (WRS), and supporting facilities.
  • The Overland Conveyor (OLC) intersects with Panas, Lampit, Babar, Beh, Rinti, and unnamed watersheds around Brang Tongoloka and Brang Sejorong rivers.
Original Text
The proposed Elang pit lies on top one watershed -the Panas Watershed (Table 7-5). There are five other (Babar, Lampit, Presa, Mentajo and Sedu) watershedS surrounding the mine, proposed Waste Rock Storage (WRS) and supporting facilities. The Overland Conveyor (OLC) stretches from the Elang Project area up to the Batu Hijau Project area. The OLC intersects with Panas, Lampit, Babar, Beh, Rinti watersheds, as well as unnamed watersheds around Brang Tongoloka and Brang Sejorong rivers in the Batu ...
p. 173 Water Catchment Sizes in the Elang Project Area
14 facts â–¼
  • The Panas watershed has a size of 17,146 ha.
  • The Beh watershed is the largest listed, with a size of 153,711 ha.
  • The Babar watershed has a size of 5,771 ha.
  • + 11 more facts...
  • The Panas watershed has a size of 17,146 ha.
  • The Beh watershed is the largest listed, with a size of 153,711 ha.
  • The Babar watershed has a size of 5,771 ha.
  • The Lampit watershed has a size of 6,623 ha.
  • The Presa watershed has a size of 2,867 ha.
  • The Mentajo watershed has a size of 1,723 ha.
  • The Sedu watershed has a size of 1,185 ha.
  • The Rinti watershed has a size of 20,147 ha.
  • An unnamed watershed around Brang Tongoloka has a size of 9,374 ha.
  • An unnamed watershed around Brang Sejorong has a size of 9,932 ha.
  • The Batu Hijau project area is transected by four main rivers, with three draining into the Indian Ocean and one into the Alas Strait.
  • The Brang Tatarloka is the largest watershed in the Batu Hijau project area, encompassing 168 kmÂ².
  • AMNT installed eight gauging stations to monitor stream flow and stage elevation in four different watersheds.
  • The section focuses on the Sejorong Watershed (SG-6A, SG-3A, SG-9A) due to its proximity to the mill and DSTP pipeline.
Original Text
Panas, Size (ha) = 17,146. Beh, Size (ha) = 153,711. Babar, Size (ha) = 5,771. Lampit, Size (ha) = 6,623. Presa, Size (ha) = 2,867. Mentajo, Size (ha) = 1,723. Sedu, Size (ha) = 1,185. Rinti, Size (ha) = 20,147. Unnamed watershed around Brang Tongoloka, Size (ha) = 9,374. Unnamed watershed around Brang Sejorong, Size (ha) = 9,932 Source: Ministry of Environment and Forestry of the Republic of Indonesia. Retrieved from: http://appgis.dephut.go.id/appgis/download.aspx
The Batu Hijau project area is transected by four main rivers, three of which drain into the Indian Ocean, and one which drains into the Alas Strait. The largest watershed is the Brang Tatarloka, which encompasses an area of 168 km . AMNT installed eight gauging stations to 2 monitor stream flow and stage elevation in four different watersheds (Figure 7-17). p. 178 Surface Water Quality Monitoring
5 facts â–¼
  • Surface water quality monitoring locations are within the Elang Project site.
  • Primary monitoring data was collected from a field survey in July 2019 at sites SWQ-1 through SWQ-4.
  • Sampling and analysis for primary data adhered to Indonesian National Standards (SNI) and were performed by PT Sky Pacific Indonesia, an accredited la...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Surface water quality monitoring locations are within the Elang Project site.
  • Primary monitoring data was collected from a field survey in July 2019 at sites SWQ-1 through SWQ-4.
  • Sampling and analysis for primary data adhered to Indonesian National Standards (SNI) and were performed by PT Sky Pacific Indonesia, an accredited laboratory.
  • Secondary monitoring data was acquired from the 2018 Elang Environmental Management Document (DPLH).
  • Water quality is measured annually at secondary data sites SWDOD09, SWLIN16, and SWDOD20.
Original Text
Monitoring locations within the Elang Project site are provided in Figure 7-22. Monitoring data from two sets of monitoring points were used: Â· Primary data from a field survey conducted in July 2019 (sites SWQ-1 through SWQ-4). Sampling and analysis methods adhered to Indonesian National Standards (SNI), and were performed by an accredited laboratory (PT Sky Pacific Indonesia), and; Â· Secondary data acquired from the 2018 Elang Environmental Management Document ( Dokumen Pengelolaan Lingkungan ...
p. 180 Surface Water Quality Standards and Data
10 facts â–¼
  • The National Standard 1 for pH is 5.0-9.0.
  • The National Standard 1 for Dissolved Oxygen (DO) is >0 mg/l.
  • The National Standard 1 for Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) is 2,000 mg/l.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • The National Standard 1 for pH is 5.0-9.0.
  • The National Standard 1 for Dissolved Oxygen (DO) is >0 mg/l.
  • The National Standard 1 for Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) is 2,000 mg/l.
  • The National Standard 1 for Total Suspended Solids (TSS) is 400 mg/l.
  • The National Standard 1 for Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) is 12 mg/l.
  • The National Standard 1 for Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) is 10 mg/L.
  • The National Standard 1 for Total Coliform is 10,000.
  • In November 2015, TDS was 349 mg/l, TSS was <2.5 mg/l, BOD was <2 mg/l, COD was <3.3 mg/L, and Total Coliform was >12,098.
  • In May 2016, pH was 8.30, DO was 9 mg/l, TDS was 210 mg/l, TSS was <2.5 mg/l, BOD was <2 mg/l, COD was <3.3 mg/L, and Total Coliform was 8,665.
  • In November 2016, pH was 7.90, DO was 8 mg/l, and Turbidity was 14 NTU.

p. 183 Hydrogeology of Elang Mine Site
4 facts â–¼
  • Groundwater in the proposed Elang Mine site may flow through 'clean and open' joints, breccia zones (intrusive breccia, tonalities, volcanics), major ...
  • Groundwater flow could be blocked by impermeable argillic altered rocks or due to a lack of cross-cutting structures.
  • A hydrogeological model by AMNT (AMC, 2018) presented in the Elang Mine Pre-feasibility Study illustrates a shallow 'active' groundwater system.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Groundwater in the proposed Elang Mine site may flow through 'clean and open' joints, breccia zones (intrusive breccia, tonalities, volcanics), major fault zones (beneath river sections and domain boundaries), and colluvials or alluvials beneath the river system.
  • Groundwater flow could be blocked by impermeable argillic altered rocks or due to a lack of cross-cutting structures.
  • A hydrogeological model by AMNT (AMC, 2018) presented in the Elang Mine Pre-feasibility Study illustrates a shallow 'active' groundwater system.
  • The shallow 'active' groundwater system experiences high rates of rainfall recharge.
Original Text
In the proposed Elang Mine site, groundwater may flow through 'clean and open' joints or breccia zones (such as intrusive breccia, tonalities, and volcanics); major fault zones (beneath river sections and domain boundaries); and colluvials or alluvials beneath the river system. However, groundwater flow could also be blocked by impermeable argillic altered rocks or due to lack of cross-cutting structures. A hydrogeological model by AMNT (AMC, 2018) presented in the Elang Mine Pre-fea...
p. 184 Groundwater Quality
4 facts â–¼
  • During the exploration phase, AMNT used two groundwater wells at the Elang Base Camp for employee drinking, cooking, bathing, and hygienic purposes.
  • Groundwater quality data for the Elang Base Camp and nearby residential areas is based on primary and secondary data.
  • Primary data from a field survey was collected in July 2019 at sites GW-01, 02, 03, and 04.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • During the exploration phase, AMNT used two groundwater wells at the Elang Base Camp for employee drinking, cooking, bathing, and hygienic purposes.
  • Groundwater quality data for the Elang Base Camp and nearby residential areas is based on primary and secondary data.
  • Primary data from a field survey was collected in July 2019 at sites GW-01, 02, 03, and 04.
  • Sampling and analysis methods for primary groundwater data adhered to Indonesian National Standards (SNI).
Original Text
During the exploration phase of the block, AMNT utilized two groundwater wells in the Elang Base Camp to meet employee needs for drinking, cooking, bathing, and hygienic purposes (AMNT, 2019). p. 186 Groundwater Quality Measurements at Elang Base Camp, 2018
9 facts â–¼
  • Groundwater quality measurements at Elang Base Camp in 2018 were compared against Kepmenkes 492/2010 standards.
  • The standard for pH is 6.5-8.5, for TDS is 500 mg/l, and for Turbidity is 5.0 NTU.
  • The standard for Total Iron is 0.30 mg/L, for Copper is 2.00 mg/L, and for Free Chlorine is 5.00 mg/L.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • Groundwater quality measurements at Elang Base Camp in 2018 were compared against Kepmenkes 492/2010 standards.
  • The standard for pH is 6.5-8.5, for TDS is 500 mg/l, and for Turbidity is 5.0 NTU.
  • The standard for Total Iron is 0.30 mg/L, for Copper is 2.00 mg/L, and for Free Chlorine is 5.00 mg/L.
  • Coliform standards require 0 for both 24-hour and 48-hour tests.
  • On March 6, 2018, Copper measured 0.02 mg/L.
  • On July 26, 2018, temperature was 24.1Â°C, pH was 6.7, TDS was 296 mg/l, and Turbidity was 1.3 NTU.
  • On July 26, 2018, Alkalinity was 98.0 mg/l, Hardness was 132 mg/L, and Total Iron was 0.00 mg/L.
  • On July 26, 2018, Copper was 0.03 mg/L, and both 24-hour and 48-hour Coliform tests were negative.
  • On July 30, 2018, temperature was 24.0Â°C, pH was 7.2, and TDS was 240 mg/l.

p. 187 Groundwater Quality Measurements at Elang Base Camp and Vill...
8 facts â–¼
  • Groundwater depth measurements in 2019 ranged from 1m to 2m across GW-1, GW-2, and GW-3.
  • Dissolved Oxygen (DO) levels in 2019 ranged from 2.3 mg/L to 4.9 mg/L across the monitored groundwater wells.
  • Conductivity measurements in 2019 ranged from 52.1 to 106.7 across the monitored groundwater wells.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Groundwater depth measurements in 2019 ranged from 1m to 2m across GW-1, GW-2, and GW-3.
  • Dissolved Oxygen (DO) levels in 2019 ranged from 2.3 mg/L to 4.9 mg/L across the monitored groundwater wells.
  • Conductivity measurements in 2019 ranged from 52.1 to 106.7 across the monitored groundwater wells.
  • AMNT conducts quarterly monitoring of seawater and sediment quality due to its Deep-Sea Tailing Placement (DST) system.
  • Monitoring includes physical, chemical, and dissolved parameters at the outfall and in the mixing zone.
  • Figure 7-25 illustrates 28 stations used by AMNT for monitoring in 2017 and 2018.
  • Seawater quality is sampled at various depths using a Carousel Water Sampler with CTD SBE method/equipment.
  • The 28 monitoring stations are distributed across three defined zones.
Original Text

Figure 7-25 illustrates the 28 stations used by AMNT in its monitoring efforts in 2017 and 2018. p. 192 Conductivity, Temperature, and Depth (CTD) Monitoring
5 facts â–¼
  • AMNT conducts monthly seawater profile monitoring around the DSTP discharge.
  • CTD SBE 911 and CTD320 Idronaut with multiparameter probes are used for monitoring.
  • Monitored parameters include temperature, transmissivity, turbidity, chlorophyll-a concentration, salinity, density, pH, and dissolved oxygen.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • AMNT conducts monthly seawater profile monitoring around the DSTP discharge.
  • CTD SBE 911 and CTD320 Idronaut with multiparameter probes are used for monitoring.
  • Monitored parameters include temperature, transmissivity, turbidity, chlorophyll-a concentration, salinity, density, pH, and dissolved oxygen.
  • Seawater transmissivity is specifically used to track the extent of tailing dispersion.
  • Seawater profiles from 2018 were provided for three stations: S1, SC2, and S48.
Original Text
In addition to monitoring seawater quality, AMNT also monitors monthly seawater profiles around the DSTP discharge (Figure 7-30). AMNT uses a CTD SBE 911 and CTD320 Idronaut with multiparameter probe to determine trends (with depth) of temperature, transmissivity, turbidity, chlorophyll-a concentration, salinity, density, pH, and dissolved oxygen. Transmissivity of seawater is particularly useful for tracking the extent of tailing dispersion. Figure 7-27 provides the seawater profiles i...

2 facts â–¼
  • Oceanography profiles near the DSTP outfall were monitored at stations S01, S48, and SC2.
  • Data for oceanography monitoring was sourced from the AMNT Environmental Monitoring and Management Report, 2018.
  • Oceanography profiles near the DSTP outfall were monitored at stations S01, S48, and SC2.
  • Data for oceanography monitoring was sourced from the AMNT Environmental Monitoring and Management Report, 2018.
Original Text
Station SC2 Source: AMNT Environmental Monitoring and Management Report, 2018 Figure 7-27 Oceanography Profiles Near the DSTP Outfall (Stations S01, S48, SC2)
p. 194 Thermocline Definition and Monitoring
4 facts â–¼
  • Government Regulation No. 12 of 2018 defines thermocline as a water layer with a temperature gradient of at least 0.1 C/m.
  • A high temperature gradient in the thermocline prevents mixing of surface and deep water layers, containing tailing spread.
  • AMNT monitored temperature changes with depth in 2018 at five stations along the southern coast of Sumbawa Island.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Government Regulation No. 12 of 2018 defines thermocline as a water layer with a temperature gradient of at least 0.1 C/m.
  • A high temperature gradient in the thermocline prevents mixing of surface and deep water layers, containing tailing spread.
  • AMNT monitored temperature changes with depth in 2018 at five stations along the southern coast of Sumbawa Island.
  • The monitoring aimed to indicate the extent and depth of the thermocline.
Original Text
Government Regulation No. 12 of 2018 concerning Procedure for Waste Dumping into the Ocean defines thermocline as the line between the upper and lower layers of a water body, where the temperature gradient is at least 0.1 C/m. This high temperature gradient prevents o mixing of surface and deep layers, thus containing tailing spread well below the surface layer. In 2018, AMNT monitored temperature changes with depth, indicating the extent and depth of the thermocline, at five stations along the...
p. 196 Marine Sediment Quality Monitoring
3 facts â–¼
  • AMNT monitors sediment quality to ensure tailings move down the Senunu Canyon and are not deposited on the canyon shelf or onshore.
  • Sediment quality is monitored at 15 stations, grouped into Zone B and Zone C.
  • Zone A is not monitored for sediment quality because it is designated as the mixing zone.
  • AMNT monitors sediment quality to ensure tailings move down the Senunu Canyon and are not deposited on the canyon shelf or onshore.
  • Sediment quality is monitored at 15 stations, grouped into Zone B and Zone C.
  • Zone A is not monitored for sediment quality because it is designated as the mixing zone.
Original Text
AMNT monitors sediment quality to ensure that tailings move down the Senunu Canyon, and tailings are not deposited around the canyon shelf or onshore of the tailings discharge. AMNT monitors the sediment quality at 15 stations (Figure 7-30), grouped into two zones (Zone B and Zone C) as illustrated in Figure 7-24. AMNT does not monitor sediment quality in Zone A because it is the mixing zone. Figure 7-30 Monitoring Locations for Marine Sediment Table 7-14 summarizes the monitoring results. ...

p. 199 Bathymetry and Tailing Deposition Studies
6 facts â–¼
  • Detailed bathymetry near the DSTP outfall is presented in Map 16: Mixing Zone in Appendix 11: Map Book.
  • Canyon and ridge structures perpendicular to the Sumbawa shoreline flow into an interslope basin 3000-3500 m below sea level.
  • The Lombok basin is located 4000-4600 m below sea level.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • Detailed bathymetry near the DSTP outfall is presented in Map 16: Mixing Zone in Appendix 11: Map Book.
  • Canyon and ridge structures perpendicular to the Sumbawa shoreline flow into an interslope basin 3000-3500 m below sea level.
  • The Lombok basin is located 4000-4600 m below sea level.
  • The Indonesian Research Centre for Oceanography (LIPI) conducted four independent studies in 2003, 2009, 2013, and 2018.
  • These LIPI studies aimed to validate the depositional footprint of tailing solids and identify impacts of tailing placement over 18 years of PTNNT operations.
  • LIPI defined tailings in sediment samples for the 'Main area' as having Cu content over 60 mg/kg and tailings thickness greater than 1 cm.
Original Text
A portion of the bathymetry profile south of the southwest coast of Sumbawa Island is illustrated in Figure 7-31. Detailed bathymetry near the DSTP outfall can be seen in Map 16: Mixing Zone in Appendix 11: Map Book, which shows the ocean depth under which the tailing has deposited. Figure 7-35 (from the Deep Sea Study by LIPI [2013]), shows the canyon and ridge structures that occur perpendicular to the Sumbawa shoreline. The canyons and ridges flow into an interslope...
The Indonesian Research Centre for Oceanography Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI) has recently conducted four independent studies (2003, 2009, 2013, and 2018) to validate the depositional footprint of tailing solids in the deep sea and to identify impacts of tailing placement during the first 18 years of PTNNT operations. The LIPI studies adopted the following definition of tailings in sediment samples: Â· Main area: where the sampling station meets all main crite...
p. 200 Main and Traceable Footprint
5 facts â–¼
  • Tailings monitoring at the deaeration box is conducted according to AMNT's Environmental Monitoring Plan (RPL) and Tailing Placement permit.
  • Monitoring is consistent with Decree of the Minister of Environment and Forestry No. SK.382/Menl hk/Setjen/ PLB.3/5/2016 for AMNT's permit renewal for...
  • Parameters measured monthly include pH and dissolved metals.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Tailings monitoring at the deaeration box is conducted according to AMNT's Environmental Monitoring Plan (RPL) and Tailing Placement permit.
  • Monitoring is consistent with Decree of the Minister of Environment and Forestry No. SK.382/Menl hk/Setjen/ PLB.3/5/2016 for AMNT's permit renewal for dumping toxic and hazardous waste into the sea.
  • Parameters measured monthly include pH and dissolved metals.
  • Copper (Cu) and hydrogen sulphide (H2S) are sampled weekly.
  • Laboratory analyses are performed by PT. ALS.

p. 201 Tailings at the Deaeration Box
7 facts â–¼
  • The standard pH for tailings is 7-10.
  • Standard limits for arsenic (As) are 0.1 mg/L, cadmium (Cd) 0.01 mg/L, chromium (Cr) 0.1 mg/L, copper (Cu) 0.5 mg/L, lead (Pb) 0.1 mg/L, mercury (Hg) ...

  • + 4 more facts...
  • The standard pH for tailings is 7-10.
  • Standard limits for arsenic (As) are 0.1 mg/L, cadmium (Cd) 0.01 mg/L, chromium (Cr) 0.1 mg/L, copper (Cu) 0.5 mg/L, lead (Pb) 0.1 mg/L, mercury (Hg) 0.003 mg/L, nickel (Ni) 0.5 mg/L, zinc (Zn) 1 mg/L, and hydrogen sulphide (H2S) 0.1 mg/L.
  • On January 3, 2018, the pH was 9, arsenic was 0.0125 mg/L, cadmium was 0.0003 mg/L, chromium was 0.001 mg/L, copper was 0.002 mg/L, lead was <0.001 mg/L, mercury was <0.00005 mg/L, nickel was <0.001 mg/L, zinc was <0.005 mg/L, and H2S was <0.002 mg/L.
  • On June 6, 2018, nickel was 0.002 mg/L, zinc was <0.005 mg/L, and H2S was <0.002 mg/L.
  • On June 13, 2018, the pH was 9 and copper was 0.005 mg/L.
  • On June 27, 2018, the pH was 9 and copper was 0.013 mg/L.
  • On July 4, 2018, the pH was 9, arsenic was 0.0054 mg/L, cadmium was <0.0001 mg/L, chromium was <0.001 mg/L, and copper was 0.004 mg/L.

p. 203 Terrestrial Eco-region
5 facts â–¼
  • The terrestrial eco-region is part of the Lesser Sundas Deciduous Forests Ecoregion.
  • This region spans from Lombok Island, across Sumbawa Besar Island, to Flores Island in the southern Wallacean Zone.
  • The ecoregion represents semi-evergreen dry forests.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The terrestrial eco-region is part of the Lesser Sundas Deciduous Forests Ecoregion.
  • This region spans from Lombok Island, across Sumbawa Besar Island, to Flores Island in the southern Wallacean Zone.
  • The ecoregion represents semi-evergreen dry forests.
  • Ecosystem types include dry deciduous forest at lower elevations, dry evergreen forest at higher elevations, and montane evergreen forest above 1,000 m ASL.
  • The Wallacean zone is characterized by high flora and fauna biodiversity, influenced by Asian and Australian species.
Original Text
The terrestrial eco-region includes the Lesser Sundas Deciduous Forests Ecoregion (Figure 7-34). This region extends from Lombok Island, across Sumbawa Besar Island to Flores Island in the most southern part of Wallacean Zone, and represents the semi-evergreen dry forests (WWF, 2019). Ecosystem types are dry deciduous forest in the lower-elevation zones, with dry evergreen forest at higher elevations, and montane evergreen forest at elevations above 1,000 m ASL (WWF, 2019). The Wallacean ...
p. 204 Ecosystems and Flora
8 facts â–¼
  • The description of natural ecosystems for the Elang project is based on the Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont, 1996).
  • Natural vegetation is defined by naturally occurring ecosystem characteristics such as structure, species composition, topography, and soil condition.
  • Modified ecosystems refer to areas impacted by agriculture or anthropogenic activity.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • The description of natural ecosystems for the Elang project is based on the Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont, 1996).
  • Natural vegetation is defined by naturally occurring ecosystem characteristics such as structure, species composition, topography, and soil condition.
  • Modified ecosystems refer to areas impacted by agriculture or anthropogenic activity.
  • The coastal ecosystem is a narrow band along the coastline influenced by tides, storm surges, and salt spray.
  • This coastal area receives less than 1000 mm of annual rainfall.
  • Vegetation composition in the coastal ecosystem varies with soil type, ranging from unconsolidated sandy soils to consolidated soil.
  • Habitat types within the coastal ecosystem include shrubby beach communities, coastal heath, grassland, and narrow mangrove ecosystems.
  • Flora species in unconsolidated sandy soils primarily include Spinifex littoralis and Ipomoea pescaprae.
Original Text
The description of natural ecosystems within and around the Elang project is based on the Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont, 1996) and can be seen in Figure 7-35 which displays natural and modified ecosystems. Natural vegetation was defined based on naturally occurring ecosystem characteristics such as structure and species composition, topography, and soil condition, while modified ecosystems refer to agriculture or anthropogenic activity.
The coastal ecosystem represents a narrow band along the coastline including tides, storm surges, and areas of salt spray from the sea. This area receives less than 1000 mm of annual rainfall. The vegetation composition represents the soil type characteristics, which vary between unconsolidated sandy soils and consolidated soil. Habitat types of the coastal ecosystem are shrubby beach communities, coastal heath, grassland, and narrow mangrove ecosystems. Flora species growin...
p. 205 Dry Forest and Moist Evergreen Forest
5 facts â–¼
  • Dry forest, consisting of dry deciduous and mixed Corypha forest, is widespread between sea level and 100 m ASL, particularly in the western part of B...
  • Environmental factors influencing dry forest formation include low precipitation (<1000 mm annual rainfall), low elevation, and specific soil condi...
  • Moist evergreen forest is the dominant forest cover, accounting for 90% of the Elang project area.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Dry forest, consisting of dry deciduous and mixed Corypha forest, is widespread between sea level and 100 m ASL, particularly in the western part of Batu Hijau.
  • Environmental factors influencing dry forest formation include low precipitation (<1000 mm annual rainfall), low elevation, and specific soil conditions.
  • Moist evergreen forest is the dominant forest cover, accounting for 90% of the Elang project area.
  • Moist evergreen forest is characterized by abundant liana and rattans, creating a multi-layer forest structure.
  • Canopy height in moist evergreen forest commonly ranges from 15-20 m on steep hillsides, reaching higher levels on flat slopes.
Original Text
Dry forest consists of two types of ecosystem: dry deciduous forest, and mixed Corypha Forest. Dry forest is widespread between sea level and up to 100 m ASL. It occurs extensively in the western part of Batu Hijau. However, the vegetation zone boundary is unclear in some areas, due to the composition of dry forest vegetation that is associated with moist evergreen forest or riparian forests. Environmental factors that affect dry forest formation are the low precipitation (<1000 ...
Moist evergreen forest is the dominant forest cover (90%) within the Elang project area. It is characterized by an abundance of liana and rattans creating a multi-layer forest structure. Ground cover is diverse as a result of variations in topography such as steep slopes, creeks, rivers, and valleys. Forest structure is characterized by diverse canopy stratification, where a low canopy height of approximately 15 -20 m is common on steep hillsides. The highest levels of forest strati...
p. 206 Riparian, Montane, and Modified Habitats
9 facts â–¼
  • Riparian forest grows in lowland areas up to 150 m ASL, surrounding rivers with alluvial sediment soil.
  • Dominant species in riparian forest include Tetrameles nudiflora, Lagerstromia speciosa, Eugenia subglauca, and Serianthes sp.
  • Montane forest ecosystems are found above 800 m ASL, with pre-montane forest between 800-950 m ASL and montane forest above 950 m ASL.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • Riparian forest grows in lowland areas up to 150 m ASL, surrounding rivers with alluvial sediment soil.
  • Dominant species in riparian forest include Tetrameles nudiflora, Lagerstromia speciosa, Eugenia subglauca, and Serianthes sp.
  • Montane forest ecosystems are found above 800 m ASL, with pre-montane forest between 800-950 m ASL and montane forest above 950 m ASL.
  • Species diversity sharply decreases above 900 m elevation due to thin topsoil and high humidity.
  • Pre-montane forest trees range from 30-40 m in height, while montane forest trees are typically less than 15 m.
  • Forest plantations are categorized as modified habitats, often abandoned dry land agriculture or planted areas requiring no intensive maintenance.
  • Forest plantations typically consist of economically valuable plants like coconut and banana, with other species such as jackfruit, mango, and coffee.
  • Agriculture, including wetland paddy fields and mixed gardens, is categorized as modified habitat and utilized by local communities for daily needs.
  • Vegetation species in agricultural areas include sweet potatoes, chili pepper, soybean, clove, cacao, and various fruit trees.
Original Text
Riparian forest grows on lowland areas up to 150 m ASL surrounding rivers with alluvial sediment soil on the valley floor. Forest structure of riparian forest ecosystems is similar to moist evergreen forests, but displaying sparser canopy cover. Dominant species that were recorded are Tetrameles nudiflora , Lagerstromia speciosa , Eugenia subglauca , and Serianthes sp . Presence of the emergent tree species Tetrameles nudiflora and Serianthes sp distinguishes the riparian fores...
The montane forest ecosystem was recorded on sites above 800 m ASL. Pre-montane forest ecosystem ranges between 800 -950 m ASL, while the montane forest ecosystem is found above approximately 950 m ASL. Species diversity tends to decrease sharply above 900 m elevation due to the thin topsoil substrate and high humidity. Pre-montane forest structure is dominated by trees with heights ranging from 30-40 m. The montane forest ecosystem is dominated by Syzygium sp. and Ardisia javanika with ...
Forest plantations are categorized as modified habitats, and can be abandoned dry land agriculture fields or planted forest area that requires no intensive maintenance. Forest plantations typically consist of economically valuable plants dominated by coconut and banana. Other species that occur in smaller amounts are jackfruit, mango, papaya, candlenut, palms, and coffee. In formerly forested areas, some native flora species were found, such as gaharu, keruing, k...
Agriculture is categorized as modified habitat and includes wetland agriculture (paddy fields) and mixed gardens surrounding settlements. Local communities utilize mixed gardens for their daily needs for plants, vegetables, medical vegetation, fruit, hardwood, and decorative plants. Vegetation species in this class include sweet potatoes, string beans, chili pepper, tomato, spinach, pumpkin, soybean, clove, cacao, coconut, mango, soursop, and limes. Orchids are a common decorative plan...
p. 207 Flora Monitoring in Mine Areas
9 facts â–¼
  • AMNT conducted vegetation monitoring surveys during operations at Batu Hijau, including rehabilitation activities.
  • Twenty-three species were recorded during field surveys, with Pola (Pseuduvaria reticulata) and Majaq (Syzygium longiflorum) dominating tree vegetatio...
  • Pola (P. reticulata) was the most widespread species, followed by Majaq (S. longiflorum).
  • + 6 more facts...
  • AMNT conducted vegetation monitoring surveys during operations at Batu Hijau, including rehabilitation activities.
  • Twenty-three species were recorded during field surveys, with Pola (Pseuduvaria reticulata) and Majaq (Syzygium longiflorum) dominating tree vegetation.
  • Pola (P. reticulata) was the most widespread species, followed by Majaq (S. longiflorum).
  • Fifty-five tree species were recorded in the forest area designated as a waste rock dump expansion plan.
  • Langer, Rapat Bewe, and Majaq were the dominant tree species in the waste rock dump area.
  • Rapat Bewe (Drypetes longifolia) had an INP index of 58.78% at the pole level and 27.69% at the sapling level, and was widespread across all vegetation growth levels.
  • The waste rock dump area reclamation aims to recreate a structurally and biologically varied forest community.
  • The evergreen ecosystem served as a reference for waste rock dump reclamation success, while the deciduous ecosystem was used for other supporting facility area reclamation.
  • Reclamation monitoring in 2012 recorded a total score for all reclamation areas.
Original Text
AMNT conducted vegetation monitoring surveys during operations on Batu Hijau, including rehabilitation activities. Vegetation conditions during mine operations at the Batu Hijau mining area are described in the following sections.
There were 23 species recorded during field surveys. Species such as Pola ( Pseuduvaria reticulata ) and Majaq ( Syzygium longiflorum ) dominated tree vegetation at sample locations. Related species distribution and frequency indicated that Pola ( P. reticulata ) was the most widespread species, followed by Majaq ( S. longiflorum ). Similarly, Dau and Majaq represent a large basal cover as indicated by their dominance in the survey data. Species diversity index is a parameter that can b...
There were 55 species of trees recorded in the forest area designated as a waste rock dump area within the expansion plan. The dominant vegetation species were Langer, Rapat Bewe, and Majaq at the tree level. Rapat Bewe had an INP index of 58.78% and 27.69% at the pole and sapling levels, respectively, while Mentangir species dominated the seedling level. Rapat Bewe ( Drypetes longifolia ) species was widespread in communities for all vegetation growth levels. The analysis indicated tha...
The waste rock dump area reclamation is intended to recreate a structurally and biologically varied forest community, although it is not necessarily intented to be indentical in terms of species composition within the previous forest. The evergreen ecosystem consistent with its original condition was used as a reference to assess the success of the waste rock dump reclamation area, while the deciduous ecosystem was used for other supporting facility area reclam...
p. 208 Terrestrial Fauna Baseline
8 facts â–¼
  • The 1996 baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded 201 local land vertebrate species within or near the Batu Hijau operation area.
  • This included 7 amphibians, 27 reptiles, 144 birds, and 25 mammals.
  • The 1996 assessment identified 25 mammal species, comprising 15 insectivores, 3 rodents, 3 carnivores, 2 ungulates, and 1 primate.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • The 1996 baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded 201 local land vertebrate species within or near the Batu Hijau operation area.
  • This included 7 amphibians, 27 reptiles, 144 birds, and 25 mammals.
  • The 1996 assessment identified 25 mammal species, comprising 15 insectivores, 3 rodents, 3 carnivores, 2 ungulates, and 1 primate.
  • Secondary forest areas exhibited the highest number of mammal species (19 species), followed by moist evergreen forest (12 species).
  • Bats were the most common mammal group in both secondary and moist evergreen forest locations.
  • No significant season-based changes in mammal diversity were observed.
  • The Lesser Sunda Fruit Bat was the most common species captured in mist net surveys.
  • Three rodent species, including the Polynesia rat, were recorded.
Original Text
The 1996 baseline Environmental Impact Assessment (PT Newmont, 1996) recorded 201 local land vertebrate species including 7 amphibians, 27 reptiles, 144 birds, and 25 mammals within or near the Batu Hijau operation area.
The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded a total of 25 species of mammals, including 15,1 insectivore, 3 rodents, 3 carnivores, 2 ungulates, and 1 primate (Table 7-12). Areas of secondary forest had the highest number of species (19 species), followed by moist evergreen forest (12 species). Bats was the most common group on both locations. There was no significant season-based change in diversity. The Lesser Sunda Fruit Bat was the most common species tr...

  • The table lists mammal species observed during the Elang Block Baseline Study in 2019.
  • Mammals are categorized by Order, Family, Species, Common Name, Location, Conservation Status (IUCN and CITES), and Distribution.
  • One listed species has an IUCN Conservation Status of 'LC' (Least Concern) and no CITES listing.
  • + 1 more facts...

  • Mammals are categorized by Order, Family, Species, Common Name, Location, Conservation Status (IUCN and CITES), and Distribution.
  • One listed species has an IUCN Conservation Status of 'LC' (Least Concern) and no CITES listing.
  • This species is distributed in Lombok and Ls.

p. 213 Mammals observed during the Elang Block Baseline Study, 2019
3 facts â–¼
  • The Chinese Goshawk (Accipiter soloensis) is a migratory species listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN and CITES Appendix II.
  • The Common Kingfisher (Alcedo atthis) is listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Brown-throated Sunbird (Anthreptes malacensis) is listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Chinese Goshawk (Accipiter soloensis) is a migratory species listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN and CITES Appendix II.
  • The Common Kingfisher (Alcedo atthis) is listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Brown-throated Sunbird (Anthreptes malacensis) is listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.

p. 214 Mammals, Reptiles, and Amphibians observed during the Elang ...
8 facts â–¼
  • The Black-faced Munia (Lonchura molucca) is an endemic species to Wallaceae and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Crested Dark-eye (Lophozosterops dohertyi) is an endemic species to Nusa Tenggara (NT) and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Yellow-browed Dark-eye (Lophozosterops superciliaris) is an endemic species to Flores and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • The Black-faced Munia (Lonchura molucca) is an endemic species to Wallaceae and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Crested Dark-eye (Lophozosterops dohertyi) is an endemic species to Nusa Tenggara (NT) and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Yellow-browed Dark-eye (Lophozosterops superciliaris) is an endemic species to Flores and listed as Least Concern (LC) by IUCN.
  • The Batu Hijau Environmental Impact Assessment Baseline Study recorded a total of 27 reptile species, including 10 snakes, 15 lizards, 1 turtle, and 1 crocodile.
  • The baseline study also recorded 7 amphibian species, comprising 6 frogs and 1 toad.
  • Twenty-one reptile and amphibian species (62%) were found in the moist evergreen forest habitat.
  • Rana limnocharis, a widespread amphibian, was recorded in 4 out of 6 habitat types in Batu Hijau.
  • The Microhylid frog (Oreophryne jeffersoniana) was the most dominant species in the moist evergreen forest habitat.

Twenty-one species (62%) were found in the moist evergreen forest habitat. Rana limnocharis is a widespread amphibian species in Batu Hijau; it was recorded in 4 of 6 habitat types. p. 219 Project Area Locations
4 facts â–¼
  • C1 (Elang-Dodo Area) includes the Brang Dodo River (Camp-Upstream), Camp Delta - Liang Nong River, and Elang-Dodo Camp.
  • C2 (Sebu Area) encompasses the Camp Dodo - Sebu track, small stream Sebu camp, Kokar Jelatang Stream, Brang Kuning River, and Sebu Camp.
  • C3 (Krida Area) contains a dried stream 2 km west of Flying campsites, Brang Po River, and a small stream in Brang Po River.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • C1 (Elang-Dodo Area) includes the Brang Dodo River (Camp-Upstream), Camp Delta - Liang Nong River, and Elang-Dodo Camp.
  • C2 (Sebu Area) encompasses the Camp Dodo - Sebu track, small stream Sebu camp, Kokar Jelatang Stream, Brang Kuning River, and Sebu Camp.
  • C3 (Krida Area) contains a dried stream 2 km west of Flying campsites, Brang Po River, and a small stream in Brang Po River.
  • C4 (Lunyuk Area) includes Batu Pampang and Sumber Sari.
