p. 220 Aquatic Biota Overview
5 facts â–¼
  • The description of aquatic ecosystems is based on the 1996 Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont).
  • Three main freshwater aquatic habitat types exist within the project area: Torrents, Middle reaches, and Estuaries.
  • Freshwater streams in the study area are short, have steep gradients in upper reaches, and limited estuarine habitat.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The description of aquatic ecosystems is based on the 1996 Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont).
  • Three main freshwater aquatic habitat types exist within the project area: Torrents, Middle reaches, and Estuaries.
  • Freshwater streams in the study area are short, have steep gradients in upper reaches, and limited estuarine habitat.
  • Water quality in the upper and middle reaches is generally very good, indicating minimal human disturbance.
  • Estuarine habitats are extremely restricted with poorly developed mangroves.
Original Text
The description of aquatic ecosystems within and around the Project is based on the Environmental Impact Assessment of Batu Hijau (PT Newmont, 1996).
There are three main freshwater aquatic habitat types within the project area: â–ª Torrents â–ª Middle reaches â–ª Estuaries Freshwater streams within the study area are short in length, have steep gradients in the upper reaches, and have limited estuarine habitat near the coast. Monitoring sites of aquatic ecology are shown in Figure 7-40 . Water quality in the upper and middle reaches generally is very good, and indicative of systems with little human disturbance. However, estuarine habit...
p. 221 Torrent and Middle Reach Habitats
10 facts â–¼
  • Upland torrent streams are characterized by steep gradients, fast water flow, rocky substrates, and shallow depths.
  • Two torrent habitat sites studied were the Sejorong system near Air Merah and the Tongoloka system.
  • Torrent sites exhibited relatively high pH (up to 8.1), low conductivity, and high dissolved oxygen content.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Upland torrent streams are characterized by steep gradients, fast water flow, rocky substrates, and shallow depths.
  • Two torrent habitat sites studied were the Sejorong system near Air Merah and the Tongoloka system.
  • Torrent sites exhibited relatively high pH (up to 8.1), low conductivity, and high dissolved oxygen content.
  • Aquatic vegetation in torrents was sparse or non-existent, consisting only of algae on rocks.
  • Middle-reach habitats occur where flow is reduced and river valleys are broad.
  • Five sites were selected in middle-reach habitats: Jereweh, Sejorong, Tongoloka, Liangse, and Tatarloka river systems.
  • Middle-reach water was generally clear, with slow to fast flows, and depths up to 2 m (typically < 1 m).
  • Channel width in middle reaches was variable, up to 60 m wide.
  • Middle-reach pH levels were relatively high, ranging from 7.6 to 8.5, with conductivity below 577 micromhos.
  • Aquatic vegetation in middle reaches was sparse, primarily algae.
Original Text
Upland torrent streams occur in the upper reaches of the main river systems. They are characterized by steep gradients, fast water flow, rocky substrates often with large boulders, and generally shallow depths. Two sites were chosen to study torrent habitat: the Sejorong system near Air Merah, and the Tongoloka system. The sites had relatively high pH (up to 8.1), while conductivity was low, and dissolved oxygen content was high. Aquatic vegetation was sparse or non-existent and consi...
These habitats occur in the middle reaches of the main rivers where flow is reduced and the river valleys are broad. Five sites were selected in middle-reach habitats: Jereweh, Sejorong, Tongoloka, Liangse, and Tatarloka river systems. Water at these sites was generally clear, with slow to fast flows. Depths were up to 2 m in the larger pools but typically < 1 m. Channel width was variable and as wide as 60 m. The pH levels were relatively high, ranging from 7.6 to 8.5. Conductivit...
p. 222 Estuarine Habitats
5 facts â–¼
  • Estuaries in the Elang project area are very small, often only several hundred meters in length.
  • The largest estuary is at the mouth of Brang Tatarloka, extending approximately two kilometers upstream.
  • Estuaries were relatively deep (> 2 m), slow-flowing or still, and tidally influenced.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Estuaries in the Elang project area are very small, often only several hundred meters in length.
  • The largest estuary is at the mouth of Brang Tatarloka, extending approximately two kilometers upstream.
  • Estuaries were relatively deep (> 2 m), slow-flowing or still, and tidally influenced.
  • Seven estuarine sites were selected at the mouths of the Sejorong, Sekongkang, Tatarloka, Liangse, and Tongoloka rivers.
  • Water quality in the estuaries was high.
Original Text
Estuaries exist in lower river reaches near the coast where they experience marine influence. Within the Elang project area they are very small, often only several hundred meters in length. The largest estuary in the area is at the mouth of Brang Tatarloka, which extends for approximately two kms upstream, as shown in Figure 7-43. The estuaries were relatively deep (> 2 m), slow-flowing or still, and tidally influenced. Seven sites were selected for estuaries: at the mouth...
p. 223 Macro-invertebrates and Fish
8 facts â–¼
  • Middle reaches had the highest number of macro-invertebrate species, with 86% being insect taxa.
  • Diptera (20 species), Trichoptera (12 species), and Coleoptera (10 species) were the most diverse insect orders.
  • Total abundance of individual macro-invertebrates at each site ranged from 40 to 259.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Middle reaches had the highest number of macro-invertebrate species, with 86% being insect taxa.
  • Diptera (20 species), Trichoptera (12 species), and Coleoptera (10 species) were the most diverse insect orders.
  • Total abundance of individual macro-invertebrates at each site ranged from 40 to 259.
  • Sekongkang river sites had fewer individual macro-invertebrates than other sites.
  • Tatarloka River had the highest number of macro-invertebrate species and the second-highest number of individuals.
  • The order Ephemeroptera (mayflies) was the most abundant macro-invertebrate group.
  • 549 individual fish of 21 species were found in Torrents, including 236 Rasbora laterisriata.
  • 537 individual fish among 33 species were found in Estuarine and Middle Reaches.
Original Text
Middle reaches had the highest number of species, and the majority (86%) of fauna was insect taxa. Diptera (flies), Trichoptera (caddisflies) and Coleoptera (beetles) were the most diverse orders comprising 20, 12, and 10 species respectively. Other insect orders were represented by fewer than 10 species. Total abundance of individuals at each site ranged from 40 to 259. Sites in Sekongkang river had fewer numbers of individuals than other sites. Tatarloka River had the highest number of species...
There were 549 individual fish of 21 species found in Torrents, including 236 Rasbora laterisriata . In the Estuarine and Middle Reaches, 537 individual fish were found among 33 species.
p. 224 Species Diversity and Distribution
3 facts â–¼
  • The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded a total of 70 fish species from 27 families.
  • The order Gobiidei (gobies) was the most frequent group, represented by 26 species from 4 families.
  • Gobies accounted for 37% of all fish species recorded in the survey.
  • The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded a total of 70 fish species from 27 families.
  • The order Gobiidei (gobies) was the most frequent group, represented by 26 species from 4 families.
  • Gobies accounted for 37% of all fish species recorded in the survey.
Original Text
The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment recorded a total of 70 fish species from 27 families were recorded during the surveys. The most frequent group recorded was from the order Gobiidei (gobies), which was represented by 26 species from 4 families. These families were Rhyacicthyidae (loach gobies), Eleotrididae (gudgeons), Kraemariidae (sand gobies), and Gobiidae ('true' gobies). In total, gobies accounted for 37% of all fish species recorded in the survey. Figure ...
p. 226 Introduced species and Marine Ecosystems
10 facts â–¼
  • One introduced fish species, tilapia (Oreochromis mossambica), was found in high abundance in the Coastal Wetlands despite poor water quality.
  • Introduced fish species established in Lake Taliwang, 15 km north of the study area, include tilapia, walking catfish, gourami, and snakewad.
  • Numerous freshwater prawns from the genus Macrobrachium and freshwater mollusks were collected.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • One introduced fish species, tilapia (Oreochromis mossambica), was found in high abundance in the Coastal Wetlands despite poor water quality.
  • Introduced fish species established in Lake Taliwang, 15 km north of the study area, include tilapia, walking catfish, gourami, and snakewad.
  • Numerous freshwater prawns from the genus Macrobrachium and freshwater mollusks were collected.
  • No freshwater turtles were recorded, and local people stated they do not occur in these river systems.
  • Estuarine crocodiles (Crocodylus porosus) are known to live in the Tatarloka and Liangse rivers, with one sighted during surveys.
  • Estuarine snakes such as Cerberus rynchops and Acrochordus granulatus are present.
  • Marine ecosystems include shoreline habitats, intertidal and subtidal communities, coral reefs, macro-zoobenthos, and plankton from Teluk Benete to Teluk Puna.
  • Coastal habitats are predominantly exposed, high wave-energy environments.
  • The western shore of Sumbawa is characterized by steep cliffs with boulders or sandy embayments.
  • The southern shore consists of extensive wave-cut platforms, fringing reefs, and sandy beaches.
Original Text
Despite extremely poor water quality within the Coastal Wetlands sites, one introduced fish species, tilapia ( Oreochromis mossambica ), was found in high abundance. This species in an important food fish throughout Asia and has been widely introduced. Several introduced fish are established in Lake Taliwang, a large freshwater wetland approximately 15 km north of the study area. These include tilapia ( Oreochromis mossambica ), walking catfish ( Clarius batrachus ), gourami ( Osphro...
Many freshwater prawns, especially from the genus Macrobrachium , were collected by electrofishing methods. Numerous freshwater mollusks were also hand-collected from rocks along streams. No freshwater turtles were recorded and local people interviewed stated that turtles do not occur in these river systems. Estuarine crocodiles ( Crocodylus porosus ) are known to live in the Tatarloka and Liangse rivers, but only one was sighted during the surveys. Estuarine snakes such as Cerberus ryn...
Marine ecosystems within the study area include shoreline habitats, intertidal and subtidal communities, coral reefs, macro-zoobenthos, and plankton of the coastal waters from Teluk Benete to Teluk Puna (Figure 7-46). Coastal habitats are predominantly exposed, high waveenergy coastal environments, characterized on the western shore of Sumbawa by steep cliffs, with boulders or sandy embayments between the headlands. The southern shore consists of extensive wave-cut platforms, fringing reefs,...
p. 227 Cliffs and Rocky Headlands
8 facts â–¼
  • Steep, precipitous cliffs up to 300 m elevation dominate the western coastline facing the Alas Strait.
  • Major embayments separating headlands include Teluk Benete and Teluk Sekongkang.
  • Scars from rockfalls and under-cut cliffs characterize main headlands with little to no reef platform.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Steep, precipitous cliffs up to 300 m elevation dominate the western coastline facing the Alas Strait.
  • Major embayments separating headlands include Teluk Benete and Teluk Sekongkang.
  • Scars from rockfalls and under-cut cliffs characterize main headlands with little to no reef platform.
  • Teluk Benete is the most sheltered coastal environment due to its narrow entrance and northwesterly aspect.
  • Two rivers, Brang Benete and a smaller creek, flow into Teluk Benete, making its eastern coastal waters frequently turbid.
  • Beaches have black/grey sand from on-shore material or yellow/white sand of marine, coralline origin.
  • White sandy beaches occur in Teluk Sekongkang and along most of the coast from Tanjung Mangkun to Teluk Puna.
  • Extensive intertidal reef areas typically occur offshore of white sandy beaches.
Original Text
Steep, precipitous cliffs dominate the western coastline of the study area which faces the Alas Strait. The headlands are up to 300 m elevation and are separated by embayments; the major ones being Teluk Benete and Teluk Sekongkang. Scars from rockfalls and under-cut cliffs characterize all main headlands around which there is little or no reef platform. Steep cliffs occur on the north and south sides of Teluk Benete, which is protected because of its relatively narrow entrance and n...
Beaches throughout the study area either have black/grey sand where the sand is derived from on-shore material or yellow/white where the sand is of marine, coralline origin. White sandy beaches occur in Teluk Sekongkang, and along most of the coast from Tanjung Mangkun to Teluk Puna. Extensive intertidal reef areas typically occur offshore of these sandy beaches. Teluk Benete is the most sheltered coastal environment within the study area. Two rivers, Brang Benete and a smaller creek to the sout...
p. 228 Intertidal Reefs
3 facts â–¼
  • The most extensive intertidal reef system is along the south coast, from Tanjung Mangkun to the Brang Puna estuary, approximately 5 km east of Teluk S...
  • This fringing reef is up to 300 m wide and forms a distinctive line of surf.
  • The reef has pronounced spur and groove formation extending from the subtidal area to the low and mid-intertidal zone.
  • The most extensive intertidal reef system is along the south coast, from Tanjung Mangkun to the Brang Puna estuary, approximately 5 km east of Teluk Senutak.
  • This fringing reef is up to 300 m wide and forms a distinctive line of surf.
  • The reef has pronounced spur and groove formation extending from the subtidal area to the low and mid-intertidal zone.
Original Text
The most extensive intertidal reef system occurs along the south coast, from Tanjung Mangkun to the estuary of Brang Puna, approximately 5 km east of Teluk Senutak, shown in Figure 7-47. The fringing reef is up to 300 m wide and forms a distinctive line of surf from the oceanic swell. Throughout its length, the reef has pronounced spur and groove formation which extends from the subtidal area to the low and mid-intertidal zone.
p. 229 Intertidal Monitoring Sites
5 facts â–¼
  • East of Brang Puna and throughout Teluk Puna, the intertidal reef platform is narrow or non-existent.
  • This coastal section is dominated by eroding limestone cliffs (Teluk Sennutak to Brang Puna) and low volcanic cliffs (east of Brang Puna).
  • Fragments of eroded cliff and rocks extend only a short subtidal distance due to the steep offshore gradient.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • East of Brang Puna and throughout Teluk Puna, the intertidal reef platform is narrow or non-existent.
  • This coastal section is dominated by eroding limestone cliffs (Teluk Sennutak to Brang Puna) and low volcanic cliffs (east of Brang Puna).
  • Fragments of eroded cliff and rocks extend only a short subtidal distance due to the steep offshore gradient.
  • In Benete, the intertidal zone of black sand mixed with clay is most extensive at the east end of the bay.
  • The width of the intertidal zone varies in Benete.
Original Text
To the east of Brang Puna and throughout Teluk Puna, the intertidal reef platform is narrow or non-existent. In this section, the coast is dominated by eroding cliffs consisting of limestone (low headlands from Teluk Sennutak to Brang Puna) and low volcanic cliffs (to the east of Brang Puna). Along this coastal area, fragments of eroded cliff and rocks extend subtidally only a short distance beyond the surf zone because of the step off-shore gradient. In Benete, the intertidal zone of black sand...
p. 231 Subtidal Reefs
8 facts â–¼
  • Coral reef development around southwest Sumbawa is strongly influenced by heavy swell and surf from the Indian Ocean.
  • High wave energy has led to fringing reefs and wave-cut platforms along the south coast and in Sekongkang embayments.
  • Reef crests and seaward slopes of fringing reefs exhibit pronounced spur and groove formations.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Coral reef development around southwest Sumbawa is strongly influenced by heavy swell and surf from the Indian Ocean.
  • High wave energy has led to fringing reefs and wave-cut platforms along the south coast and in Sekongkang embayments.
  • Reef crests and seaward slopes of fringing reefs exhibit pronounced spur and groove formations.
  • The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) observed seafloor material varying from fine grey sand to coarse coral rubble and oolitic sand.
  • Underwater video at the top of the Senunu trench (30-43m depth) confirmed discernible, though irregular, spur and groove differentiation.
  • Submarine canyons of Teluk Senutak and Teluk Senunu consist of horizontal, sediment-covered ledges and vertical or near-vertical cliff walls.
  • Rock material in canyon walls appeared to be an extension of volcanic material with interspersed crevasses.
  • Life forms at these depths in 1996 mainly consisted of encrusting organisms.
Original Text
Exposure to heavy swell and surf from the Indian Ocean strongly influences the development of coral reefs around the coast of southwest Sumbawa. High wave energy has resulted in the development of fringing reefs and wave-cut platforms along much of the south coast, and in the embayments of Sekongkang. Reef crests and seaward slopes of the fringing reefs have pronounced spur and groove formation resulting from the surge and backwash of the swell carrying sand and broken coral fragments, forming a...
Observation results from the 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment shows seafloor material generally varied from fine grey sand of predominantly terrigenous origin (e.g., off Teluk Puna and in Benete) to coarse coral rubble and oolitic sand (cemented calcium carbonate) and shell fragments (e.g., off Senunu). Direct observations from the underwater video at the top of the Senunu trench in depths of 30 to 43 m confirmed that differentiation of spur and groove was still discernib...
Submarine canyons of Teluk Senutak and Teluk Senunu were viewed in the 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmental Impact Assessment. The steep gradient of these canyons consists predominantly of a series of horizontal, sediment-covered ledges, and vertical or nearvertical cliff walls. Rock material of these walls appeared to be an extension of volcanic material interspersed with crevasses as is evident in much of the land formations. The 1996 Batu Hijau baseline Environmenta...
p. 232 Coral Communities
4 facts â–¼
  • Coral communities consisted of hard coral, soft coral, and sand or rock substratum.
  • The 2018 Batu Hijau Environmental Management and Implementation reported very little algae cover, typical of highly exposed fringing reef areas.
  • Coral reefs of Teluk Sekongkang and Tanjung Mangkun have the highest percent cover of live corals in the study area, at 74% and 76% respectively.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Coral communities consisted of hard coral, soft coral, and sand or rock substratum.
  • The 2018 Batu Hijau Environmental Management and Implementation reported very little algae cover, typical of highly exposed fringing reef areas.
  • Coral reefs of Teluk Sekongkang and Tanjung Mangkun have the highest percent cover of live corals in the study area, at 74% and 76% respectively.
  • In exposed areas with predominantly rock substratum, a high cover of life forms was observed, dominated by encrusting and low-branching corals.
Original Text
Coral communities consisted of hard coral, soft coral, and sand or rock substratum. Based on the 2018 Batu Hijau Environmental Management and Implementation, there was very little cover of algae (except for isolated patches of Halimeda ), typical of the highly exposed fringing reef area, and little dead coral. Coral reefs of Teluk Sekongkang and Tanjung Mangkun have the highest percent cover of live corals in the study area with 74% and 76%, respectively. In exposed areas, where the substratum w...
p. 233 Reef Fish
4 facts â–¼
  • Reef fish census observations focused on Pomacentridae and Chaetodontidae families due to their reef-dependent nature and ease of counting.
  • At least 46 reef fish species were identified within the coral reefs of the study area.
  • Fish abundance in Teluk Benete was approximately 0.61 individuals/mÂ².
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Reef fish census observations focused on Pomacentridae and Chaetodontidae families due to their reef-dependent nature and ease of counting.
  • At least 46 reef fish species were identified within the coral reefs of the study area.
  • Fish abundance in Teluk Benete was approximately 0.61 individuals/mÂ².
  • Abundance was lowest in the exposed reef slope areas (Senutak east and west).
Original Text
Reef fish census observations concentrated mainly on the Pomacentridae and Chaetodontidae , which are families of reef-dependent species generally resident in specific localities and are relatively easy to count -making them an optimal target for reef-fish inventories. Other groups were also included in the census if abundant. At least 46 species were found within the coral reefs of the study area, and fish abundance was around 0.61 individuals/m in Teluk Benete. 2 Abundance was low...
p. 234 Other Reef Organisms
9 facts â–¼
  • Typical reef organisms like urchins, starfish, clams, sea cucumbers, and crabs seek cryptic habitats in high-energy reef areas.
  • Subsistence fishers obtain urchins, abalone, sea cucumbers, and small fish from intertidal areas at low tide.
  • Approximately 20 species of phytoplankton and 8 dominant groups of zooplankton were recorded in the coastal waters.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • Typical reef organisms like urchins, starfish, clams, sea cucumbers, and crabs seek cryptic habitats in high-energy reef areas.
  • Subsistence fishers obtain urchins, abalone, sea cucumbers, and small fish from intertidal areas at low tide.
  • Approximately 20 species of phytoplankton and 8 dominant groups of zooplankton were recorded in the coastal waters.
  • Phytoplankton abundance varied, exceeding 50,000 individuals per liter of seawater.
  • The 2018 Batu Hijau Environmental Management and Implementation recorded macrobenthos taxa ranging from 6 to 13 in Benete Bay.
  • The highest macrobenthos abundance was 410 individuals/mÂ², and the lowest was 80 individuals/mÂ².
  • The diversity index for macrobenthos ranged from 2.43 to 3.04.
  • Benete Bay was highly dominated by Malacostraca (Hyale, Caliannasa).
  • The highest abundance of macro-zoobenthos was documented at Teluk Benete with 1,615 individuals/mÂ².
Original Text
In the generally high-energy reef areas, other typical reef organisms such as urchins, starfish, clams, sea cucumbers, and crabs tend to seek out cryptic (concealing) habitat. This makes them difficult to observe and abundance is therefore difficult to assess. Subsistence fishers often fish in the intertidal areas at low tide by means of crowbars breaking open holes and crevices to obtain varieties of urchins, abalone, sea cucumbers, and small fish (including pufferfish and stonefish...
Plankton is divided into two major groups -phytoplankton (flora) and zooplankton (fauna). Zooplankton feeds on phytoplankton, which forms the basis of the marine food chain. Approximately 20 species of phytoplankton and 8 dominant groups of zooplankton were recorded in the coastal waters of the study area with monitoring sites for plankton and benthic coomunities are shown in Figure 7-18. Phytoplankton abundance varied, with >50,000 individuals per ...
The 2018 Batu Hijau Environmental Management and Implementation recorded the highest taxa of macrobenthos were 13 taxa and the lowest were 6 taxa at Benete Bay with monitrong sites are shown in Figure 7-18. The highest abundance was found at 410 individuals/m2, and the lowest at 80 individuals/m2. The diversity index ranged from 2.43 to 3.04. Benete was also highly dominated by Malacostraca ( Hyale , Caliannasa ). Figure 7-50 Plankton and Benthic Communities Monitoring Sites The highest abundanc...
p. 236 Deep Water Fish
4 facts â–¼
  • Ten to twelve species of deep-water snapper, grouper, and jacks, which are of commercial value, inhabit the continental slopes of the tropical Indo-Pa...
  • These high-value food species include 7 specific species: Pristimopoides multidens, P. filamentous, Etelis carbunculus, E. radiosus, Lethrinus elongat...
  • Pristipomoides multidens was most commonly represented in the catch during February.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Ten to twelve species of deep-water snapper, grouper, and jacks, which are of commercial value, inhabit the continental slopes of the tropical Indo-Pacific region.
  • These high-value food species include 7 specific species: Pristimopoides multidens, P. filamentous, Etelis carbunculus, E. radiosus, Lethrinus elongate, Epinephalus magniscuttis, and Dentex tumifrons.
  • Pristipomoides multidens was most commonly represented in the catch during February.
  • Pristimopoides multidens was replaced by Etelis carbunculus in subsequent catches.
Original Text
Ten to twelve species of deep-water snapper, grouper, and jacks -species of commercial value -are known to inhabit the continental slopes of the tropical InfoPacific region (Richards [1984], SPC [1984], Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola [undated]). These high-value food species comprise of 7 species: Pristimopoides multidens , P. filamentous , Etelis carbunculus , E. radiosus , Lethrinus elongate , Epinephalus magniscuttis, and Dentex tumifrons . Pristipomoides multidens was...
p. 237 Sea Turtles
3 facts â–¼
  • Sea turtle nesting tracks were surveyed on beaches within the study area primarily by helicopter, supplemented by ground surveys.
  • Documented data included new turtle tracks, old turtle tracks, non-return tracks, and evidence of nest disturbance or egg collectors.
  • Ground surveys confirmed the presence of old turtle nesting pits on most beaches where sand extends above the highest tide level.
  • Sea turtle nesting tracks were surveyed on beaches within the study area primarily by helicopter, supplemented by ground surveys.
  • Documented data included new turtle tracks, old turtle tracks, non-return tracks, and evidence of nest disturbance or egg collectors.
  • Ground surveys confirmed the presence of old turtle nesting pits on most beaches where sand extends above the highest tide level.

p. 239 Project-Affected People
3 facts â–¼
  • The proposed Elang Project area, excluding the Overland Conveyor (OLC), overlaps three subdistricts: Lenangguar, Ropang, and Lunyuk Districts.
  • The OLC also overlaps with three subdistricts: Sekongkang, Lunyuk, and Lenangguar.
  • AMNT, in partnership with Universitas Indonesia (UI), completed a comprehensive social baseline study of the Elang block area in 2012.

  • The OLC also overlaps with three subdistricts: Sekongkang, Lunyuk, and Lenangguar.

p. 244 Education and Skill Base
3 facts â–¼
  • Sumbawa Regency has higher student-to-teacher ratios than West Sumbawa Regency, ranging from 27 (primary) to 40 (high school) students per teacher.
  • West Sumbawa Regency has lower student-to-teacher ratios, ranging from 3 (primary) to 9 (high school) students per teacher.
  • Sumbawa Regency has more schools at all educational levels, possibly due to better economic conditions.

p. 249 Traditions
5 facts â–¼
  • Communities around the Batu Hijau mine site strongly embrace social norms and values centered on helpfulness, unity, justice, honesty, and trust.
  • Prior to the Batu Hijau mine's operation, local residents were described as 'aggressively traditional' with strong social norms.
  • Since the mine's commissioning in 1997, immigration from other parts of Indonesia has occurred.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Communities around the Batu Hijau mine site strongly embrace social norms and values centered on helpfulness, unity, justice, honesty, and trust.
  • Prior to the Batu Hijau mine's operation, local residents were described as 'aggressively traditional' with strong social norms.
  • Since the mine's commissioning in 1997, immigration from other parts of Indonesia has occurred.
  • Ethnic people on Sumbawa Island are referred to as tau Samawa, recognized as having mixed heritage from various Indonesian islands.
  • Subtle perceptions of 'higher class' exist among those with Bugis ancestry within the Samawa ethnic group.
Original Text
Communities around the Batu Hijau mine site strongly embrace social norms and values, which are centered around the virtues of helpfulness, unity, justice, honesty, and trust (Social Impact Assesssment, 2013). Many of these values are based on their faith, religion, and spirituality. Prior studies by NNT stated that prior to operation of the Batu Hijau mine, local residents were 'aggressively traditional' with strong and binding social norms and values. Since commissioning o...
Ethnic people on Sumbawa Island are referred to as tau Samawa (directly translated as 'people of Sumbawa'), who are recognized by anthropologists and local people -to be mixed heritage, with ancestors coming from Java, Sulawesi, Bali, Lombok, Flores, Bima, and others (UI, 2012). Within the ethnic group of Samawa, there are perceived differences among groups based on their ancestry and geographic locations. For instance, concerning ancestry, UI (2012) noted a subtle perception...
p. 250 Vulnerable Groups
3 facts â–¼
  • Vulnerable groups are individuals or groups at higher risk of impoverishment and social exclusion.
  • Vulnerability can stem from ethnicity, color, gender, gender identity, language, religion, age, disablement, political or different opinion, national ...
  • Separate consultations are typically held for women and vulnerable groups to address their specific needs and concerns.
  • Vulnerable groups are individuals or groups at higher risk of impoverishment and social exclusion.
  • Vulnerability can stem from ethnicity, color, gender, gender identity, language, religion, age, disablement, political or different opinion, national or social origin, property, birth, and/or status.
  • Separate consultations are typically held for women and vulnerable groups to address their specific needs and concerns.
Original Text
Vulnerable groups are made up of people who experience higher risks of impoverishment and social exclusion compared to the general population. Vulnerability may stem from an individual's or group's ethnicity, color, gender, gender identity, language, relig ion, age, disablement, political or different opinion, national or social origin, property, birth, and or status. p. 251 Cultural Values
8 facts â–¼
  • Compromise, tolerance, and respect are values embraced by the people of Sumbawa.
  • Historical instances of anger and violence have occurred, such as the murder of B. Eysenburger on January 7, 1913.
  • Sumbawa values tend to revolve around ila (pride), pamendi (kindness), and janggi (resignation to fate).
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Compromise, tolerance, and respect are values embraced by the people of Sumbawa.
  • Historical instances of anger and violence have occurred, such as the murder of B. Eysenburger on January 7, 1913.
  • Sumbawa values tend to revolve around ila (pride), pamendi (kindness), and janggi (resignation to fate).
  • Ila (pride) is often attributed to conflicts among Sumbawan people, especially in familial disputes.
  • Two major social institutions practiced on Sumbawa Island are Tokal adat and Tokal keluarga.
  • Tokal adat is a community meeting led by senior members concerning public issues like conflicts and infrastructure.
  • Tokal keluarga is a family discussion led by experienced family members regarding familial matters such as births, circumcisions, and marriages.
  • The practical significance of tokol adat has decreased over time.
Original Text
Compromise, tolerance, and respect are values embraced by the people of Sumbawa. However, anger and violence has erupted in the past, such as the murder of B. Eysenburger on 7 January, 1913 (UI, 2012). Raba (2003, in UI [2012]) explained how Sumbawa values tend to revolve around ila (pride), pamendi (kindness, especially to newcomers and the unfortunate), and janggi (resignation to fate, possibly mixed with regrets). The first value -ila -is often attributed to conflicts that ...
There are two major social institutions practiced on Sumbawa Island (UI, 2012): Â· Tokal adat , which is a meeting or discussion -often led by the most senior and experienced members of the community -concerning public issues, such as conflicts among community members and infrastructure issues (e.g., roads, irrigation pipelines). Â· Tokal keluarga , which is a discussion relating to familial matters, such as births, circumcision and marriage, and generally led by the m...
p. 252 Cultural Heritage
5 facts â–¼
  • Greencorp identified several cultural heritage sites within and around the Elang Project Area.
  • UI (2012) reported two ancient grave sites, collectively referred to as the Dodo Grave.
  • One Dodo Grave site is in an abandoned village in Ropang District, Sumbawa Regency.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Greencorp identified several cultural heritage sites within and around the Elang Project Area.
  • UI (2012) reported two ancient grave sites, collectively referred to as the Dodo Grave.
  • One Dodo Grave site is in an abandoned village in Ropang District, Sumbawa Regency.
  • The second Dodo Grave site is on the eastern side of Olat (Mount) Dodo, beside the Brang Dodo River.
  • The exact location of the Dodo Grave is unknown due to its age and dense surrounding forests.

p. 253 Perception to Tailing
5 facts â–¼
  • A Stakeholder Mapping Report by AMNT (2017) indicated community concerns about the risks of DSTP (Deep Sea Tailing Placement).
  • Residents of Tongo Village, Sekongkang District, expressed particular concern due to a 2017 contaminated-water event.
  • The 2017 event in Tongo Village was suspected to be caused by an overflow of mine waste into the Tongo Loka River, resulting in fish deaths.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • A Stakeholder Mapping Report by AMNT (2017) indicated community concerns about the risks of DSTP (Deep Sea Tailing Placement).
  • Residents of Tongo Village, Sekongkang District, expressed particular concern due to a 2017 contaminated-water event.
  • The 2017 event in Tongo Village was suspected to be caused by an overflow of mine waste into the Tongo Loka River, resulting in fish deaths.
  • The contaminated-water event led to a protest against the company, but no official cause of contamination was declared.
  • The unresolved 2017 incident contributes to community belief that similar accidents could recur.
Original Text
A Stakeholder Mapping Report by AMNT (2017) revealed that some communities are still concerned about the risks of DSTP. This is particularly true for people in Tongo Village, Sekongkang District, where in 2017, there was a contaminated-water event suspected to be caused by overflow of mine waste into the Tongo Loka River. As a result, many fish were killed. This led to a protest against the company; however, there has never been an official cause of the contamination declared. Thi...
p. 254 Gross Regional Domestic Product
3 facts â–¼

The majority of residents in these villages were farmers (46% of 300 respondents across all surveyed villages) (Figure 7-63). Entrepreneurship (i.e. owning and operating small and medium shops or businesses) and working as private employees are also popular occupations in these villages, with 16% and 13% of the respondents having these occupations, respectively (Table 7-34). p. 259 Income and Expenditure
3 facts â–¼
  • A 2017 fishery study by the University of Mataram found that most surveyed fishers used traditional, small-scale methods with 6-7m boats and 5-7 PK en...
  • Fisher income levels in Ai Kangkung Village fluctuated from IDR 1,428,324 to IDR 7,513,494 monthly in 2017.
  • Income levels for fishers were higher in March due to optimal weather conditions leading to increased catch rates.
  • A 2017 fishery study by the University of Mataram found that most surveyed fishers used traditional, small-scale methods with 6-7m boats and 5-7 PK engines.
  • Fisher income levels in Ai Kangkung Village fluctuated from IDR 1,428,324 to IDR 7,513,494 monthly in 2017.
  • Income levels for fishers were higher in March due to optimal weather conditions leading to increased catch rates.
Original Text
Based on a 2017 fishery study by the University of Mataram, the majority of surveyed fishers used traditional methods and operated on a small-scale - generally referred to as 'one -day fishing' and characterized by 6 -7 m-long and 0.5-1 m-wide boats, 5-7 PK engines, and 1-3 people onboard. The survey revealed that fisher income level tends to fluctuate throughout the year. In Ai Kangkung Vilage, monthly income levels ranged from IDR 1,428,324 to IDR 7,513,494. Income levels in March tend to be h...

p. 261 Fisheries
3 facts â–¼
  • A 2017 fishery survey by the University of Mataram focused on Ai Kangkung Village, Sekongkang District, within the Batu Hijau processing plant expansi...
  • Most fishers in Sekongkang District are traditional, small-scale fishers who learn from family members.
  • The majority of fishers in the area fish in coral reefs and seagrass areas.
  • A 2017 fishery survey by the University of Mataram focused on Ai Kangkung Village, Sekongkang District, within the Batu Hijau processing plant expansion area.
  • Most fishers in Sekongkang District are traditional, small-scale fishers who learn from family members.
  • The majority of fishers in the area fish in coral reefs and seagrass areas.
Original Text

The survey included a village within the expansion area of Batu Hijau processing plant: Ai Kangkung Village, Sekongkang District, which will be the focus of this subsection. p. 263 Length and Condition of Roads
2 facts â–¼
  • Sumbawa District has 951 km of roads, with 47% (452.4 km) paved with asphalt and approximately 35% (332.4 km) being dirt roads.
  • 51% of the roads in Sumbawa Regency are in 'good' condition, while 28% are 'severely damaged' and 10% are 'damaged'.
  • Sumbawa District has 951 km of roads, with 47% (452.4 km) paved with asphalt and approximately 35% (332.4 km) being dirt roads.
  • 51% of the roads in Sumbawa Regency are in 'good' condition, while 28% are 'severely damaged' and 10% are 'damaged'.
Original Text
The majority of roads in Sumbawa District and Project-affected villages are either asphalt or dirt roads (Table 7-37). Out of 951 km of roads in the District, 47% are paved with asphalt (452.4 km) and approximately 35% are dirt roads (332.4 km). 51% of the roads in the Regency are considered 'good', while 28% are 'severely damaged', and 10% are 'damaged'. p. 267 Prevalence of Diseases
4 facts â–¼
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract (URTI) was the most common disease in Sumbawa Regency in 2015 and 2016, accounting for over 23% of tota...
  • URTI includes nasal obstruction, sore throat, sinusitis, and the common cold, primarily caused by viruses and bacteria.
  • URTI diseases like flu and coughs are particularly prevalent during planting and harvesting seasons.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract (URTI) was the most common disease in Sumbawa Regency in 2015 and 2016, accounting for over 23% of total health cases.
  • URTI includes nasal obstruction, sore throat, sinusitis, and the common cold, primarily caused by viruses and bacteria.
  • URTI diseases like flu and coughs are particularly prevalent during planting and harvesting seasons.
  • Neuromuscular diseases are also common in Sumbawa Regency.
Original Text
The most common disease in Sumbawa Regency, according to the National Statistics Agency, is acute infection of the upper respiratory tract (URTI), making up more than 23% of the total health cases in 2015 and 2016. URTI generally refers to a group of diseases, including nasal obstruction, sore throat, sinusitis, and the common cold. URTI is mostly caused by viruses and bacteria; however, they are generally considered non-fatal. URTI diseases, such as flu and coughs, are especially prevalent duri...
p. 268 Sanitation
4 facts â–¼
  • In Lenangguar District, 79.1% of respondents lacked access to toilets in 2012.

  • Conversely, 60.8% of residents in Lunyuk District possessed their own private toilets in 2012.

  • The 2012 UI Social Baseline Study reported a lack of community awareness regarding healthy and sanitary practices.

A significant proportion of people in Ropang subdistrict (41.5%) did not have toilets either. Conversely, 60.8% of residents in Lunyuk possessed their own, private toilets. These data indicate the varying accessibility among some subdistricts to proper sanitation practices. UI (2012) also ...
p. 269 Sources of Clean Water
4 facts â–¼
  • The Greencorp 2019 social survey found that 46.2% of respondents across surveyed districts used dug wells for drinking water.
  • Dug wells were used by 65% of respondents for cooking, 65.9% for showering, and 64.3% for washing.
  • Only 0.9% of respondents used rivers as a source for drinking water.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Greencorp 2019 social survey found that 46.2% of respondents across surveyed districts used dug wells for drinking water.
  • Dug wells were used by 65% of respondents for cooking, 65.9% for showering, and 64.3% for washing.
  • Only 0.9% of respondents used rivers as a source for drinking water.
  • River water was used by 1.3% of respondents for cooking, 5.4% for showering, and 4.5% for washing.
Original Text
Results from the Greencorp 2019 social survey are provided in Table 7-47 and Table 7-48. Respondents across all surveyed districts were dependent on dug wells: 46.2% of the total respondents use them for drinking; 65% for cooking; 65.9% for showering; and 64.3% for washing. The numbers of respondents who used the river as a source of clean water are relatively low: 0.9% for drinking, 1.3% for cooking, 5.4% for showering, and 4.5% for washing (Table 7-48). p. 273 SCOPING OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL RISKS AND IMPACTS
3 facts â–¼

  • The scope of impact assessment includes the Elang project Area of Influence, encompassing cumulative impacts.
  • Risks and impacts from third-party actions within the Elang project's area of influence will be addressed if the project has control or influence.
  • The Elang project has a process for identifying and evaluating environmental and social risks and impacts, primarily through the ESIA and IFC requirements.
  • The scope of impact assessment includes the Elang project Area of Influence, encompassing cumulative impacts.
  • Risks and impacts from third-party actions within the Elang project's area of influence will be addressed if the project has control or influence.
Original Text
The Elang project has established and maintains a process for identifying and evaluating the environmental and social risks and impacts of the Elang project, principally through the ESIA and related IFC requirements. The scope includes the Elang project Area of Influence (as defined below), including cumulative impacts (Chapter 11). Risks and impacts in the Elang project's area of influence that result from a third party's actions will be addressed where the Elang project has con...
p. 274 Terminology and Definitions
2 facts â–¼
  • Direct impacts result from a direct interaction between a planned project activity and the receiving environment, such as land occupation and habitat ...
  • Secondary impacts follow from primary interactions, affecting the environment through subsequent interactions, like habitat loss impacting a species p...
  • Direct impacts result from a direct interaction between a planned project activity and the receiving environment, such as land occupation and habitat loss.
  • Secondary impacts follow from primary interactions, affecting the environment through subsequent interactions, like habitat loss impacting a species population over a wider area.
Original Text
A description of the terminologies that are used throughout ESIA to define and describe impacts follows.
High Medium Low Slight No Change Impacts that result from a direct interaction between a planned project activity and the receiving environment (e.g. between occupation of a plot of land and the habitats which are lost). Impact that follow on from the primary interactions between the project and its environment as a result of subsequent interactions within the environment (e.g. loss of part of a habitat affects the viability of a species population over a wi...
p. 275 Impact Scale and Significance
14 facts â–¼
  • Local scale impacts are restricted to the vicinity of the plant, within the project area.
  • Broader scale impacts extend well beyond the immediate vicinity of facilities, affecting the region.
  • Extensive impacts are on a much broader scale than the project's zone of influence, potentially provincial, national, or international, including seco...
  • + 11 more facts...
  • Local scale impacts are restricted to the vicinity of the plant, within the project area.
  • Broader scale impacts extend well beyond the immediate vicinity of facilities, affecting the region.
  • Extensive impacts are on a much broader scale than the project's zone of influence, potentially provincial, national, or international, including secondary economic benefits or primary carbon footprint.
  • A positive impact represents an improvement on the baseline or introduces a new desirable factor.
  • A negligible impact has a magnitude of change comparable to natural variation.
  • A minor impact is detectable but not significant, and is considered an acceptable risk, though further mitigation is desirable.
  • A moderate impact is significant, amenable to mitigation, and borderline acceptable, requiring further mitigation if possible.
  • A major impact is significant, amenable to mitigation, and must be mitigated as it is not acceptable.
  • A critical impact is intolerable and not amenable to mitigation.
  • An event is 'very unlikely' if it is generally never heard of in the industry but may occur in exceptional circumstances.
  • An event is 'unlikely' if it may occur at some time during normal operating conditions and is heard of in the industry.
  • An event is 'likely' if it is expected to occur at some time during normal operating conditions, having occurred in the company before.
  • An event is 'very likely' if it occurs several times per year in the company during normal operating conditions.
  • An event 'will occur' during normal operating conditions.
Original Text
Impacts are on a local scale (e.g. restricted to the vicinity of the plant, i.e. restricted to within the project area. Impacts are on a broader scale (effects extend well beyond the immediate vicinity of the facilities and affect the region). Impacts are on a much broader scale than what would be considered to be the project's zone of influence. They are usually secondary impacts such as economic benefits but can be primary such as Carbon footprint. Such impacts can be fe...
Positive Impact An impact that is considered to represent an improvement on the baseline or introduces a new desirable factor Negligible Impact Magnitude of change is comparable to natural variation Minor Impact Detectable but is not significant - should be further mitigated if possible but is an acceptable risk Moderate Impact Significant, amenable to mitigation, should be further mitigated if possible borderline acceptability. Major Impact Significant; amenable to m...
The event is very unlikely to occur under normal operating conditions but may occur in exceptional circumstances, i.e. the event is generally never heard of in industry The event is unlikely but may occur at some time during normal operating conditions, i.e. the event is heard of in industry The event is likely to occur at some time during normal operating conditions, i.e. incident has occurred in the company before The event is very likely to occur during normal operating ...
p. 276 Project Area of Influence
3 facts â–¼
  • The Project Area of Influence (AOI) encompasses all areas expected to undergo physical changes due to Project activities.
  • The Elang project area primarily consists of the Elang mine footprint, OCL, mill, DSTP infrastructure, and power plants.
  • The Elang project boundary, including all areas of direct physical changes, totals approximately 2,300 ha in Sumbawa and West Sumbawa.
  • The Project Area of Influence (AOI) encompasses all areas expected to undergo physical changes due to Project activities.
  • The Elang project area primarily consists of the Elang mine footprint, OCL, mill, DSTP infrastructure, and power plants.
  • The Elang project boundary, including all areas of direct physical changes, totals approximately 2,300 ha in Sumbawa and West Sumbawa.
Original Text
Although trans-boundary environmental effects such as greenhouse gas emissions may need consideration, environmental assessment is first of all site-based. The obvious Project Area of Influence (AOI) (and hence study area) is the Elang project area itself, which comprises all areas expected to undergo physical changes due to Project activities. In the case of this Project, the Elang project area consists mainly of Elang mine foot print, OCL, mill, DSTP infrastructure,...
The Elang project boundary includes all areas of direct physical changes -the 'footprint' of the Elang Project, totalling to about 2,300 ha in Sumbawa and West Sumbawa. Figure 8-2 Project Boundary
p. 277 Ecological Boundary
4 facts â–¼
  • The ecological boundary includes all areas where environmental impacts, including indirect impacts, may occur.
  • The ecological boundary is determined by impact distribution within water and air components.
  • Project construction and operations are expected to potentially affect downstream watersheds.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The ecological boundary includes all areas where environmental impacts, including indirect impacts, may occur.
  • The ecological boundary is determined by impact distribution within water and air components.
  • Project construction and operations are expected to potentially affect downstream watersheds.
  • Atmospheric modeling of coal-fired power plant emissions at Benete Bay indicates the point of maximum infringement of air emissions will reach a distance of about 1 km.
Original Text
The ecological boundary encompasses all areas in which environmental impacts, including indirect impacts, may occur. The ecological boundary is determined based on the impact distribution within the water and air components: (1) project construction and operations will potentially affect downstream watersheds; (2) atmospheric modelling of coal-fired power plant emissions at Benete Bay (and past environmental monitoring data for ambient air quality) indicates th...

p. 279 8.2.4 Administrative Boundary
3 facts â–¼
  • The administrative boundary includes jurisdictions influencing the Elang project, with Batu Hijau and Elang mines located in two different regencies.
  • An ESIA requires both primary data (direct observations, field measurements, laboratory analyses, questionnaires, in-depth interviews) and secondary d...
  • Secondary data is sourced from published environmental studies, government institutions, and the internet.
  • The administrative boundary includes jurisdictions influencing the Elang project, with Batu Hijau and Elang mines located in two different regencies.
  • An ESIA requires both primary data (direct observations, field measurements, laboratory analyses, questionnaires, in-depth interviews) and secondary data (spatial management maps, administrative maps, topographical maps, land use maps, statistical data, rainfall data).
  • Secondary data is sourced from published environmental studies, government institutions, and the internet.
Original Text
The administrative boundary includes the various jurisdictions with influence on the Elang project. As stated elsewhere Batu Hijau and the Elang mines are located in two different regencies. The administrative boundary is illustrated in Figure 8-4.
An ESIA requires primary and secondary data. Primary data are obtained from direct observations and field measurements, laboratory analyses, questionnaires, and in-depth interviews. Secondary data (e.g., spatial management map, administration map, topographical map, land use map, statistical data, and rainfall data) are obtained from a variety of sources such as published environmental studies, government institutions, and the internet. Collected data, which ...

5 facts â–¼
  • The Leopold Matrix assesses environmental impacts during the operation stage, including those from Provincial Road Upgrade and Elang Site Development.
  • Impacts from Provincial Road Upgrade on Air Quality, Noise, Erosion and Sedimentation, Surface Water Quality, Groundwater Quality, Marine Water Qualit...
  • Impacts from Elang Site Development on Air Quality, Noise, Erosion and Sedimentation, and Surface Water Quality are evaluated.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Leopold Matrix assesses environmental impacts during the operation stage, including those from Provincial Road Upgrade and Elang Site Development.
  • Impacts from Provincial Road Upgrade on Air Quality, Noise, Erosion and Sedimentation, Surface Water Quality, Groundwater Quality, Marine Water Quality, Terrestrial and Aquatic Ecology, Marine Ecology, and Waste are evaluated.
  • Impacts from Elang Site Development on Air Quality, Noise, Erosion and Sedimentation, and Surface Water Quality are evaluated.
  • Impact significance is determined by assessing the project component's effect on the existing environmental baseline and potentially affected sensitive receptors.
  • The severity and magnitude of potential impacts are considered in the evaluation process.

In evaluating the significance or importance of impacts, several factors are taken into consideration. These include an assessment of the Elang project component and its effect on the existing environmental baseline and the potentially affected sensitive receptors. p. 283 Table 8-3 Determining the Severity of Impacts
4 facts â–¼
  • The severity of impacts is determined based on the magnitude of change and the sensitivity of the receptor.
  • A 'No Change Medium' magnitude results in a 'Slight' impact severity across all receptor sensitivities (Low, Low-Medium, Medium, Medium-High, High).
  • A 'Slight' magnitude results in 'Slight' impact severity for Low, Low-Medium, and Medium receptor sensitivities.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The severity of impacts is determined based on the magnitude of change and the sensitivity of the receptor.
  • A 'No Change Medium' magnitude results in a 'Slight' impact severity across all receptor sensitivities (Low, Low-Medium, Medium, Medium-High, High).
  • A 'Slight' magnitude results in 'Slight' impact severity for Low, Low-Medium, and Medium receptor sensitivities.
  • A 'Slight' magnitude results in 'Low' impact severity for Medium-High and High receptor sensitivities.
Original Text
No Change Medium, Sensitivity of Receptor.Low = Slight. No Change Medium, Sensitivity of Receptor.Low-Medium = Slight. No Change Medium, Sensitivity of Receptor.Medium = Slight. No Change Medium, Sensitivity of Receptor.Medium-High = Slight. No Change Medium, Sensitivity of Receptor.High = Slight. Magnitude Slight, Sensitivity of Receptor.Low = Slight. Magnitude Slight, Sensitivity of Receptor.Low-Medium = Slight. Magnitude Slight, Sensitivity of Receptor.Medium = Low. Magnitude Slight, Sensitiv...
p. 284 8.4.2 Impact Evaluation Methods
3 facts â–¼
  • Impact evaluation methods can be tailored and scaled, with more complex and costly methods reserved for Stage 3 (impact assessment).
  • The Analogy Method predicts environmental impacts by direct comparison or extrapolation from similar activities at existing industries.
  • Conclusions from the Analogy Method may be adjusted to accommodate different site conditions for the proposed activity.
  • Impact evaluation methods can be tailored and scaled, with more complex and costly methods reserved for Stage 3 (impact assessment).
  • The Analogy Method predicts environmental impacts by direct comparison or extrapolation from similar activities at existing industries.
  • Conclusions from the Analogy Method may be adjusted to accommodate different site conditions for the proposed activity.
Original Text
The following approaches can be tailored and scaled for use in any step in the impact evaluation, though the more complex and costly methods are used only in Stage 3 (impact assessment) (Figure 8-7). Figure 8-7 Methods and Tools for Identifying and Evaluating Impacts Analogy Method: Prediction by analogy is where environmental impacts are predicted by direct comparison or extrapolation from similar activities at existing industries. Conclusions may be adjusted to accommoda...
p. 287 Identified Significant Impacts of Project Activities
5 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project's potentially significant environmental and social risks and impacts are identified and presented in the Leopold matrix (Table 8-1).
  • Impact avoidance is the preferred option for the Elang Project, followed by minimization, restoration/remediation, and compensation or offset.
  • Where residual impacts cannot be avoided, a management plan with mitigation measures will ensure compliance with applicable laws, regulations, and IFC...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Elang Project's potentially significant environmental and social risks and impacts are identified and presented in the Leopold matrix (Table 8-1).
  • Impact avoidance is the preferred option for the Elang Project, followed by minimization, restoration/remediation, and compensation or offset.
  • Where residual impacts cannot be avoided, a management plan with mitigation measures will ensure compliance with applicable laws, regulations, and IFC Performance Standards 1 through 8.
  • Initial investments in built-in pollution controls are expected to significantly and cost-effectively reduce impact consequences.
  • The acceptability of residual impacts is based on meeting statutory and policy requirements, Good International Industry Practices, and protecting public health.
Original Text
The Elang Project's potentially significant environmental and social risks and impacts are identified and are presented in the Leopold matrix (Table 8-1). These impacts are assessed in in Section 10.
In this Project avoidance of impacts is the preferred option. The next best options in order of preference are: minimization, restoration/ remediation, and compensation or offset (Figure 8-9). Where identified risks and impacts cannot be avoided (residual impacts), a management plan is prepared containing mitigation measures to ensure the Elang project will operate in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and meet the requirements of Performance Standards 1 through 8 as contained in th...
Initial investments in impact mitigation through built-in pollution controls will significantly and cost-effectively reduce impact consequences. After these precautions are taken, however, considerably larger expenditures would be required to achieve an additional reduction in impacts. The acceptability of residual impacts in this Project is based on the following. â–ª Statutory and Policy Requirements -The Elang project is designed to meet all applicable regulatory requiremen...
p. 290 Information Disclosure, Consultation, and Participation
4 facts â–¼
  • This chapter details AMNT's information disclosure activities with stakeholders, providing disaggregated responses where data is available (age, gende...
  • AMNT is committed to proactively engaging with Project-affected stakeholders throughout all phases of the Elang project.
  • Stakeholder engagement is considered essential for building strong, constructive, and responsive relationships to manage environmental and social impa...
  • + 1 more facts...
  • This chapter details AMNT's information disclosure activities with stakeholders, providing disaggregated responses where data is available (age, gender, socioeconomic status).
  • AMNT is committed to proactively engaging with Project-affected stakeholders throughout all phases of the Elang project.
  • Stakeholder engagement is considered essential for building strong, constructive, and responsive relationships to manage environmental and social impacts.
  • The ongoing stakeholder engagement process involves stakeholder analysis, disclosure and dissemination of information, and consultation and participation.
Original Text
This Chapter presents AMNT's information disclosure activities with stakeholders. Whenever data is available, this Chapter provides disaggregated responses taking into consideration factors such as age, gender, and socioeconomic status. For disclosures, the information related to locations, timing, means, and tools is provided
AMNT is committed to proactively engaging with Project-affected stakeholders before and during all phases of the Elang project. AMNT understands that stakeholder engagement is the basis for building strong, constructive, and responsive relationships that are essential for successful management of the Elang project's environmental and social impacts. It is an ongoing process that involves varying degrees of the following: â–ª Stakeholder analysis (power to influence and inter...
p. 291 Stakeholder Engagement Plan
5 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project Stakeholder Engagement Plan (SEP) is a separate document prepared as part of the ESIA report (Appendix 2).
  • The SEP provides a structured, disciplined, and integrated process for meeting engagement objectives.
  • AMNT is responsible for the effective execution and resourcing of the SEP.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Elang project Stakeholder Engagement Plan (SEP) is a separate document prepared as part of the ESIA report (Appendix 2).
  • The SEP provides a structured, disciplined, and integrated process for meeting engagement objectives.
  • AMNT is responsible for the effective execution and resourcing of the SEP.
  • The SEP requires AMNT to prepare for stakeholder engagement by identifying stakeholders, considering their issues, assessing their influence and interests, and documenting these details.
  • The stakeholder identification exercise is continually updated based on changing Project conditions.
Original Text

It provides a structured, disciplined, and integrated process for systematically meeting the engagement objectives listed above. p. 292 Identified Stakeholders
10 facts â–¼
  • Table 9-1 presents the spectrum of potential stakeholders, acknowledging that identified stakeholders will change over the life of the Elang project.
  • Central government authorities, including the Indonesian Investment Board and various departments (Interior, Energy and Mineral Resources, Environment...
  • Authorities responsible for environmental pollution control (water, waste, soil, noise, air) and natural resource protection (biodiversity, cultural h...
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Table 9-1 presents the spectrum of potential stakeholders, acknowledging that identified stakeholders will change over the life of the Elang project.
  • Central government authorities, including the Indonesian Investment Board and various departments (Interior, Energy and Mineral Resources, Environment and Forestry), are identified stakeholders.
  • Authorities responsible for environmental pollution control (water, waste, soil, noise, air) and natural resource protection (biodiversity, cultural heritage, landscape) are stakeholders.
  • Regional government offices for agriculture, energy, forestry, and fisheries, whose interests may be affected, are also identified.
  • Health and safety authorities are listed as stakeholders.
  • Landowners and residents, including former landowners, are key local stakeholders.
  • General members of the local and wider public are considered stakeholders due to AMNT's prominence in Sumbawa.
  • Elected representatives and community figures, such as religious leaders and teachers, are identified stakeholders.
  • Local community and resident groups (e.g., youth groups) are included.
  • Groups representing users of natural resources, such as local farmers, fishermen, and residents hunting/collecting forest products, are stakeholders.
Original Text
Table 9-1 presents the spectrum of potential stakeholders, recognizing that the identified stakeholders will change over the life of the Elang project.

Â· Authorities responsible for environmental pollution control (water, waste, soil, noise, and air): Â· Authorities responsible for protection of natural resources-- biodiversity, cultural heritage, and the landscape (aesthetics). Â· Regional government offices responsible for agriculture, energy, forestry, and fish...
Â· Landowners and residents -likely including former landowners. Â· General members of the local and wider public -AMNT is a well-known company in Sumbawa, and any activity related to the Company will likely attract attention. Â· Elected representatives and community figures, such as religious leaders and teachers. Â· Local community and resident groups (e.g., youth groups). Â· Groups representing users of natural resources (for example, local farmers in the Elang project area, fishermen along the co...

  • Employee organizations, such as trade unions, are also considered interested parties.
  • Research institutes, universities, and other centers of expertise, including local universities that assisted in the environmental assessment, retain an interest in the project.
  • The key local stakeholder communities are represented by 16 villages believed to be most impacted by the Elang Project.

p. 295 Consultation and Participation
8 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project proactively communicates with external stakeholders, with tactical plans detailed in a separate Stakeholder Engagement Plan.
  • AMNT implements and maintains a grievance mechanism to receive, register, screen, assess, track, and document external communications from the public.
  • The grievance mechanism will provide responses and allow for adjustments to the Stakeholder Engagement Plan and the Project itself.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • The Elang project proactively communicates with external stakeholders, with tactical plans detailed in a separate Stakeholder Engagement Plan.
  • AMNT implements and maintains a grievance mechanism to receive, register, screen, assess, track, and document external communications from the public.
  • The grievance mechanism will provide responses and allow for adjustments to the Stakeholder Engagement Plan and the Project itself.
  • AMNT will implement a Project-level Grievance Redress Mechanism specifically for the Elang Mining Project in Lunyuk Kecamatan and elsewhere in Sumbawa and West Sumbawa Regencies.
  • A grievance resolution mechanism is considered essential for industrial projects like Elang due to anticipated ongoing operational risks and potential adverse impacts on surrounding communities.
  • The grievance mechanism design is being developed to address challenges to Project development and operation.
  • IFC Performance Standard (PS) 1 requires the establishment of a grievance mechanism where affected communities are involved in the Elang project area.
  • The grievance mechanism should be scaled to the risks and adverse impacts of the Elang project and be accessible to Affected Communities.
Original Text
The Elang project proactively communicates with external stakeholders. Tactical plans and approaches are contained in the Stakeholder Engagement Plan separately prepared as part of this ESIA effort. AMNT also implements and maintains a grievance mechanism (refer to next section) for external communications to: â–ª Receive and register external communications from the public; â–ª Screen and assess the issues raised and determine how to address them; â–ª Provide, track, and document responses; and â–ª Adj...
AMNT will provide and implement a Project-level Grievance Redress Mechanism specific to the Elang Mining Project (Elang or Elang Project or the Elang project) planned for development in Lunyuk Kecamatan and elsewhere in in Sumbawa and West Sumbawa Regencies. A grievance resolution or redress mechanism is essential for industrial projects where ongoing operational risks and potential adverse impacts on surrounding communities (the Elang project Affected People (PAP) are anti...
As stated in IFC (International Finance Corporation) Performance Standard (PS) 1, a grievance mechanism should be established where there are affected communities involved in the Elang project area. Below are the requirements for a grievance mechanism in compliance with IFC PS 1: The client will establish a grievance mechanism to receive and facilitate resolution of Affected Communities' concerns and grievances about the client's environmental and social performance. p. 296 Elang Project Grievance Redress Mechanism Design

  • The Grievance Resolution Mechanism (GRM) will channel concerns through an established company mechanism developed over decades of operation in Sumbawa...
  • AMNT will process grievances in a timely, effective, and consistent manner.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • All Elang Project Affected People will have equal opportunity to raise concerns, complaints, requests for information, issues, and disputes.
  • The Grievance Resolution Mechanism (GRM) will channel concerns through an established company mechanism developed over decades of operation in Sumbawa.
  • AMNT will process grievances in a timely, effective, and consistent manner.
  • The GRM will be designed to accommodate grievances early in the process.

All these, as well as requests for information, issues, and disputes will be channelled through an established mechanism that has been developed by the Company over decades of operation in Sumbawa, and will be processed by AMNT in a timely, effective, and consistent m...

p. 299 ASSESSMENT OF ANTICIPATED ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL RISKS AND...
8 facts â–¼
  • Chapter 10 provides an assessment of the main environmental and social impacts of the Elang project.
  • The environmental impact assessment of the Elang Project benefits from two decades of successful operation of the Batu Hijau Mine and its generated en...
  • The analogy method was extensively used in this ESIA due to the similarity of the Elang project to current Batu Hijau operations, with impact predicti...
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Chapter 10 provides an assessment of the main environmental and social impacts of the Elang project.
  • The environmental impact assessment of the Elang Project benefits from two decades of successful operation of the Batu Hijau Mine and its generated environmental data.
  • The analogy method was extensively used in this ESIA due to the similarity of the Elang project to current Batu Hijau operations, with impact predictions reflecting actual operational experience.
  • Quantitative assessment methods were also used in addition to the analogy method.
  • The Elang project has the potential to generate pollutant emissions to the atmosphere at each stage, with dust generation being a particular concern.
  • Principal sources of emission will include coal-fired (CFPP) or combined cycle (CCPP) power plants and emissions from mine equipment.
  • The extent of air quality degradation for sensitive receptors is not expected to exceed Indonesian regulations due to the assimilative capacity of the air shed.
  • The Environmental Management Plan includes measures for the control of emissions.
Original Text
Chapter 10 provides an assessment of the main environmental and social impacts of the Elang project. As stated elsewhere the environmental impact assessment of the Elang Project benefits from two decades of successful operation of the Batu Hijau Mine and the wealth of environmentally relevant knowledge and data generated over this time. Given the similarity of Elang project to the current Batu Hijau operations the analogy method was extensively used in this ESIA, and impact prediction...
The Elang project has the potential to generate pollutant emissions to the atmosphere at each stage. Of particular concern will be the generation of dust that will be dealt with in Chapter 10.2. Principal sources of emission will be the coal fired (CFPP) or combined cycle (CCPP) power plants and emissions from mine equipment. The extent of the degradation of air quality for sensitive receptors is not expected to exceed Indonesian regulations, due to the assimilative capacity of the air shed whic...
p. 300 Prediction of the Impacts at Receptors
4 facts â–¼
  • Ambient environmental measurements confirm the assimilative capacity of a very clean airshed in the Elang project area.
  • Three sampling locations were used: AMWTP immediately adjacent to the plant, AMPRO approximately 14km away, and AMSEJ in Sejorong approximately 12km a...
  • AMSEJ is considered a control location, away from the power plant(s) and the mine.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Ambient environmental measurements confirm the assimilative capacity of a very clean airshed in the Elang project area.
  • Three sampling locations were used: AMWTP immediately adjacent to the plant, AMPRO approximately 14km away, and AMSEJ in Sejorong approximately 12km away (to the SSE).
  • AMSEJ is considered a control location, away from the power plant(s) and the mine.
  • Consistent measurements over 10 years show relatively small differences between the sampling locations.
Original Text
Ambient environmental measurements taken in the Elang project confirm the assimilative capacity of a very clean airshed. The three sampling locations used represent different distances from the point sources of the power facility AMWTP, immediately adjacent to the plant, AMPRO approximately 14km away and AMSEJ (to the ESE), in Sejorong approximately 12km away (to the SSE) (Table 10-2). Of the three AMSEJ could best be considered a control location, away from the power plant(s) and th...
p. 302 Drivers for Atmospheric Dilution of Air Pollutants
5 facts â–¼
  • In accordance with IFC General EHS Guidelines, the airshed is not considered degraded or ecologically sensitive.
  • Changes in ambient air quality due to combustion gas emissions during operations are expected to be very small, if any.
  • The significance of the impact of combustion gas emissions during operations is considered negligible.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • In accordance with IFC General EHS Guidelines, the airshed is not considered degraded or ecologically sensitive.
  • Changes in ambient air quality due to combustion gas emissions during operations are expected to be very small, if any.
  • The significance of the impact of combustion gas emissions during operations is considered negligible.
  • Emissions from vehicles, plant, and equipment during the construction phase do not represent a major change from existing environmental conditions.
  • Construction phase emissions of combustion gases are also considered to have a negligible impact on the existing environment.
Original Text
In accordance with IFC General EHS Guidelines, the airshed cannot be considered degraded or ecologically sensitive. Furthermore, the changes in ambient Air quality are expected to be very small, if any. Therefore, the significance of the impact of combustion gas emissions during operations can be considered to be negligible. Emissions form vehicles, plant and equipment during construction phase do not represent a major change from the existing environmental condition. Construction phase emission...
p. 303 Predicted Impacts from Power Plant
2 facts â–¼
  • The analogy method predicts that ambient air quality will meet applicable standards after constructing and operating three additional 100 MW units.
  • Simulated maximum pollutant concentrations from Elang project emissions are well below the adopted Project Criteria for NO2 (24-hour and annual averag...
  • The analogy method predicts that ambient air quality will meet applicable standards after constructing and operating three additional 100 MW units.
  • Simulated maximum pollutant concentrations from Elang project emissions are well below the adopted Project Criteria for NO2 (24-hour and annual average), PM10 (24-hour and annual average), PM2.5 (24-hour and annual average), and SO2 (annual average).
Original Text
The analogy method suggests that ambient air quality will meet applicable standards after constructing and operating of three additional 100 MW units. Table 10-1 and Table 10-2 illustrate simulated ground level concentrations of SO2 for various atmospheric conditions (see appendices for model report). The simulated maximum pollutant concentrations from emissions from the Elang project are well below the adopted Project Criteria for NO2 as a 24 hour and annual average, PM10 and PM2....

  • For another pollutant (likely SO2 based on context, though not explicitly stated for these values), at receptor 1, the maximum incremental concentration is 2.53 Âµg/m3, with a total of 32.93 Âµg/m3, not exceeding GoI standard but exceeding WHO standards.
  • At receptor 2, the maximum incremental concentration is 2.53 Âµg/m3, with a total of 32.93 Âµg/m3, not exceeding GoI standard but exceeding WHO standards.
  • At receptor 3, the maximum incremental concentration is 2.08 Âµg/m3, with a total of 32.48 Âµg/m3, not exceeding GoI standard but exceeding WHO standards.

p. 309 Predicted Maximum Pollutant Concentrations at the Most Affec...
4 facts â–¼
  • For 1-hour SO2, the most affected receptor is R2, with an incremental impact of 30.29 Âµg/mÂ³ and a combined impact of 75.48 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • The 1-hour combined SO2 impact of 75.48 Âµg/mÂ³ is well below the Indonesia Standard of 900 Âµg/mÂ³ and the USEPA Standard of 196 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • For 24-hour SO2, the most affected receptor is R2, with an incremental impact of 2.53 Âµg/mÂ³ and a combined impact of 32.93 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • For 1-hour SO2, the most affected receptor is R2, with an incremental impact of 30.29 Âµg/mÂ³ and a combined impact of 75.48 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • The 1-hour combined SO2 impact of 75.48 Âµg/mÂ³ is well below the Indonesia Standard of 900 Âµg/mÂ³ and the USEPA Standard of 196 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • For 24-hour SO2, the most affected receptor is R2, with an incremental impact of 2.53 Âµg/mÂ³ and a combined impact of 32.93 Âµg/mÂ³.
  • The 24-hour combined SO2 impact of 32.93 Âµg/mÂ³ is well below the Indonesia Standard of 365 Âµg/mÂ³.
Original Text
