p. 313 Impact Significance Summary
4 facts â–¼
  • Impacts due to emissions to air are considered minor.
  • Emissions from power plants are predicted not to result in any appreciable change in ambient air quality or gas concentrations at residential sensitiv...
  • The impact magnitude from power plant emissions is rated as slight.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Impacts due to emissions to air are considered minor.
  • Emissions from power plants are predicted not to result in any appreciable change in ambient air quality or gas concentrations at residential sensitive receptors.
  • The impact magnitude from power plant emissions is rated as slight.
  • Emissions from vehicles and equipment during construction and operation phases do not represent a major change from existing environmental conditions.

Impacts due to emissions to air are minor . Based on current operating experience and predictive numerical modelling, emissions from the power plants will not result in any appreciable change in ambient air quality or concentration of gases at any residential sensitive receptors (impact magnitude is slight). p. 314 Particulates (Dust)
3 facts â–¼
  • Open pit mining operations generate significant amounts of dust.
  • The main impacts of dust are 'neighbourhood annoyance' and perceived health effects on local residential communities.
  • Dust represents the most common source of complaint from residential communities near mining operations.
  • Open pit mining operations generate significant amounts of dust.
  • The main impacts of dust are 'neighbourhood annoyance' and perceived health effects on local residential communities.
  • Dust represents the most common source of complaint from residential communities near mining operations.
Original Text
Most open pit mining operations generate significant amount of dust. While dust can have minor adverse impacts on biological communities, the main impacts associated with dust are ' neighbourhood annoyance' issues and perceived health effects on local residential communities. In fact, dust represents the most common issues of complaint wherever there are residential communities within close to mining operations. Potential sources of particulates are listed in Table 10-5 which also shows the ar...
p. 316 Mining Operations (Dust)
8 facts â–¼
  • Drilling and blasting will generate dust, primarily in the upper levels of the open pit above the water table.
  • Dust from drilling and blasting will generally be confined within pit limits, except during strong winds.
  • Water application, particularly on roads and high-traffic areas, will be the main measure to control dust generation.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Drilling and blasting will generate dust, primarily in the upper levels of the open pit above the water table.
  • Dust from drilling and blasting will generally be confined within pit limits, except during strong winds.
  • Water application, particularly on roads and high-traffic areas, will be the main measure to control dust generation.
  • More frequent watering will be required during the dry season.
  • Mining activities within 1 km of residential communities may result in significant dust impacts.
  • The overland conveyor (central corridor option) located at Lunyuk river low land area may require trestles with high-level pad foundations along 2 km, supported by pile foundations.
  • A dust suppression system will be implemented along the overland conveyor as a mitigation measure.
  • Prior to OLC construction, 73 km of existing provincial roads from Benete, West Sumbawa Regency, will be utilized.
Original Text
Drilling and blasting will generate dust, particularly in the upper levels of the open pit, above the water table. However, except on rare occasions when strong winds occur, this dust will be confined within the pit limits. The main measures used to control dust generation involve the application of water. Roads and other areas of high traffic activity will be watered using water trucks, with much more frequent watering being required during the dry season. Experience at Batu Hijau and elsewhere...
The distances of mining activities from residential communities that are less than 1 km may have significant impacts resulted from dust generated. Overland conveyor -central corridor option located at Lunyuk river low land area may require trestles with high level pad foundations along 2 km that will supported by pile foundations and implement mitigation measures by developing dust suppression system along the overland conveyor. Prior to commencement of OLC construction the ...
p. 317 Impact Significance Summary (Dust)
4 facts â–¼
  • Impacts from dust are considered temporary and negligible, with a slight impact magnitude and medium to high community sensitivity.
  • Experience shows that dust impacts can be severe for residences within 2 km of mining activities and within 200 m of haulage roads.
  • The nearest settlement, Lawin Village, Roppang District, is more than 5 km away from the Elang pit, indicating a low likelihood of impact.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Impacts from dust are considered temporary and negligible, with a slight impact magnitude and medium to high community sensitivity.
  • Experience shows that dust impacts can be severe for residences within 2 km of mining activities and within 200 m of haulage roads.
  • The nearest settlement, Lawin Village, Roppang District, is more than 5 km away from the Elang pit, indicating a low likelihood of impact.
  • Water sprays are identified as easy and successful measures for dust control, based on experience at Batu Hijau.
Original Text
Impacts by dust are temporary and negligible (impact magnitude is slight with medium to high sensitivity of community members). Experience has that impacts of dust can be severe for residences within 2 km of mining activities and within 200 m of haulage roads. In this project the nearest settlement is Lawin Village, Roppang District, more than 5 km away from the Elang pit (low likelihood of impact occurring) (refer to Table 10-12). Water sprays are easy and successful measures to d...
p. 318 Source Emissions (Noise)
5 facts â–¼
  • Residential areas are generally too distant from most proposed mining operations for project-generated noise to be audible.
  • Highest noise levels will originate from blasting within the open pit.
  • The nearest communities are located more than 5 km from the mine.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Residential areas are generally too distant from most proposed mining operations for project-generated noise to be audible.
  • Highest noise levels will originate from blasting within the open pit.
  • The nearest communities are located more than 5 km from the mine.
  • Blasting noise will not be audible at distances greater than 5 km, even under worst-case atmospheric conditions.
  • Blasting will only occur during daylight hours to mitigate potential impacts.
Original Text
10.3.1.1 Mining Operations The situation regarding noise is similar to that for dust as, for most of the proposed mining operations the residential areas are too distant from mining activities for project generated noise to be audible. Highest noise levels will come from blasting within the open pit. The nearest communities are located more than 5 km from the mine (Table 10-12). The noise of blasting will not be audible at this distance even under worst case atmospheric conditions. To further mi...
p. 319 Associated Operational Noise
3 facts â–¼
  • The overland conveyor (10,000 tph, belt speed 5.2 m/s) is estimated to generate 84 dBA to 86 dBA.
  • Mining activities, specifically blasting, are estimated to generate around 120 dBA.
  • Haul roads are estimated to generate around 70 dBA.

  • Mining activities, specifically blasting, are estimated to generate around 120 dBA.
  • Haul roads are estimated to generate around 70 dBA.

p. 321 Determining the Severity of Impacts due to Noise
8 facts â–¼
  • Blasting within the open pit is identified as the only significant source of vibration.
  • No ground vibrations or shaking due to air pressure are expected to be experienced by residential communities due to distances involved.
  • The impact of vibration is assessed as negligible.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Blasting within the open pit is identified as the only significant source of vibration.
  • No ground vibrations or shaking due to air pressure are expected to be experienced by residential communities due to distances involved.
  • The impact of vibration is assessed as negligible.
  • Land clearing, topsoil removal, and earthworks will predispose the ground surface to erosion.
  • The risk of major erosion is greatest when these activities occur during the wet season.
  • Short-term measures to minimize erosion include deployment of silt fences, contour drains, contour banks, vegetation bales, jute netting, and widespread use of mulch.
  • Vegetation will be established over disturbed areas no longer required for further construction activities.
  • Drainage systems will be provided with specific designs to manage water flow.

Blasting within the open pit will be the only significant source of vibration. As is the case for noise, the distances involved mean that no ground vibrations or shaking due to air pressure will be experienced by residential communities. Impact to vibration is negligible .
Land clearing, topsoil removal and earthworks will predispose the ground surface to erosion. The risk of major erosion will be greatest where these activities take place during the wet season. Short term measures will be implemented to minimize erosion. These will include deployment of silt fences, contour drains, contour banks, vegetation bales, jute netting and the widespread use of mulch derived from the cleared vegetation.   • Prior to mitigation, the potential for sediment discharges could lead to significant impacts.
  • Most potential significant impacts from sedimentation have been eliminated by proven practices from Batu Hijau Operations.

  • Prior to mitigation, the potential for sediment discharges could lead to significant impacts.
  • Most potential significant impacts from sedimentation have been eliminated by proven practices from Batu Hijau Operations.
  • After applying design mitigation strategies and implementing ongoing ESC management plans, the significance of the impact is reduced to Low.

Brang Dodo has its headwaters 7 km to the north of the proposed Elang pit and passes close to its eastern margin, joining Brang Panas 6 km to the southeast. p. 324 Acid Rock Drainage
5 facts â–¼
  • Acid rock drainage (ARD) is associated with porphyry copper mines, including the existing Batu Hijau mine and the proposed Elang mine.
  • ARD results from the oxidation of sulphide minerals, particularly pyrite.
  • ARD occurs naturally but develops more rapidly and extensively when sulphide minerals are exposed to air and water.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Acid rock drainage (ARD) is associated with porphyry copper mines, including the existing Batu Hijau mine and the proposed Elang mine.
  • ARD results from the oxidation of sulphide minerals, particularly pyrite.
  • ARD occurs naturally but develops more rapidly and extensively when sulphide minerals are exposed to air and water.
  • At Elang, ARD is likely to affect water pumped from the open pit and water draining from the Waste Rock Storage (WRS).
  • The main characteristics of ARD are low pH and relatively high concentrations of sulfate.
Original Text
Acid rock drainage (ARD) is associated with porphyry copper mines such as the existing Batu Hijau mine and the proposed Elang mine. ARD results from the oxidation of sulphide minerals, particularly pyrite (Lottermoser, 2007; Spitz & Trudinger, 2019). ARD occurs under natural conditions but develops much more rapidly and to a greater extent where sulphide minerals are exposed to air and water. At Elang, ARD is likely to affect water pumped from the open pit, and water draining from the Waste Rock...
p. 325 Residual ARD Impacts
7 facts â–¼
  • Proposed management procedures are anticipated to effectively control ARD.
  • Discharges to the environment are expected to meet applicable Indonesian water quality standards for pH, TSS, and dissolved metals.
  • During construction, land clearing and site preparation create a risk of accelerated erosion.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • Proposed management procedures are anticipated to effectively control ARD.
  • Discharges to the environment are expected to meet applicable Indonesian water quality standards for pH, TSS, and dissolved metals.
  • During construction, land clearing and site preparation create a risk of accelerated erosion.
  • Accelerated erosion can lead to the delivery of suspended sediment to nearby surface waters.
  • Brang Dodo is identified as the river most affected by construction activities.
  • Erosion control measures will be implemented at each site.
  • An unavoidable period of high risk for surface runoff carrying suspended sediment concentrations exists between initial land clearing and the installation of erosion control measures.
Original Text
It is anticipated that the proposed management procedures will be effective in controlling ARD to the extent that discharges to the environment will meet applicable Indonesian water quality standards for pH, TSS and dissolved metals (see Chapter 3).
During construction, land clearing and other site preparation activities will create the risk of accelerated erosion, with consequent delivery of suspended sediment to nearby surface waters. As discussed in the previous section, Brang Dodo is the river that will be the most affected by construction activities. Erosion control measures will be implemented; however, at each site, there will be an unavoidable period of high risk between the initial land clearing and the insta...

p. 327 Impacts on Groundwater
4 facts â–¼
  • Mining of the Elang open pit will cause groundwater drawdown.
  • Groundwater drawdown will extend up to approximately 700 m beyond pit limits by the end of Stage 2.
  • By the completion of mining, groundwater drawdowns are expected to extend for about 1,500 m.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Mining of the Elang open pit will cause groundwater drawdown.
  • Groundwater drawdown will extend up to approximately 700 m beyond pit limits by the end of Stage 2.
  • By the completion of mining, groundwater drawdowns are expected to extend for about 1,500 m.
  • Groundwater levels in surrounding areas will take decades to recover to pre-mining levels after mining ceases.
Original Text
Mining of the Elang open pit will cause groundwater drawdown in the areas surrounding the pit. Drawdown will commence when the pit floor extends below the water table and will increase as the pit becomes deeper. Groundwater studies (Golder, 2018a) indicate that, by the end of Stage 2, drawdown will extend up to around 700 m beyond pit limits. By the completion of mining, drawdowns can be expected to extend for around 1,500 m. After mining is complete, the groundwat...
p. 328 Impact on Seawater Quality
4 facts â–¼
  • The Batu Hijau mine uses a deep-sea tailings placement (DSTP) facility in the offshore Senunu Canyon.
  • Surveys in 2004 and 2009 determined trace metal concentrations in tailings, waters, and sediments near the DSTP.
  • Dissolved concentrations of Ag, As, Cd, Cr, Hg, Pb, and Zn in coastal and deep seawater samples were in the sub Î¼g/L range.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Batu Hijau mine uses a deep-sea tailings placement (DSTP) facility in the offshore Senunu Canyon.
  • Surveys in 2004 and 2009 determined trace metal concentrations in tailings, waters, and sediments near the DSTP.
  • Dissolved concentrations of Ag, As, Cd, Cr, Hg, Pb, and Zn in coastal and deep seawater samples were in the sub Î¼g/L range.
  • Dissolved copper concentrations ranged from 0.05 to 0.5 Î¼g/L in seawater samples.
Original Text
10.8.1 Source of Pollutants 10.8.1.1 Tailings Disposal The Batu Hijau mine operates a deep-sea tailings placement (DSTP) facility to dispose of the tailings within the offshore Senunu Canyon. The concentrations of trace metals in tailings, waters, and sediments from locations in the vicinity of the DSTP were determined during surveys in 2004 and 2009. p. 329 Cooling Water Discharge from Power Plant
4 facts â–¼
  • Cooling water discharge is predicted to impact coastal ecosystems, particularly coral reefs.
  • Changes in sea temperature of 2-3Â°C above or below normal can cause coral bleaching.
  • Coral reef condition in Benete Bay has been stable from 2010 to 2017.
  • + 1 more facts...

  • Changes in sea temperature of 2-3Â°C above or below normal can cause coral bleaching.
  • Coral reef condition in Benete Bay has been stable from 2010 to 2017.
  • Hard coral cover in Benete Bay generally ranges from 40.67% to 54.67%, dominated by Branching Acropora.

p. 330 Predicted Impact from Tailings Disposal
4 facts â–¼
  • The 1996 AMDAL predicted no liquid or solid tailings would rise above the discharge depth to enter the surface mixed layer (0-100 m).
  • The 1996 AMDAL predicted no effect on reefs and subsistence fisheries within the surface mixed layer.
  • The Management Plan predicted significant adverse impacts on the marine ecosystem from DSTP within the deeper Senunu Canyon.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The 1996 AMDAL predicted no liquid or solid tailings would rise above the discharge depth to enter the surface mixed layer (0-100 m).
  • The 1996 AMDAL predicted no effect on reefs and subsistence fisheries within the surface mixed layer.
  • The Management Plan predicted significant adverse impacts on the marine ecosystem from DSTP within the deeper Senunu Canyon.
  • Predicted adverse impacts include reduction in seawater quality due to elevated turbidity and dissolved metals.
Original Text
The 1996 AMDAL predicted that no liquid or solid fraction of tailings would be able to rise higher than the discharge depth to enter the surface mixed (biologically productive) layer of the upper ocean (typically surface to 100 m) and therefore no effect on the reefs and subsistence fisheries within that zone would occur. In the vicinity of the DSTP outfall and within the deeper Senunu Canyon, the Management Plan predicted significant adverse impacts from the DSTP on the marine ec...

p. 338 Critical Habitat (CH) Criterion of IFC PS 6
12 facts â–¼
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 1a triggers if impacts affect â‰¥ 0.5% of the global population and â‰¥5 reproductive units of IUCN EN or CR species.
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 1b triggers if impacts may change the IUCN status of VU species to EN or CR.
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 2 triggers for Endemic and Restricted Range Species with an Extent of Occurrence (EOO) <50,000 km2.
  • + 9 more facts...
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 1a triggers if impacts affect â‰¥ 0.5% of the global population and â‰¥5 reproductive units of IUCN EN or CR species.
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 1b triggers if impacts may change the IUCN status of VU species to EN or CR.
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 2 triggers for Endemic and Restricted Range Species with an Extent of Occurrence (EOO) <50,000 km2.
  • IFC PS 6 Critical Habitat criterion 3 triggers for Migratory and Congregatory Species where a significant proportion move cyclically through the project area or gather in large groups.
  • The Elang project area is located within two internationally recognized Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA): Tatar Sepang and Dodo Jaranpusang.
  • Two legally protected areas, Pedauh Nature Reserve and Jereweh Nature Reserve, are within the Area of Assessment.
  • The direct project footprint is not anticipated to overlap with any protected areas.
  • Measurable adverse effects on ecosystem function might occur.
  • The Elang project is expected to utilize natural resources, including water and vegetation clearing.
  • Approximately 2,000 ha of land will be cleared for the Elang project.
  • During construction, increased erosion rates are expected, potentially decreasing surface water quality.
  • Decreased surface water quality could affect downstream uses such as irrigation for agriculture and other community uses.
Original Text
1a, Descriptor = Endangered Species - IUCN EN or CR species. 1a, Trigger = â‰¥ 0.5% of the global population and â‰¥5 reproductive units. 1b, Descriptor = Endangered Species - important populations of ICUN VU species. 1b, Trigger = May result in a change of ICUN status to EN or CR if lost.. 2, Descriptor = Endemic and Restricted Range Species. 2, Trigger = Extent of Occurrence (EOO) <50,000km 2. 3, Descriptor = Migratory and Congregatory Species. 3, Trigger = Any species of which a significant pr...
The Elang project area is located within two internationally recognized areas, the Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA) of Tatar Sepang and Dodo Jaranpusang. Two legally protected areas (Pedauh Nature Reserve and Jereweh Nature Reserve) are located within the Area of Assessment, but it is not anticipated that the direct project footprint will overlap any of them. Therefore, measurable adverse effects of ecosystem function might occur.
The Elang project might have adverse impacts on environmental services. The Elang project is expected to utilize natural resources components such as water and vegetation clearing for development as the Elang project area will acquire a land cleared approximately 2,000 ha of land. During the construction phase, the rate of erosion will increase which, if not managed, will decrease surface water quality due to land clearing and earthworks. This condition has potential affect downstream uses s...
p. 340 Impact Significance Summary
5 facts â–¼
  • Analytical studies on biodiversity components are limited to habitats and do not specifically address impacts on species.
  • Data distribution and patterns for each priority species are limited.
  • Potential impacts on biodiversity and habitat include site preparation (land clearing) for the mining pit, supporting facilities, conveyor route, and ...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Analytical studies on biodiversity components are limited to habitats and do not specifically address impacts on species.
  • Data distribution and patterns for each priority species are limited.
  • Potential impacts on biodiversity and habitat include site preparation (land clearing) for the mining pit, supporting facilities, conveyor route, and access road.
  • Area calculations for land clearing are rough estimates using GIS with several assumptions.
  • The conveyor is assumed to have a width of 10 meters.
Original Text
Analytical studies on biodiversity components are limited to habitats and do not specifically address impacts on species. Limited of data distribution and patterns of each priority species. Potential impacts for biodiversity and the habitat are: - â–ª Site preparation (land clearing), this activity is to prepare the land for the mining pit and supporting facilities on Elang Block, conveyor route and the access road (Table 10-22). p. 343 Operation Stage Impacts and Mitigation
5 facts â–¼
  • Operation stage impacts are expected to decrease, become more predictable, stable, and manageable.
  • Key operational impacts include noise, lighting, and wildlife mortality.
  • Drilling activities will be conducted for 24 hours daily.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Operation stage impacts are expected to decrease, become more predictable, stable, and manageable.
  • Key operational impacts include noise, lighting, and wildlife mortality.
  • Drilling activities will be conducted for 24 hours daily.
  • Habitat disturbance from hazardous materials, noise, light, and vibration pollution during drilling and supporting facility operations has a raw potential impact significance of Medium.
  • Mitigation measures are expected to reduce the significance of habitat disturbance to Negligible during the operation stage.
Original Text
Impacts in operation tend to decrease, or become more predictable, stable and therefore manageable. The impact of project activity relating operation stage are noise, lighting and wildlife mortality. Drilling will be conducted for 24-hours. The proposed mitigation for the operation stage is presented on Table 10-24.   • No additional impacts on marine life are expected from the increased tailings discharge.
  • + 1 more facts...

p. 345 Current Impacts to Surface Mixed Layer and Critical Habitat ...
5 facts â–¼
  • Environmental management objectives are being met, with most tailings deposition occurring at depths greater than 3,000 m and 50 to 100 km from the co...
  • Light transmission in surface water layers remains high, and chlorophyll concentrations are consistent with typical phytoplankton populations.
  • Metal concentrations in tissues of demersal fish and filter-feeding organisms are within acceptable ranges.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Environmental management objectives are being met, with most tailings deposition occurring at depths greater than 3,000 m and 50 to 100 km from the coast.
  • Light transmission in surface water layers remains high, and chlorophyll concentrations are consistent with typical phytoplankton populations.
  • Metal concentrations in tissues of demersal fish and filter-feeding organisms are within acceptable ranges.
  • The Biodiversity Consultancy (TBC) CH Screening Report identifies species likely or potentially qualifying under Criterion 1a.
  • Full details of the CH Screening Report are provided in Appendix 7 of the supporting documents.
Original Text
The results of the monitoring studies are summarized in several studies (Angel et al., 2015, Waworuntu 2015, GESAMP 2015) and the main findings are as follows. â–ª The environmental management objectives are being met and the majority of the tailings deposition is observed to occur at depths greater than 3,000 m, 50 to 100 km from the coast. â–ª Light transmission within the surface water layers remains high, with chlorophyll concentrations in the range consistent with typical phytoplankto...

p. 346 Critical Habitat Screening for Marine Ecology
5 facts â–¼

  • Infrequent sightings of larger whales like humpback or sperm whales have been reported.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Acropora suharsonoi, an offshore coral species, is listed as Endangered (EN) by IUCN and is a Likely Critical Habitat species under IFC CH Criteria 1a.
  • Several whale species are likely to occur in the area, with anecdotal visual observations over 20 years showing frequent appearance of dolphins and occasional pilot whales.
  • Infrequent sightings of larger whales like humpback or sperm whales have been reported.
  • Killer whales were observed on one occasion.
  • Humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) are listed as Endangered by IUCN and have a wide range in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.

Anecdotal visual observations over 20 years of monitoring show reasonably frequent appearance (i.e. most trips) of dolphins (spinner/ bottle nosed), occasional pilot whales but very infrequent larger whales such as humpback or sperm, in the distance. p. 347 Fish and Marine Mammals
5 facts â–¼
  • The Whale Shark (Rhincodon typus) is listed as an Endangered Species (EN) by IUCN and is likely to be present in the project area, though no occurrenc...
  • No adverse interactions with whales or dolphins have been reported over 20 years of routine marine monitoring.
  • Evidence of turtle nesting, including nesting pits, tracks, and direct observations, was found on beaches along the southwest coast of Sumbawa from 19...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Whale Shark (Rhincodon typus) is listed as an Endangered Species (EN) by IUCN and is likely to be present in the project area, though no occurrences have been seen over the past 20 years.
  • No adverse interactions with whales or dolphins have been reported over 20 years of routine marine monitoring.
  • Evidence of turtle nesting, including nesting pits, tracks, and direct observations, was found on beaches along the southwest coast of Sumbawa from 1994 to 1996.
  • Helicopter surveys of turtle nesting activity were conducted at 43 beaches from Benete to Tanjung Tolonan starting in 1994.
  • Two species of turtles were observed nesting along the beaches on the southwest coast of Sumbawa.
Original Text
Whale Shark ( Rhincodon typus ) is listed in IUCN as an Endangered Species EN. Likely to be present in project area, but no occurrence has been seen over the past 20 years. Over the 20 years of routine marine monitoring conducted to date, no issues of any adverse interactions with whales or dolphins have been reported. There is no reason to expect that this will change as a result of the Elang Project.
During the initial characterization and baseline data collection from 1994 to 1996, evidence of turtle nesting was observed from the presence of nesting pits, tracks and direct observations of turtles nesting on beaches along the south west coast of Sumbawa, to the west and east of Senunu. Helicopter surveys of turtle nesting activity at 43 beaches from Benete to Tanjung Tolonan were undertaken by NNT from 1994, later replaced by camping and direct observation on the key nesting bea...

  • All impacts to water quality, sediment quality, and seabed (benthic communities) are confined to the deep area.

The extent and general consistency between the internal routine and independent monitoring provides high confidence in the findings of the last 16 years of mine operations. There is every reason to believe that this will continue. It is evident from the multiple sources of monitoring results that the primary objectives of achieving no impact to coral reefs, beaches, fish or other coastal attributes within the biologically active near-surface zone have consistently been met. p. 349 Potential Risks from Proposed Discharge of Elang Tailings
4 facts â–¼
  • Government of Indonesia Regulation No. 12 Year 2018 sets a maximum concentration for copper in tailings at 750 mg/kg dry wt for waste dumping to the s...
  • Surface sediments at LIPI sites 18, 19, 20, and 63 show copper content well above 60 mg/kg, as per 2013 and 2018 surveys.
  • The main tailings footprint extends slightly outside the boundary at site 6.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Government of Indonesia Regulation No. 12 Year 2018 sets a maximum concentration for copper in tailings at 750 mg/kg dry wt for waste dumping to the sea.
  • Surface sediments at LIPI sites 18, 19, 20, and 63 show copper content well above 60 mg/kg, as per 2013 and 2018 surveys.
  • The main tailings footprint extends slightly outside the boundary at site 6.
  • The DHI model indicates potential for tailings settlement beyond current sampling sites to the east of site 63.
Original Text
The Government of Indonesia introduced a new Environmental and Forestry Regulation No. 12 Year 2018 concerning Requirement and Procedure for Waste Dumping to the Sea and PP No 101 Year 2014 concerning Hazardous Waste Management, including tailings disposal to the sea. The main issue arising from the Regulation No. 12 Year 2018 is contained in Article 7 (1a), which states that the total concentration of pollutants must be in accordance with those listed in Attachment 1 of this Ministerial Regulat...
The easterly extension of the tailing footprint observed at LIPI sites 18, 19, 20 and 63 all have copper content well above 60 mg/kg, in the surface sediments as at the time of the LIPI 2013 and 2018 surveys. Also, the main tailings footprint extends slightly outside the boundary at site 6. Most is likely to have derived from transported subsurface plumes that could not be fully tracked by the DHI model. However, there is no further sampling site to the east of site 63 to assess any further ext...

p. 351 General Waste
5 facts â–¼
  • General waste volume will increase during the construction phase, estimated at 7,500 liters/day (2.5 liters/person/day x 3,000 personnel).
  • Domestic waste is currently managed through a contract with the Local Authority at West Sumbawa.
  • Hazardous waste generated at Batu Hijau primarily results from project maintenance, operational activities, and medical waste.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • General waste volume will increase during the construction phase, estimated at 7,500 liters/day (2.5 liters/person/day x 3,000 personnel).
  • Domestic waste is currently managed through a contract with the Local Authority at West Sumbawa.
  • Hazardous waste generated at Batu Hijau primarily results from project maintenance, operational activities, and medical waste.
  • The profile of hazardous wastes will change during the construction phase due to increased plant and equipment operation.
  • Existing arrangements for hazardous waste involve using a licensed contractor for transport and disposal.
Original Text
General waste is associated with the presence of the workforce. Therefore, through the construction phase the volume will increase commensurate with the ramp up of the construction workforce (estimated roughly as 2.5 liter/person/day x 3,000personnel or around 7,500 liter/day). Then as construction ramps down, this will return to around current values. Currently Domestic waste is managed through a contract with the Local Authority at West Sumbawa. In the early st...
The inventory of hazardous waste generated at Batu Hijau results mostly from project maintenance and operational activities as well as medical waste. The profile of these wastes will change during the construction phase, with significant hours of operation of plant and equipment that will require maintenance and refueling. p. 352 Fly Ash and Bottom Ash
8 facts â–¼
  • Increased capacity of the Coal Fired power station will proportionally increase fly ash and bottom ash generation.
  • Phasing out diesel generators will reduce hazardous waste from maintenance and exhaust filters.
  • Changes in government regulations will allow fly ash to be supplied to a cement manufacturer.
  • + 5 more facts...
  • Increased capacity of the Coal Fired power station will proportionally increase fly ash and bottom ash generation.
  • Phasing out diesel generators will reduce hazardous waste from maintenance and exhaust filters.
  • Changes in government regulations will allow fly ash to be supplied to a cement manufacturer.
  • Bottom ash can be incorporated into concrete materials like shotcrete.
  • Vegetation waste will be generated during land clearing for construction.
  • The local community will be given the opportunity to harvest viable materials (crops, fruit, timber) from vegetation waste during land clearing.
  • Environmental impacts of waste generation are expected to be negligible once managed through the AMNT Waste Management Plan.
  • Waste management processes will offer business opportunities to local contractors through contracts and licenses.
Original Text
Existing Fly and Bottom Ash Landfill The additional capacity of the Coal Fired power station will increase the generation of fly ash and Bottom Ash, roughly in proportion to the increased generation capacity. As the diesel generators are phased out this will also result in a reduction of hazardous waste in the form of maintenance waste and exhaust filters. Fly Ash is currently being landfilled, but changes in government regulations will allow fly ash to be supplied to a cemen...
Vegetation waste will be generated during the land clearing for construction. In general vegetation waste will have little impact, but can become problem in poorly managed stockpiles. Poorly managed materials can end up in waterways and pollute local rivers and stockpiles can become home to vermin. During the land clearing phase, in the first instance the local community shall be given the opportunity to harvest any viable materials crops, fruit or timber from the waste. ...
Once waste is managed through the AMNT Waste Management Plan, its environmental impacts will become negligible. In fact through contracts and licences with local contracts, managing the waste Process will offer business opportunities to local contractors. p. 353 Impacts and Management of Construction Camps
5 facts â–¼
  • An estimated 60% to 80% of the Elang Project construction workforce will occupy construction camps.
  • Construction camps provide accommodation, management facilities, workshops, warehouses, sanitary and water supply facilities, and security posts.
  • Siting of construction camps will avoid sensitive areas such as wetlands, sensitive vegetation types, or sensitive landscape units.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • An estimated 60% to 80% of the Elang Project construction workforce will occupy construction camps.
  • Construction camps provide accommodation, management facilities, workshops, warehouses, sanitary and water supply facilities, and security posts.
  • Siting of construction camps will avoid sensitive areas such as wetlands, sensitive vegetation types, or sensitive landscape units.
  • Ideally, construction camps will be placed within existing disturbed areas or areas already designated for disturbance by the Elang project.
  • Site clearing for camps will increase risks of water and wind erosion and result in direct loss of fauna and flora.
Original Text
Planning, design, construction, and operation of temporary construction camps providing accommodation for workers as well as facilities for management and administration, workshops (including some vehicles and equipment maintenance), warehouses, sanitary and water supply facilities, other utilities as needed, and security posts, is of environmental concern if not managed adequately. Of the workforce needed for the Elang Project construction activities, an estimated 60 to 80% will ...

Examples follow: - â–ª Siting of buildings / construction camps avoids locating these in sensitive areas such as wetlands, sensitive vegetation types, or sensitive landscape units.   • The EPC Contractor is responsible for implementing environmental management on site and in construction camps.
  • An appointed Environmental Control Officer (ECO) will enforce environmental management on behalf of AMNT.
  • The ECO is responsible for monitoring the implementation of environmental management practices described in the ESIA document.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The EPC Contractor is responsible for implementing environmental management on site and in construction camps.
  • An appointed Environmental Control Officer (ECO) will enforce environmental management on behalf of AMNT.
  • The ECO is responsible for monitoring the implementation of environmental management practices described in the ESIA document.
  • The ECO will be appointed directly by AMNT and must have adequate knowledge of integrated environmental management principles and applicable environmental regulations.

The responsibility for implementing environmental management on site/ construction camps rests with the appointed EPC Contractor but will be enforced on behalf of AMNT by an appointed Environmental Control Officer (ECO). The ECO is the person responsible for the monitoring of the implementation of environmental management practices as described in the ESIA document. This person will be appointed directly by AMNT and will have adequate knowledge of the principles of integrated envi...

3 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project expects to recruit a peak of 6,000 workers during operations, with many relocating from Batu Hijau Mining activity.

  • Economic mobility of local communities consistently increased from 7.28% in 2007 to 15.35% in 2015.

p. 362 Impact to Public Infrastructure and Community Amenity

  • The project will involve the construction and upgrade of the provincial road from West Sumbawa to Sumbawa Regency.
  • Increased usage of public infrastructure will result in accelerated deterioration.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • AMNT will require permission to utilize existing infrastructure, such as road networks and bridges for road hauling and river systems for barging operations, to minimize land disturbance.
  • The project will involve the construction and upgrade of the provincial road from West Sumbawa to Sumbawa Regency.
  • Increased usage of public infrastructure will result in accelerated deterioration.
  • One of the first construction activities will be the upgrade of approximately 74 km of provincial road from the Batu Hijau area to the Elang area.
  • The provincial road will be upgraded to a 7m corridor with appropriate profiles and drainage, requiring maintenance of culverts and bridges.
  • Road construction requires permission from the local government.
  • The current status of the road is poor, with minimal activity primarily by motorcycles between villages.

  • An additional 800 personnel, likely from outside Sumbawa, will also be in the area.

p. 364 Operation Stage
5 facts â–¼
  • Changes in the Lunyuk area are expected to settle by the commencement of the Operations Phase as the workforce migrates from Batu Hijau.
  • AMNT has established a Grievance Mechanism and considerable experience working with local Sumbawa communities to manage community changes.
  • Prior to Primary Access Road construction, equipment and material mobilization will use existing provincial roads passing through rural villages in We...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Changes in the Lunyuk area are expected to settle by the commencement of the Operations Phase as the workforce migrates from Batu Hijau.
  • AMNT has established a Grievance Mechanism and considerable experience working with local Sumbawa communities to manage community changes.
  • Prior to Primary Access Road construction, equipment and material mobilization will use existing provincial roads passing through rural villages in West Sumbawa and Sumbawa Regencies.
  • Mobilization activities may affect air quality, specifically dust, and increase noise levels.
  • Decreased air quality can cause health problems and adversely affect community well-being, although mobilization is an intermittent activity.
Original Text
The changes in the Lunyuk area should be settled by the commencement of the Operations Phase, as the workforce gradually migrates from Batu Hijau. There will be change, which may be perceived in different ways throughout the community and will need to be managed through the Stakeholder engagement plan. AMNT has considerable experience in working with the local Sumbawa communities and a Grievance Mechanism is already established. Change management will be a focal part of...

p. 365 10.17.1 Overview
10 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project will require an additional 3,000 workers during the peak construction phase.
  • The Elang project will retain approximately 6,000 workers during operations.
  • Most workers are assumed to be local Indonesian, with a small number of foreign technical specialists.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • The Elang project will require an additional 3,000 workers during the peak construction phase.
  • The Elang project will retain approximately 6,000 workers during operations.
  • Most workers are assumed to be local Indonesian, with a small number of foreign technical specialists.
  • Local workers will be housed within the community during both construction and operational phases.
  • The Elang project is required to comply with Indonesian Labour laws at a minimum.
  • The project must also uphold relevant principles and actions described under IFC PS 2 - Labour and Working Conditions.
  • Where differences exist between local laws and IFC requirements, the more stringent requirement must be adopted.
  • Relevant Indonesian labour laws include Manpower (Indonesian Labour) Law (Law No. 13, 2003).
  • The Manpower Law promotes equal opportunity, worker protection, and improving worker welfare.
  • Ministry of Manpower and Transmigrations Regulation (Law No. 19, 2012) outlines conditions for outsourcing work.
Original Text
This section addresses issues associated with the safe and fair employment of workers during construction and operations of the Elang project as required by IFC PS2. The Elang project will require an additional 3,000 workers during construction (peak) and will retain approximately 6,000 workers during operations. It is assumed that most of the workers will be local Indonesian, with a small number being foreign technical specialists. For both the construction and operational phase...
The Elang project is required to comply with Indonesian Labour laws at a minimum, and where applicable also uphold relevant principles and actions described under IFC PS 2 -Labour and Working Conditions. Where there are differences between local laws and IFC requirements, the more stringent requirement is to be adopted.
Relevant Indonesian labour laws to the Elang project include: - â–ª Manpower (Indonesian Labour) Law (Law No. 13, 2003) -The peak labour law in Indonesia. Outlines the principles and conditions for worker employment. The law promotes the principles of equal opportunity, worker protection, and improving the welfare of workers and their families (ILO, 2014). - â–ª Ministry of Manpower and Transmigrations Regulation (Law No. 19, 2012) on Conditions for Outsourcing the ...
p. 366 IFC PS 2 - Labour and Working Conditions
9 facts â–¼
  • IFC PS 2 recognizes and seeks to protect the fundamental rights of workers.
  • The objectives of PS 2 include promoting fair treatment, non-discrimination, and equal opportunity for workers.
  • PS 2 aims to establish, maintain, and improve worker-management relationships.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • IFC PS 2 recognizes and seeks to protect the fundamental rights of workers.
  • The objectives of PS 2 include promoting fair treatment, non-discrimination, and equal opportunity for workers.
  • PS 2 aims to establish, maintain, and improve worker-management relationships.
  • PS 2 promotes compliance with national employment laws.
  • PS 2 seeks to protect vulnerable categories of workers, including children, migrant workers, and third-party workers.
  • AMNT has a mature OHS Management system from the Batu Hijau Project.
  • Elang project workers may be exposed to general workplace health and safety hazards.
  • Potential hazards include hazardous substances, use of explosives, electrical safety issues, physical hazards, and ionizing radiation.
  • Relevant ILO conventions include Convention 87 on Freedom of Association and Convention 98 on Collective Bargaining.
Original Text
PS 2 recognises and seeks to protect the fundamental rights of workers. It encompasses a range of principles from international conventions and instruments, including from the International Labour Organisation [1] and the United Nations [2] . The objectives of the PS are to: â–ª Promote fair treatment, non-discrimination and equal opportunity of workers, â–ª Establish, maintain and improve worker-management relationships, â–ª Promote compliance with national employment laws, â–ª Protect worker...
AMNT have a mature OHS Management system that has been in place through the execution of the Batu Hijau Project. The Elang project construction and operation has the potential to expose workers to the following: â–ª General workplace health and safety â–ª Hazardous substances â–ª Use of explosives â–ª Electrical safety and isolation â–ª Physical hazards â–ª Ionizing radiation â–ª Fitness for work [1] Relevant ILO laws include: ILO Convention 87 on Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organiz...

p. 369 Vulnerability of Indigenous Peoples
3 facts â–¼
  • Indigenous Peoples (Masyarakat Hukum Adat or Masyarakat Adat) tend to have collective attachment to their lands.
  • Indigenous Peoples are highly dependent on natural resources for livelihoods, cultural, ceremonial, and spiritual purposes.
  • A field survey in July 2019 identified three Indigenous Peoples groups (Pekasa, Bercu, and Talonang) within the project boundary.

While the IP may not possess formally legitimate rights over these lands, their utilization for IP livelihoods, cultural, ceremonial, and spiritual purposes that define their identity and lifestyle reflects strong relationship with their claimed lands. p. 373 CUMULATIVE AND TRANSBOUNDARY IMPACT ASSESSMENT
5 facts â–¼
  • Chapter 11 addresses cumulative and transboundary impacts from incremental project impacts combined with other existing or planned developments.
  • Examples of cumulative impacts include increased marine water temperature in Benete Bay from multiple power plants and the proposed copper smelter.
  • Potential decrease of marine water quality at Senunu Bay (DSTP outfall) is a cumulative impact from tailings release.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Chapter 11 addresses cumulative and transboundary impacts from incremental project impacts combined with other existing or planned developments.
  • Examples of cumulative impacts include increased marine water temperature in Benete Bay from multiple power plants and the proposed copper smelter.
  • Potential decrease of marine water quality at Senunu Bay (DSTP outfall) is a cumulative impact from tailings release.
  • IFC Performance Standard 1 defines the Elang project area of influence to include cumulative impacts from other existing, planned, or reasonably defined developments.
  • Performance Standard 1 limits cumulative impacts to those recognized as important based on scientific concerns or concerns from Affected Communities.
Original Text

  • The Batu Hijau mine development commenced in the early 1990s.
  • The previous mine owner, NNT, prepared an AMDAL in 1996 for copper ore mining, concentrate shipment, and Deep Sea Tailing Disposal (DSTP).
  • AMNT prepared a separate AMDAL for the Benete coal-fired power plant.
  • An Addendum AMDAL in 2015 included changes to Batu Hijau mining methods.
  • An AMDAL for the AMIN copper smelter was prepared in 2017 and superseded by a 2019 addendum.

  • Baseline conditions of ambient air quality are described in Chapter 7, with impact assessment in Chapter 10.
  • The copper smelter and its supporting facilities will contribute to gaseous and particulate emissions.

p. 377 11.4.1 Airshed of power plants and smelter operations
3 facts â–¼
  • The existing Batu Hijau mining operation's energy demand is met by a 130 MW coal-fired power plant (CFPP) at Benete Bay.
  • An additional 300 MW (3 x 100 MW units) coal-fired power plant is planned for construction adjacent to the existing plant.
  • The AMIN Copper Smelter operation, with a supporting Acid Plant, is located close to Benete Bay.
  • The existing Batu Hijau mining operation's energy demand is met by a 130 MW coal-fired power plant (CFPP) at Benete Bay.
  • An additional 300 MW (3 x 100 MW units) coal-fired power plant is planned for construction adjacent to the existing plant.
  • The AMIN Copper Smelter operation, with a supporting Acid Plant, is located close to Benete Bay.

p. 380 Marine Water Quality at Senunu Bay (Tailings outfall)
7 facts â–¼
  • Tailings discharge is the main source of potential impacts on the marine environment of Senunu Bay.
  • The existing DSTP at Batu Hijau has been studied for close to 20 years.
  • Experience indicates that the existing DSTP has no significant negative environmental impacts on marine water quality and marine life.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • Tailings discharge is the main source of potential impacts on the marine environment of Senunu Bay.
  • The existing DSTP at Batu Hijau has been studied for close to 20 years.
  • Experience indicates that the existing DSTP has no significant negative environmental impacts on marine water quality and marine life.
  • The Batu Hijau mine has no new additional impacts on terrestrial ecology due to the continuation of mining operations.
  • Direct impacts on surrounding forest vegetation are limited to active mining areas.
  • The Elang mine operation will open new land areas, particularly along the 57 km transportation corridor.
  • The 57 km transportation corridor may pass through protected forest.
Original Text
Tailings discharge is the main source of potential impacts on marine environment of the Senunu Bay (DSTP outfall location). DSTP at Batu Hijau has been well studied for close to 20 years. Experience demonstrates that the existing DSTP has no significant negative environmental impacts on marine water quality and marine life. Potential incremental impacts from the proposed Elang mining operation are detailed in Chapter 10 and not repeated here.
The Batu Hijau mine is well established and there are no new additional impacts on terrestrial ecology due to the continuation of mining operations. As illustrated in the aerial view below direct impacts on surrounding forest vegetation are limited to active mining areas. The Elang mine operation will open new land areas, especially along the 57 km transportation corridor that may go through protected forest. p. 383 Coastal Water Resources in the Benete Bay
5 facts â–¼
  • Simulated water circulation patterns indicate limited flushing of Benete Bay, especially during the North-West Monsoon.
  • Benete Bay is a semi-enclosed area influenced by strong currents of the Alas Strait.
  • Coastal water inside Benete Bay is calm, which is the main reason for choosing it as the port location for the Batu Hijau Mine.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Simulated water circulation patterns indicate limited flushing of Benete Bay, especially during the North-West Monsoon.
  • Benete Bay is a semi-enclosed area influenced by strong currents of the Alas Strait.
  • Coastal water inside Benete Bay is calm, which is the main reason for choosing it as the port location for the Batu Hijau Mine.
  • Current velocities in Benete Bay range from 1 cm/s to 10 cm/s.
  • Current patterns in the bay follow tidal movements influenced by monsoonal winds.

p. 387 Marine Water Quality at Senunu Bay (Tailings Outfall)
9 facts â–¼
  • TSS in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 30.22 mg/l, exceeding the quality standard of 20.00 mg/l.
  • TSS in Zone B and Zone C of Senunu Bay are 0.52 mg/l and 0.58 mg/l, respectively.
  • Turbidity in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 21.88 NTU, exceeding the quality standard of 5 NTU.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • TSS in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 30.22 mg/l, exceeding the quality standard of 20.00 mg/l.
  • TSS in Zone B and Zone C of Senunu Bay are 0.52 mg/l and 0.58 mg/l, respectively.
  • Turbidity in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 21.88 NTU, exceeding the quality standard of 5 NTU.
  • Turbidity in Zone B and Zone C of Senunu Bay are 0.02 NTU and 0.03 NTU, respectively.
  • pH in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 7.86, within the quality standard range of 7-8.5.
  • pH in Zone B and Zone C of Senunu Bay are 8.07 and 8.06, respectively, within the quality standard range of 7-8.5.
  • Arsenic (As) in Zone A of Senunu Bay is 0.0019 mg/l, below the quality standard of 0.0120 mg/l.
  • Arsenic (As) in Zone B and Zone C of Senunu Bay are 0.0017 mg/l and 0.0016 mg/l, respectively, below the quality standard.
  • Cadmium (Cd) in Zone A, Zone B, and Zone C of Senunu Bay is 0.0001 mg/l.

p. 391 CLIMATE CHANGE RISK ASSESSMENT
4 facts â–¼
  • Major risks are associated with increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.
  • The Elang Project will contribute to increasing concentrations of CO2 and other GHGs in the atmosphere.
  • Subsection 5.2.1 of the ESIA provides the nature and scale of GHG emissions associated with the Elang Project.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Major risks are associated with increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.
  • The Elang Project will contribute to increasing concentrations of CO2 and other GHGs in the atmosphere.
  • Subsection 5.2.1 of the ESIA provides the nature and scale of GHG emissions associated with the Elang Project.
  • The preliminary GHG inventory includes information on recent operations at Batu Hijau and projections for Elang and associated facilities.
Original Text
It is now generally accepted that major risks are associated with increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere. The explanation of how increasing levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere contribute to global warming or climate change is known as the 'greenhouse effect.' Simply stated, greenhouse gases (GHG) act like a one -way window that lets in the heat of the sun to warm the continents and the oceans, but traps much of the radiant heat from the earth's surface and ref...
The Elang Project will contribute to increasing concentrations of CO2 and other GHGs in the atmosphere. This subsection intends to provide some context and scale to GHG contribution.
Subsection 5.2.1, Greenhouse Gases, is a key portion of Chapter 5 Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention in this ESIA. That discussion presents the nature and scale of the GHG emissions associated with the Elang Project. As necessitated by the preliminary nature of data and information available at this stage of the Elang Project design, the GHG inventory in Subsection 5.2.1 contains a mixture of information on recent operations at Batu Hijau and projections for Elang and cer...
p. 393 Moral Hazard and Regulatory Risk of the Project Contribution...
3 facts â–¼
  • Carbon Footprint measures the impact of human activities on the environment in terms of greenhouse gases produced.
  • Even a megaproject like Elang can be viewed as contributing only a tiny fraction of total atmospheric emissions in national and global contexts.
  • Consequent climate change risks from the project are often rationalized as unmeasurable, insignificant, or compensated by project benefits.
  • Carbon Footprint measures the impact of human activities on the environment in terms of greenhouse gases produced.
  • Even a megaproject like Elang can be viewed as contributing only a tiny fraction of total atmospheric emissions in national and global contexts.
  • Consequent climate change risks from the project are often rationalized as unmeasurable, insignificant, or compensated by project benefits.
Original Text
Carbon Footprint is the term used for measuring the impact human activities have on the environment in terms of the amount of greenhouse gases produced. The discussion in the previous subsection that tries to clarify and quantify this footprint also illustrates an overall dilemma of the climate change issue. This is that even a megaproject can be viewed as contributing only a tiny fraction of the total atmospheric emissions in the national and global context. Thus, the conseque...
p. 395 Climate Change Effects on Elang Project and Resulting Risks
5 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project is considered to have generally low vulnerability to climate change due to its localized, non-living resource-based facility operati...
  • The major non-living input to the Project, coal, is not directly impacted by climate change.
  • The Project is likely to remain feasible regardless of incremental climate changes affecting living resources, assuming no major changes to the global...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Elang Project is considered to have generally low vulnerability to climate change due to its localized, non-living resource-based facility operation.
  • The major non-living input to the Project, coal, is not directly impacted by climate change.
  • The Project is likely to remain feasible regardless of incremental climate changes affecting living resources, assuming no major changes to the global economy.
  • Future expansions into known ore bodies may extend AMNT operations into the second half of the century.
  • Maintaining good relations with local stakeholder communities is essential for long-term project planning.
Original Text
As a localized, non-living resource-based facility operation, the Elang Project can be seen as having a generally low vulnerability to climate change. In particular, the major non-living input to the Project, coal, is not directly impacted by climate change. On this basis, without major changes to the nature of the global economy, there is a high probability the Project will remain feasible regardless of incremental changes to climate and climate-related events affecting living resources.
Major effects of climate change on weather, marine environment, terrestrial environment, agriculture, fisheries, and human comfort and safety may have numerous effects on the Project going into the future. Considering future expansions into known ore bodies may take the time horizon of the AMNT operations into the second half of the century, and continuing good relations with local stakeholder communities being essential, a long-term and wideranging planning orientation will also be ...
p. 398 Risks of Climate Change to Project
5 facts â–¼
  • AMNT mines and infrastructure are mostly sited at relatively high elevation, minimizing issues from sea level and sea surface temperature changes.
  • Project facilities located on tidewater are vulnerable to climate change impacts.
  • Direct and important supporting inputs (coal and other commodities delivered by sea) are dependent on the marine environment.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • AMNT mines and infrastructure are mostly sited at relatively high elevation, minimizing issues from sea level and sea surface temperature changes.
  • Project facilities located on tidewater are vulnerable to climate change impacts.
  • Direct and important supporting inputs (coal and other commodities delivered by sea) are dependent on the marine environment.
  • Outputs such as tailings disposal and concentrate exports are dependent on the marine environment.
  • Numerous structures could be vulnerable to predicted rises in sea levels.
Original Text
AMNT mines and mining infrastructure for the most part are or will be sited at relatively high elevation, so in general the effects on sea level and sea surface temperature will present minimal issues. Project facilities located on tide water do present vulnerabilities, given that direct and important supporting inputs (coal and other commodities delivered by sea) and outputs (tailings disposal and continuing concentrate exports) are dependent on the ...
p. 401 Recommendations for Addressing Project Climate Change Risks
7 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project's GHG emissions contribute to a global problem, and a changing environment will complicate planning and management of AMNT's operati...
  • A basic recommendation is to maintain proactive and robust monitoring of all relevant climate parameters.
  • The key risk of the Project's climate (GHG) impacts is regulatory.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The Elang Project's GHG emissions contribute to a global problem, and a changing environment will complicate planning and management of AMNT's operations.
  • A basic recommendation is to maintain proactive and robust monitoring of all relevant climate parameters.
  • The key risk of the Project's climate (GHG) impacts is regulatory.
  • Indonesia is among the three to five largest GHG emitters globally.
  • Indonesia is one of the most vulnerable nations to climate change.
  • It is necessary to assume that a major local or global event will eventually lead to regulatory control of GHG emissions.
  • A more precise response will be possible as Project design nears completion.
Original Text
While the Elang Project's GHG emissions contribute to a global problem, the effects of a changing environment will feed back and in combination with other Project impacts, complicate planning and management of AMNT's operations. The most basic recommendation that can pres ented here, for addressing both the Project's effects and the effects on the Project, is to maintain proactive and robust monitoring of all relevant parameters. The truism that monitoring is not mitig...
The key risk of the Project's climate (GHG) impacts is regulatory. While Indonesia has yet to seriously try to regulate carbon emissions, two salient facts unlikely to change any time soon are that Indonesia is: (1) Among the three to five largest GHG emitters; and (2) One of the most vulnerable nations to climate change. This combination can only indicate a need to assume that a major local or global event (or series of phenomena) will at some time lead to regulatory control of GHG emissions. T...
p. 403 Recommendations for Addressing Climate Change Risks to Proje...
5 facts â–¼
  • The most predictable climate change risk for the Project is the certainty of sea level rise.
  • Effects of sea level rise on port facilities and the tailing system can be anticipated well in advance.
  • These effects are likely amenable to incremental solutions.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The most predictable climate change risk for the Project is the certainty of sea level rise.
  • Effects of sea level rise on port facilities and the tailing system can be anticipated well in advance.
  • These effects are likely amenable to incremental solutions.
  • A conservative approach would assume a gradual 0.5-meter sea level rise by 2050.
  • A truly conservative outlook would consider that cyclonic storms are coming nearer to the Equator every year.
Original Text
Though the available projections vary tremendously in both scale and timing, the most predictable risk with climate change the Project will face is the certainty that sea level will rise. For both the port facilities and the tailing system, these effects can be anticipated well in advance and are more than likely amenable to incremental solutions. A somewhat conservative approach would probably assume a gradual 0.5-meter sea level rise by 2050. A truly conservative outlo...
p. 405 LAND ACQUISITION AND INVOLUNTARY RESETTLEMENT
6 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project requires land acquisition for the mine pit, ore crusher, stockpile, and overburden placement areas.
  • Land is also needed for haul roads and a mine service area for shops and support facilities.
  • An accommodation/housing area and an administration office area will likely be required.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • The Elang Project requires land acquisition for the mine pit, ore crusher, stockpile, and overburden placement areas.
  • Land is also needed for haul roads and a mine service area for shops and support facilities.
  • An accommodation/housing area and an administration office area will likely be required.
  • The mine area is located 9 kilometers inland in a largely undeveloped forest area.
  • The mine area features steep mountainous terrain with elevations up to 1,150 meters.
  • A major part of the land requirement will be to establish a corridor for the overland conveyor (OLC) with parallel maintenance access.
Original Text
The Elang Project will require obtaining land for the mine pit, ore crusher, stockpile and overburden placement areas, haul roads, mine service area for shops and other support facilities. There will also likely be an accommodation/housing area and an administration office area. The mine area is located 9 kilometers inland in a largely undeveloped forest area of steep mountainous terrain with elevations up to 1,150 meters. A major part of the land requirement...
p. 406 Project Design to Avoid or Minimize Displacement
3 facts â–¼
  • AMNT's project objective was to avoid or minimize human displacement by selecting a site boundary that does not involve physical or economic displacem...
  • The need for supporting facilities on and near the coast will require some encroachment into populated areas.
  • The overland conveyor and logistics corridor are expected to cause impacts on residents, particularly if the Southern (Coastal) Alignment is selected.
  • AMNT's project objective was to avoid or minimize human displacement by selecting a site boundary that does not involve physical or economic displacement.
  • The need for supporting facilities on and near the coast will require some encroachment into populated areas.
  • The overland conveyor and logistics corridor are expected to cause impacts on residents, particularly if the Southern (Coastal) Alignment is selected.
Original Text
In considering alternative Elang Project designs, Project objectives were to avoid or minimize human displacement to the greatest extent possible. In this decision-making process, AMNT sought to avoid such impacts by selecting a site boundary that does not involve either physical or economic displacement. The need to establish supporting facilities on and near the coast will require some encroachment into populated areas. Additionally, the overland conveyor and logistics corridor almost inevitab...
p. 408 Physical and Economic Displacement due to Project Developmen...
3 facts â–¼
  • Displaced persons are classified as physically displaced and/or economically displaced.
  • If both physical and economic displacement are necessary, livelihood restoration requirements would likely be incorporated into a Land Acquisition and...
  • A LARAP, if needed for physical displacement, would cover Indonesian law, AMDAL approval conditions, and IFC Performance Standards.
  • Displaced persons are classified as physically displaced and/or economically displaced.
  • If both physical and economic displacement are necessary, livelihood restoration requirements would likely be incorporated into a Land Acquisition and Resettlement Action Plan (LARAP).
  • A LARAP, if needed for physical displacement, would cover Indonesian law, AMDAL approval conditions, and IFC Performance Standards.
Original Text
Displaced persons are classified as physically displaced and/or economically displaced. Should both physical and economic displacement be necessary, the requirements for livelihood restoration would likely be incorporated into a Land Acquisition and Resettlement Action Plan (LARAP), eliminating the need for a separate Livelihood Restoration Framework or Plan (LRF or LRP). Should a LARAP be needed to address physical displacement, this would cover, at a minimum, the applicable requireme...
p. 409 Compensation and Benefits for Displaced Persons
3 facts â–¼
  • AMNT will provide relocation assistance sufficient for displaced families to restore their standard of living at new residential sites.
  • Livelihood restoration provisions would be incorporated into resettlement planning if necessary for individual or groups of displaced families.
  • Economic displacement without physical displacement is possible, where residences are unaffected but crop or kebun (orchard) land is acquired.
  • AMNT will provide relocation assistance sufficient for displaced families to restore their standard of living at new residential sites.
  • Livelihood restoration provisions would be incorporated into resettlement planning if necessary for individual or groups of displaced families.
  • Economic displacement without physical displacement is possible, where residences are unaffected but crop or kebun (orchard) land is acquired.
Original Text
AMNT will provide relocation assistance sufficient for displaced families to restore their standard of living at new residential sites, so that as stated above a separate LRP/LRF would likely be unnecessary. Should livelihood restoration prove necessary for individual or groups of displaced families, such provisions would be incorporated into the resettlement planning. Cases of economic displacement without physical displacement might be possible - families' residences might not be af...
p. 410 Community Engagement
9 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project will engage with affected communities through stakeholder engagement as described in Chapter 9, Section 9.1 of the ESHIA.
  • Decision-making processes for resettlement and livelihood restoration will include options and alternatives.
  • Disclosure of relevant information and consultation with affected communities will continue through planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluati...
  • + 6 more facts...
  • The Elang project will engage with affected communities through stakeholder engagement as described in Chapter 9, Section 9.1 of the ESHIA.
  • Decision-making processes for resettlement and livelihood restoration will include options and alternatives.
  • Disclosure of relevant information and consultation with affected communities will continue through planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of compensation and livelihood restoration.
  • The Elang project's Grievance Mechanism (GRM) will be available to residents affected by land acquisition and resettlement early in the project.
  • The GRM is designed to resolve disputes about compensation and relocation in an impartial manner.
  • The Elang project would establish procedures to monitor and evaluate the implementation of acquisition, compensation, and resettlement.
  • Corrective action would be applied if breakdowns in implementation occur.
  • The extent of monitoring will be commensurate with the project's risks and impacts.
  • If affected persons reject compensation offers and expropriation procedures are initiated, AMNT would proceed as permitted by law.
Original Text
The Elang project will engage with affected communities through the process of stakeholder engagement, as described in Chapter 9, Section 9.1, of this ESHIA. Decision-making processes related to resettlement and livelihood restoration would include options and alternatives where applicable. As described in Section 9.2 and 9.3, disclosure of relevant information and consultation with and participation of affected communities and persons will continue through the planning, impl...
The Elang project 's Grievance Mechanism (GRM, as more generally described in Section 9.4 and associated Appendix) would be available to residents affected by land acquisition and resettlement as early as possible in the Elang project. This would allow receiving and addressing specific concerns about compensation and relocation raised by displaced persons or members of host communities in a timely fashion, including having a recourse mechanism designed to resolve disputes in an impa...
The Elang project would establish procedures to monitor and evaluate the implementation of each step of acquisition, compensation, and resettlement (and livelihood restoration if necessary). Should there be breakdowns in implementation, corrective action would be applied. The extent of monitoring will be commensurate with the Elang project 's risks and impacts. Should cases arise where affected persons reject compensation offers in accordance with Project policies, and as a...

3 facts â–¼
  • IFC Performance Standard (PS) 6 recognizes that protecting biodiversity, maintaining ecosystem services, and sustainably managing natural resources ar...
  • The requirements in PS6 are guided by the Convention on Biological Diversity.
  • Biodiversity is defined as 'the variability among living organisms from all sources including, inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosy...
  • IFC Performance Standard (PS) 6 recognizes that protecting biodiversity, maintaining ecosystem services, and sustainably managing natural resources are fundamental to sustainable development.
  • The requirements in PS6 are guided by the Convention on Biological Diversity.
  • Biodiversity is defined as 'the variability among living organisms from all sources including, inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems and the ecological complexes of which they are a part; this includes dive'.
Original Text
IFC Performance Standard (PS) 6 recognizes that protecting and conserving biodiversity, maintaining ecosystem services, and sustainably managing living natural resources are fundamental to sustainable development. The requirements set out in this Performance Standard have been guided by the Convention on Biological Diversity, which defines biodiversity as 'the variability among living organisms from all sources including, inter alia, terrestrial, marine an...

4 facts â–¼

  • These laws and regulations primarily manage environmental resources including land, water, air, and forests.
  • Each Act has specific requirements and penalties for non-conformance.

  • Each Act has specific requirements and penalties for non-conformance.
  • Regulations ('Peraturan Pemerintah') and Ministerial Decrees and Decisions outline technical requirements for environmental management.
