p. 415 Internationally Recognized Areas and Protected Areas
4 facts â–¼
  • The Elang project's infrastructure is planned within two internationally recognized Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA): Tatar Sepang and Dodo Jaranpusang.
  • Two protected areas, Kawasan Suaka Alam Jereweh (Sekongkang) and Cagar Alam Pedauh, are located within the Project's Area of Analysis (AoA).
  • Kawasan Suaka Alam Jereweh (Sekongkang) is classified as a Category V protected area.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Elang project's infrastructure is planned within two internationally recognized Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA): Tatar Sepang and Dodo Jaranpusang.
  • Two protected areas, Kawasan Suaka Alam Jereweh (Sekongkang) and Cagar Alam Pedauh, are located within the Project's Area of Analysis (AoA).
  • Kawasan Suaka Alam Jereweh (Sekongkang) is classified as a Category V protected area.
  • Cagar Alam Pedauh is classified as a Category Ia protected area.
Original Text
The Elang project's infrastructure is planned within two internationally recognised areas, the Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA) of Tatar Sepang and Dodo Jaranpusang. Two protected areas, 6 Kawasan Suaka Alam Jereweh (Sekongkang) and Cagar Alam Pedauh are located within the 6 Key Biodiversity Areas (KBA) is 'sites contributing significantly to the global persistence of biodiversity', in terrestrial, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. See: http://www.keybiodiversityareas.org/what-are-kb...
p. 416 Habitat Classification in the Area of Assessment
5 facts â–¼
  • Habitats are classified into modified, natural, and critical for the implementation of IFC Performance Standard (PS) 6.
  • Critical habitats are a subset of modified or natural habitats.
  • Habitat definitions and triggers for natural and modified habitats are provided by the IFC PS 6 Guidance Note (February 2019).
  • + 2 more facts...
  • Habitats are classified into modified, natural, and critical for the implementation of IFC Performance Standard (PS) 6.
  • Critical habitats are a subset of modified or natural habitats.
  • Habitat definitions and triggers for natural and modified habitats are provided by the IFC PS 6 Guidance Note (February 2019).
  • Modified habitats are areas with a large proportion of non-native plant/animal species or where human activity has substantially modified the area.
  • Modified habitats generally have a lower conservation status under IFC PS 6.
Original Text
Habitat is defined as a terrestrial, freshwater, or marine geographical unit or airway that supports assemblages of living organisms and their interactions with the non-living environment. For the purposes of implementation of Performance Standard (PS) 6, habitats are classified into modified, natural, and critical. Critical habitats are a subset of modified or natural habitats.
For the purposes of this ESIA, habitat definitions and triggers are provided by IFC PS 6 Guidance Note (published in February 2019) for natural and modified habitats and describe in Table 14-2. Table 14-2 Definition of Natural and Modified Habitat within IFC Performance Standard 6 (2019) Modified, Definition = Modified habitats are areas that may contain a large proportion of plant and/or animal species of non-native origin, and/or where human activity has substantially modified ...
p. 417 Definition of Critical Habitat (CH)
5 facts â–¼
  • The Critical Habitat framework in IFC PS6 characterizes and prioritizes the relative biodiversity importance of a project area for risk and impact man...
  • IFC PS 6 defines five criteria that trigger critical habitat designation.
  • Criterion 1 for critical habitat is habitat of significant importance to critically endangered (CR) or endangered (EN) species.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Critical Habitat framework in IFC PS6 characterizes and prioritizes the relative biodiversity importance of a project area for risk and impact management.
  • IFC PS 6 defines five criteria that trigger critical habitat designation.
  • Criterion 1 for critical habitat is habitat of significant importance to critically endangered (CR) or endangered (EN) species.
  • Criterion 2 for critical habitat is habitat of significant importance to endemic and/or restricted-range species.
  • Criterion 3 for critical habitat is habitat supporting globally significant concentrations of migratory species.
Original Text
The Critical Habitat framework prescribed in PS6 is intended as means to characterise and prioritise relative biodiversity importance of a project area to support risk and impacts management. Within IFC PS 6, there are five criteria that 'trigger' critical habitat. The criteria are as follows. â–ª Criterion 1: Habitat of significant importance to critically endangered (CR) or endangered (EN) species. â–ª Criterion 2: Habitat of significant importance to endemic and/or restricted-range sp...
p. 418 Habitat Classification of the Project Area
7 facts â–¼
  • The Project has delineated two Area of Analysis (AoA) for evaluating the biodiversity importance of the Project Area.
  • AoAs are ecologically appropriate areas for determining the presence of Critical Habitat for species or ecosystems covered by Criteria 1-4.
  • The AoA boundaries consider species/ecosystem distribution and ecological patterns, processes, features, and functions.
  • + 4 more facts...
  • The Project has delineated two Area of Analysis (AoA) for evaluating the biodiversity importance of the Project Area.
  • AoAs are ecologically appropriate areas for determining the presence of Critical Habitat for species or ecosystems covered by Criteria 1-4.
  • The AoA boundaries consider species/ecosystem distribution and ecological patterns, processes, features, and functions.
  • Terrestrial ecosystems in the AoA vary based on edaphic features including topography, soils, and altitude.
  • The AoA ranges in altitude from 0 MASL along the coast to over 800 MASL.
  • Dry evergreen forest, including monsoon forests and savannah woodlands, are located in the AoA.
  • Some areas within the AoA are degraded due to conversion to agriculture, fires, and human development (WWF 2019).
Original Text
The Project has delineated two Area of Analysis (AoA) for the evaluation of biodiversity importance of the Project Area. AoAs are 'ecologically appropriate area of analysis to determine the presence of Critical Habitat for each species with regular occurrence in the project's area of influence, or ecosystem, covered by Criteria 1 -4. The boundaries of this area take into account the distribution of species or ecosystems (within and sometimes extending beyond the...
Terrestrial ecosystems vary throughout the AoA based on a range for edaphic features including topography, soils and altitude. The AoA ranges in altitude from 0 MASL along the coast to over 800 MASL Dry evergreen forest comprising monsoon forests and savannah woodlands are located in the AoA, with some areas degraded through conversion to agriculture, fires, and human development (WWF 2019). A summary of the main terrestrial ecosystems recognised in the AoA, ...
p. 420 Offshore Ecosystems
3 facts â–¼
  • The Area of Analysis (AoA) contains several marine and coastal ecosystems, including tropical shallow-water coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds.
  • Global-scale data indicate the presence of coral reef patches fringing the coast within the AoA.
  • Tropical shallow-water coral reefs are described as likely Critical Habitat (CH) qualifying due to the presence of specific coral species.
  • The Area of Analysis (AoA) contains several marine and coastal ecosystems, including tropical shallow-water coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds.
  • Global-scale data indicate the presence of coral reef patches fringing the coast within the AoA.
  • Tropical shallow-water coral reefs are described as likely Critical Habitat (CH) qualifying due to the presence of specific coral species.
Original Text
Several marine and coastal ecosystems are present in the AoA: tropical shallow-water coral reefs, mangroves and seagrass beds. A summary of the main terrestrial ecosystems recognised in the AoA, and a preliminary identification of the ecosystem types that meet the IFC PS6 definitions of Critical, Natural and Modified Habitats is presented in Table 14-4. p. 421 Identification of Key Biodiversity Values
4 facts â–¼
  • Based on the Critical Habitat Screening, the Elang Project's priority biodiversity features include 7 species likely to qualify the AoA as Critical Ha...
  • The 7 likely Critical Habitat species include 2 bird species, 1 coral species, 1 fish species, and 2 frog species.
  • An additional 11 species possibly qualify the AoA as Critical Habitat (criterion 1-3), comprising 2 bird species, 3 fish species, and 2 bat species.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • Based on the Critical Habitat Screening, the Elang Project's priority biodiversity features include 7 species likely to qualify the AoA as Critical Habitat (criterion 1-3).
  • The 7 likely Critical Habitat species include 2 bird species, 1 coral species, 1 fish species, and 2 frog species.
  • An additional 11 species possibly qualify the AoA as Critical Habitat (criterion 1-3), comprising 2 bird species, 3 fish species, and 2 bat species.
  • The semi-evergreen dry forest within the onshore AoA is likely to qualify as Critical Habitat (criterion 4).
Original Text

p. 422 Protection and Management of Biodiversity Values
3 facts â–¼

  • The preliminary ESIA indicates likely significant direct and indirect impacts to biodiversity from the Elang Project on both terrestrial and marine ecosystems.
  • Impacts on biodiversity are anticipated to be significant, particularly for high-value marine biota in Senunu Bay and Benete Bay, and terrestrial flora & fauna.
  • The dry forests in western Sumbawa are confirmed as Critical Habitat through the Critical Habitat Screening (Appendix 7), highlighting their irreplaceability and threats.
Original Text

Results of the analyses indicate that there are likely significant direct and indirect impacts to biodiversity from the Elang Project both on the terrestrial and marine ecosystems. p. 423 Management of Ecosystem Services
1 facts â–¼
  • Ecosystem services, as defined by IFC PS 6, are benefits people derive from ecosystems and are categorized into provisioning, regulating, cultural, an...
  • Ecosystem services, as defined by IFC PS 6, are benefits people derive from ecosystems and are categorized into provisioning, regulating, cultural, and supporting services.
Original Text
From IFC PS 6, ecosystem services are the benefits that people, including businesses, derive from ecosystems. Ecosystem services are organized into four types: (i) provisioning services, which are the products people obtain from ecosystems; (ii) regulating services, which are the benefits people obtain from the regulation of ecosystem processes; (iii) cultural services, which are the nonmaterial benefits people obtain from ecosystems; and (iv) supporting services, which are...
p. 424 Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources
5 facts â–¼
  • The Elang Project, as a copper-smelting project producing non-living products, is not subject to the Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resource...
  • Projects engaging in primary production of living natural resources (e.g., forestry, agriculture, fisheries) are subject to IFC PS 6 requirements for ...
  • There is a possible risk that coal purchased by AMNT for electricity generation using a CFPP may originate from areas with significant conversion of n...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Elang Project, as a copper-smelting project producing non-living products, is not subject to the Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources requirements of IFC PS 6.
  • Projects engaging in primary production of living natural resources (e.g., forestry, agriculture, fisheries) are subject to IFC PS 6 requirements for sustainable management.
  • There is a possible risk that coal purchased by AMNT for electricity generation using a CFPP may originate from areas with significant conversion of natural and/or critical habitats.
  • The Project ESMS will adopt systems and verification practices to evaluate all primary suppliers for coal.
  • The ESMS will identify primary resource needs across AMNT's supply chain, potential sourcing areas and suppliers, and assess biodiversity risks associated with primary resource sourcing.
Original Text
Consistent with IFC PS 6, only Projects engaging in the primary production of living natural resources such as forestry, agriculture, animal husbandry, aquaculture, and fisheries, are subject to the requirements of the Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources section of PS 6. As a copper-smelting project producing copper and other non-living products such as sulfuric acid, the Elang Project is not subject to the Sustainable Management of Living Natural...
Consistent with IFC PS 6, where AMNT is purchasing coal as a resource to generate and provide electricity using CFPP for the Elang project. There is a possible risk that the coal has significant conversion of natural and/or critical habitats. Systems and verification practices will be adopted as part of the Project ESMS to evaluate all primary suppliers. As such, the ESMS will: â–ª Identify primary resources needs across AMNT supply chain; â–ª Identify potential sourcing area and supplier...
p. 426 Indigenous People Policy
5 facts â–¼
  • AMNT has established its social relations standard on Indigenous Peoples (NEM-SER-STA-023) recognizing their unique rights, culture, and history.
  • The Company acknowledges and respects traditional land ownership and uses of Indigenous Peoples.
  • AMNT adheres to the International Council on Mining and Metals' (ICMM) 2013 Position Statement on IPs, requiring consent when a project is on their la...
  • + 2 more facts...
  • AMNT has established its social relations standard on Indigenous Peoples (NEM-SER-STA-023) recognizing their unique rights, culture, and history.
  • The Company acknowledges and respects traditional land ownership and uses of Indigenous Peoples.
  • AMNT adheres to the International Council on Mining and Metals' (ICMM) 2013 Position Statement on IPs, requiring consent when a project is on their land.
  • In Indonesia, virtually all citizens are considered indigenous (Pribumi), with exceptions for foreign-origin minorities.
  • The ILO, OP/BP, and PS 7 concepts of Indigenous Peoples cannot be applied to the Elang project due to the Indonesian legal and social context.
Original Text
AMNT has established its social relations standard on Indigenous Peoples (NEM-SER-STA-023) that recognizes the unique rights, culture, and history of Indigenous Peoples (IP), acknowledging that they have distinct interests and concerns that differ from, or are in addition to, those of other stakeholders. The Company acknowledges and respects traditional land ownership and uses. AMNT adheres to the International Council on Mining and Metals' (ICMM) 2013 Position Statement on IPs, whi...
In Indonesia, by law, custom, and practice, virtually all citizens are considered - and in fact are - indigenous. The exceptions are foreign-origin minorities, notably the various Chinese groups and very small numbers of Arab and South Asian groups. All others are considered Pribumi , which essentially means indigenous. The following further clarifies why the ILO, OP/BP, and PS 7 (respectively, International Labour Organisation (UN), World Bank Operating/Bank Policies, and International...
p. 427 Adat Communities in Project Area
2 facts â–¼
  • Three customary communities with collective attachment to their land and customary use of resources are found within the Elang Mine Development Planni...
  • These communities are considered in relation to vulnerability and the definition of Indigenous Peoples.
  • Three customary communities with collective attachment to their land and customary use of resources are found within the Elang Mine Development Planning Project study boundary.
  • These communities are considered in relation to vulnerability and the definition of Indigenous Peoples.
Original Text
Referring to the abovementioned categories and definition of IP in relation to vulnerability, three customary communities with collective attachment to their land and customary use of resources are found within the study boundary of Elang Mine Development Planning Project. These communities are described below.
p. 428 Talonang Customary (Adat) Community
3 facts â–¼
  • The Talonang adat community resides in a forest area of about 10,000 ha in Talonang Baru Village, West Sumbawa, NTB.
  • An anthropological field study in July 2019 confirmed the community's strong ethnic identity and presence before Indonesian Independence in 1945.
  • The community has experienced land conflicts in gaining legal titles and protecting ancestral ethnic identity and customary rights.
  • The Talonang adat community resides in a forest area of about 10,000 ha in Talonang Baru Village, West Sumbawa, NTB.
  • An anthropological field study in July 2019 confirmed the community's strong ethnic identity and presence before Indonesian Independence in 1945.
  • The community has experienced land conflicts in gaining legal titles and protecting ancestral ethnic identity and customary rights.
Original Text
The adat (customary) community of Talonang resides in the forest land within a total area of about 10,000 ha acknowledged as under the customary use of the community in Talonang Baru Village, West Sumbawa, NTB. According to the anthropological field study conducted in July 2019, this Customary Group itself possesses a strong ethnic identity and their presence on the land existed before Indonesian Independence in the year 1945. Land conflicts involving this Community in gaining legal titles ...
p. 429 Pekasa Customary (Adat) Community
5 facts â–¼
  • The Pekasa community is located in Pekasa Forest within the Lunyuk area and has existed since the 19th Century.
  • The estimated total area claimed by the Pekasa community reaches 20,000 ha.
  • The Pekasa Community established its unique administrative/ruling structure long before National Independence.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • The Pekasa community is located in Pekasa Forest within the Lunyuk area and has existed since the 19th Century.
  • The estimated total area claimed by the Pekasa community reaches 20,000 ha.
  • The Pekasa Community established its unique administrative/ruling structure long before National Independence.
  • Similar to Talonang, Pekasa has fought for legitimacy as an Adat Community and acknowledgement of control over its claimed lands.
  • An arson incident occurred in the settlement and farming area of the Pekasa Adat Community in 2011.
Original Text
Located in Pekasa Forest within the Lunyuk area, Pekasa people have existed on their land since the 19 th Century (see Appendix 9). The estimated total area reaches 20,000 ha. The Pekasa Community established its unique administrative/ruling structure within the ethnic community long before National Independence. Similar to the Talonang Adat Community, Pekasa had fought for legitimacy as an Adat Community and acknowledgement of control of its claimed lands. There was an arson in...
p. 430 Cek Bocek Selesek Reen Suri (Berco) Adat Community
6 facts â–¼
  • The Cek Bocek Selesek Reen Suri Adat Community lives in Lawin Village, Ropang Regency.
  • They believe they are descendants of Dewa Datu Awan Mas Kuning, existing since the 17th century.
  • They live in a traditional area of 28,975.74 hectares.
  • + 3 more facts...
  • The Cek Bocek Selesek Reen Suri Adat Community lives in Lawin Village, Ropang Regency.
  • They believe they are descendants of Dewa Datu Awan Mas Kuning, existing since the 17th century.
  • They live in a traditional area of 28,975.74 hectares.
  • A 2019 anthropology study confirmed their presence in the Dodo (Elang) area since the 17th century.
  • They moved to Lawin village in 1933 due to a dispute with the Sumbawa Sultanate and the Dutch Colonial Government.
  • The community still recognizes the Dodo (Elang) region as their ancestral land.
Original Text
The Cek Bocek Selesek Reen Suri Adat Community lives in Lawin Village, Ropang Regency. They believe that they are the descendant community of Dewa Datu Awan Mas Kuning that has existed since the 17th century. They live in a traditional area of 28,975.74 hectares. According to the results of the 2019 anthropology study, the Cek Bocek Selesek Reen Suri have indeed lived in the Dodo (Elang) area since the 17 th century. They moved to Lawin village in 1933 when a dispute with the Sumbawa Sultanate a...
p. 431 Analysis of IP Findings
3 facts â–¼
  • All three Adat Communities exhibit strong relationships with and dependency on their claimed customary lands.
  • The Adat Communities are highly dependent on forest and other natural resources for their livelihoods.
  • Adat Communities have actively sought formal acknowledgement and legitimation of their customary land to sustain community life and preserve cultural ...
  • All three Adat Communities exhibit strong relationships with and dependency on their claimed customary lands.
  • The Adat Communities are highly dependent on forest and other natural resources for their livelihoods.
  • Adat Communities have actively sought formal acknowledgement and legitimation of their customary land to sustain community life and preserve cultural identities.
Original Text
The findings reflect degrees of differences in terms of vulnerability and similar socioeconomic characteristics and attachment to the claimed customary lands. All three Adat Communities possess strong relationships with and dependency on their claimed lands, and strong dependency on the forest and other natural resources. All three Adat Communities have fought for acknowledgement and legitimation of their customary land not only to sustain the life of the community but also ...
p. 432 Avoidance of Adverse Impacts
9 facts â–¼
  • Adverse impacts on Indigenous Peoples (IP) as vulnerable groups will be avoided and minimized.
  • Unavoidable adverse impacts will be minimized, restored, and/or compensated in a culturally appropriate manner, proportional to the scale of impacts a...
  • AMNT's standard on IP reflects a commitment to avoid adverse impacts on affected Indigenous Peoples.
  • + 6 more facts...
  • Adverse impacts on Indigenous Peoples (IP) as vulnerable groups will be avoided and minimized.
  • Unavoidable adverse impacts will be minimized, restored, and/or compensated in a culturally appropriate manner, proportional to the scale of impacts and vulnerability.
  • AMNT's standard on IP reflects a commitment to avoid adverse impacts on affected Indigenous Peoples.
  • AMNT will undertake stakeholder engagement in a culturally appropriate manner, including identification, analysis, planning, consultation, participation, and information disclosure.
  • The engagement process will adhere to the principles of Free, Prior, Informed Consent/Consultation (FPIC).
  • FPIC requires consultation to be 'free' of external manipulation, 'prior' (timely disclosure), and 'informed'.
  • Indigenous Peoples (Masyarakat Hukum Adat or Adat Communities) typically have collective attachment to lands and dependence on natural resources.
  • The heightened vulnerability of some groups is due to characteristics of attachment and dependence on these lands.
  • Even without formally legitimate rights, IP lands are utilized for livelihoods, cultural, ceremonial, and spiritual purposes.
Original Text
Adverse impacts on affected communities of IP as vulnerable groups should be avoided and minimized where possible. Where adverse impacts are unavoidable, the Company will minimize, restore, and/ compensate for the impacts in a culturally appropriate manner, corresponding with scale of the impacts and the vulnerability of the affected communities of IP. As mentioned earlier, avoidance of adverse impacts on affected IP are reflected in the Company standard on IP. AMNT will e...
Stakeholder Relationship Management, AMNT is committed to undertake the stakeholder engagement process in a culturally appropriate manner, which includes stakeholder identification and analysis, engagement planning, consultation, participation, and information disclosure. In addition, the engagement process and practices will adhere to the principle of FPIC (Free, Prior, Informed Consent/Consultation). FPIC indicates Consultation that is 'free' (free of external manipulation, interf...
IP or in Indonesian terms Masyarakat Hukum Adat or Masyarakat Adat or Adat Communities tend to have collective attachment to their lands and dependence on natural resources. The nuances between the international and Indonesian context for these terms has been explained in this Chapter; the key issue complex is the heightened vulnerability of some groups due to characteristics of attachment and dependence. While the IP may not possess formally legitimate rights over th...
p. 433 Relocation of IP from Lands and Natural Resources
5 facts â–¼
  • PT AMNT will consider feasible alternative Project designs to avoid the relocation of Indigenous Peoples from communal lands and traditional natural r...
  • If relocation is unavoidable, AMNT will engage, participate, and consult with the community using FPIC principles throughout the process.
  • AMNT will consider alternative means to avoid impacts of critical cultural heritage loss essential to IP identity.
  • + 2 more facts...
  • PT AMNT will consider feasible alternative Project designs to avoid the relocation of Indigenous Peoples from communal lands and traditional natural resources.
  • If relocation is unavoidable, AMNT will engage, participate, and consult with the community using FPIC principles throughout the process.
  • AMNT will consider alternative means to avoid impacts of critical cultural heritage loss essential to IP identity.
  • Where adverse Project impacts on critical cultural heritage are unavoidable, AMNT will obtain FPIC from the affected IP communities.
  • AMNT's IP Standard (NEM-SER-STA-023, item 2.1) highlights prior engagement activities for cultural heritage.
Original Text
PT AMNT will consider feasible alternative Project design and planning to avoid the relocation of IP from their communal lands and from natural resources subject to traditional ownership and under customary use. Should relocation be unavoidable, AMNT will establish engagement, participation, and consultation with the community applying FPIC principles throughout the process of informed consultation and participation.
AMNT as Project proponent will consider alternative means to avoid impacts of critical cultural heritage loss where such heritage is essential to the identity and cultural, ceremonial, or spiritual aspects of the life of the affected communities of IP. Where adverse Project impacts are unavoidable, AMNT will obtain FPIC of the affected communities of IP. This is also highlighted by AMNT's IP Standard, item 2.1 on prior engagement activities section (IP Stan...

  • The application of mitigation measures to Adat Communities may not substantially differ in practice.

p. 436 Cultural Heritage
7 facts â–¼
  • Cultural heritage encompasses both tangible and intangible forms.
  • Tangible cultural resources include sites, objects, or artifacts with archaeological, paleontological, historical, architectural, religious, aesthetic...
  • Examples of tangible cultural heritage include movable/immovable objects, sites, structures, and natural features like sacred landmarks or burial site...
  • + 4 more facts...
  • Cultural heritage encompasses both tangible and intangible forms.
  • Tangible cultural resources include sites, objects, or artifacts with archaeological, paleontological, historical, architectural, religious, aesthetic, or spiritual significance.
  • Examples of tangible cultural heritage include movable/immovable objects, sites, structures, and natural features like sacred landmarks or burial sites.
  • This section outlines the legal and regulatory framework for cultural heritage in Indonesia and relevant international standards.
  • The Project design, planning, and execution will incorporate considerations for the protection of identified cultural heritage.
  • It is considered rather likely that elements of physical cultural heritage will be encountered.
  • IFC Performance Standard 8 on Cultural Heritage requires AMNT to establish a Chance Find Procedure for unexpected discoveries.
Original Text
Cultural heritage applies to tangible as well as intangible form of cultural heritage. Physical or tangible cultural resources are sites, areas, objects, or artefacts having archaeological, paleontological, historical, architectural, religious, aesthetic, or other cultural, religious, or spiritual significance to a religious group, ethnic group, and/or the wider public or nation. These include movable or immovable objects, sites, and structures, groups of structures, and natural featur...
This section outlines the legal and regulatory framework for cultural heritage issues in Indonesia and relevant International standards and conventions. It also addresses considerations in Project design, planning, and execution for protection of cultural heritage that may be identified, as well as information indicating that encountering elements of physical cultural heritage is in fact rather likely. Internationally acknowledge safeguard standards, IFC Performance Stan...
p. 438 Criteria for Cultural Heritage
3 facts â–¼
  • Objects, buildings, and structures are eligible as cultural heritage if they existed for at least 50 years, possess unique historical, educational, sc...
  • A specific location can be assigned as a cultural heritage site if it embodies cultural heritage sites, buildings, and structures or stores informatio...
  • A geographical spatial unit can be assigned as a cultural heritage district if it embodies at least two cultural heritage objects/sites in close proxi...
  • Objects, buildings, and structures are eligible as cultural heritage if they existed for at least 50 years, possess unique historical, educational, scientific, religious, or cultural meanings, or strengthen national identity, according to Law No. 11 of 2010.
  • A specific location can be assigned as a cultural heritage site if it embodies cultural heritage sites, buildings, and structures or stores information and memory of past human activities, under Law No. 11 of 2010.
  • A geographical spatial unit can be assigned as a cultural heritage district if it embodies at least two cultural heritage objects/sites in close proximity, a cultural human-made landscape existed for at least 20 years, or possesses a unique pattern highlighting past spatial use for at least 50 years, as per Law No. 11 of 2010.
Original Text
Under the Law No. 11 of 2010, Objects, buildings, and/ structures are eligible to be claimed as cultural heritage sites, structures and/ objects if the following requirements are met; Â· Existed for at least 50 years; Â· Possess unique historical, education, science, religious, and cultural meanings; Â· Possess unique cultural values that strengthen the national identity
Under the Law No. 11 of 2010, a specific location can be assigned as a cultural heritage site if the following requirements are met; Â· Embodies cultural heritage sites, buildings, and/ structures Â· Store information and memory of past human activities
Under the Law No. 11 of 2010, a geographical spatial unit can be assigned as a cultural heritage district if the following requirements are met; Â· Embodies at least two cultural heritage objects/ sites that are in close proximity with each other Â· A cultural human made landscape existed for at least 20 years Â· Possess unique pattern that highlights past spatial use existed for at least 50 years Further, table shown below (table 15-2) listed more cultural heritage related la...

3 facts â–¼
  • AMNT will recognize and map existing cultural heritage in the Project vicinity and contribute to its protection and management in collaboration with r...
  • AMNT will adhere to the AMNT Cultural Resource Management Standard (NEM-SER-STA-021, dated 01 January 2017) for identifying, protecting, and managing ...
  • Tangible cultural heritage, as defined by IFC Performance Standard 8, includes archaeological sites and artifacts.
  • AMNT will recognize and map existing cultural heritage in the Project vicinity and contribute to its protection and management in collaboration with relevant authorities.
  • AMNT will adhere to the AMNT Cultural Resource Management Standard (NEM-SER-STA-021, dated 01 January 2017) for identifying, protecting, and managing cultural resources.
  • Tangible cultural heritage, as defined by IFC Performance Standard 8, includes archaeological sites and artifacts.
Original Text
AMNT will recognize and map any existing cultural heritage identified in the vicinity of the Project and will contribute to the protection and management of any relevant cultural heritage in collaboration with the relevant authorities. As such, the Company will adhere to the AMNT Cultural Resource Management Standard, documented as NEM-SER-STA-021 and dated 01 January 2017 (AMNT 2017), outlining corporate requirements for the identification, protection, and management of cultural res...
The tangible cultural heritage findings that defined by IFC performance standard 8 on Cultural heritage embody several types, ranging from singular objects/sites to a large-scale structures and community-based sacred natural features; â–ª Archaeological Sites : Concentrated and patterned physical remains of past human activity, especially human settlement, possibly including artefacts, plant and animal remains, structural remains, and soil features. Note that, the cultural importa...
p. 446 Project Use of Cultural Heritage
3 facts â–¼
  • There is no known proposed Project use of cultural heritage identified or considered possible at the current stage for the Elang Project.
  • The 'project use' aspects of IFC Performance Standard 8 are not considered applicable or relevant to the Elang Project at this time.
  • A project-specific Chance Find Procedure, outlining standard procedures for encountering unknown cultural heritage, is part of the cultural heritage m...
  • There is no known proposed Project use of cultural heritage identified or considered possible at the current stage for the Elang Project.
  • The 'project use' aspects of IFC Performance Standard 8 are not considered applicable or relevant to the Elang Project at this time.
  • A project-specific Chance Find Procedure, outlining standard procedures for encountering unknown cultural heritage, is part of the cultural heritage management plan and can be found in Appendix 10.
Original Text
At the current stage, there is no known proposed Project use of cultural heritage identified or considered possible. The 'project use' aspects of PS 8 are not considered applicable or relevant to the Elang Project at this time.
As part of the cultural heritage management plan, a chance find procedure is a project-specific procedure that outlines the standard procedures, if unknown cultural heritage objects and/ sites are encountered. A full version of the Chance Find Procedure can be found in the Appendix 10. PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara | Environmental and Social Impact Assessment
p. 448 Management of Anticipated Environmental and Social Risks and...
10 facts â–¼
  • Chapter 17 details the management of potential environmental and social impacts described in Chapters 10 and 11, including mitigation and monitoring a...
  • The Elang project is expected to produce local and national economic and financial benefits, including improved socioeconomic conditions from direct a...
  • The project will generate tax benefits for local and national government and increase foreign exchange earnings from copper-gold product exports.
  • + 7 more facts...
  • Chapter 17 details the management of potential environmental and social impacts described in Chapters 10 and 11, including mitigation and monitoring actions.
  • The Elang project is expected to produce local and national economic and financial benefits, including improved socioeconomic conditions from direct and indirect employment and business creation.
  • The project will generate tax benefits for local and national government and increase foreign exchange earnings from copper-gold product exports.
  • AMNT has implemented a community development program near the Elang project area based on identified local community needs.
  • Since 2011, AMNT-Elang project has developed and updated an Environmental and Social Management and Monitoring Plan for the exploration phase (Dokumen Evaluasi Lingkungan Hidup - DELH, updated to UKL-UPL documents in 2019).
  • The updated UKL-UPL documents are part of the AMDAL/environmental permit for the Elang's exploration project, according to Indonesian government regulations.
  • An Environmental and Social Management Plan will be developed for the future Elang project as part of IFC requirements, with AMDAL preparation currently underway.
  • The Elang project is predicted to potentially improve community health and local student education levels.
  • Identified risks include the introduction of new diseases from workers or job seekers and increased criminal activity due to an influx of people from outside the area.
  • Anticipated benefits to the local community include direct and indirect employment opportunities.
Original Text
Chapter 17 provides management of the potential environmental and social impact as describes in Chapter 10 and Chapter 11. This management includes mitigation and monitoring actions to prevent and minimise any adverse impact from the Elang project activities.
The Elang project will produce a range of local and national economic and financial benefits, including: â–ª Improved socioeconomic conditions from direct and indirect employment and business creation, for the largely rural inhabitants of the area as well as other parts of Indonesia. â–ª Tax benefits to the local and national government. â–ª Increase in foreign exchange earnings from export of copper-gold products. AMNT currently has developed and implement a community development prog...

According to Indonesia government regulations, the document is as part of the AMDAL/ environmental permit of the Elang's exploration project. For the future of Elang project and as part of IFC requirements, the Environmental and So...
From the evaluation of impacts, the Elang project is predicted would to potentially produce improvements in both community health and the levels of education achieved by local students. On the other hand it was identified that the project also carried the risk of the introduction of new diseases from workers or job seekers from outside the area, and the possibility of increased criminal activity due to the influx of people from outside the area. Other anticipated benefits to the loca...
p. 451 Conclusions
4 facts â–¼
  • The Batu Hijau Mine, discovered in 1990, commenced ore production in 2000 and has produced 3.6 million tonnes of copper and 8 million ounces of gold.
  • As of 2019, the Batu Hijau Mine has six years of remaining operational life as a surface mine.
  • PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) plans to develop the Elang Mine, located 60 km east of Batu Hijau, to remain in the market.
  • + 1 more facts...
  • The Batu Hijau Mine, discovered in 1990, commenced ore production in 2000 and has produced 3.6 million tonnes of copper and 8 million ounces of gold.
  • As of 2019, the Batu Hijau Mine has six years of remaining operational life as a surface mine.
  • PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) plans to develop the Elang Mine, located 60 km east of Batu Hijau, to remain in the market.
  • AMNT intends to build a copper smelter to retain its copper concentrate export license (persetujuan ekspor), as stipulated in Indonesian Law No. 4 year.
Original Text
Discovered in 1990, Batu Hijau Mine commenced ore production in 2000 and has provided global markets with 3.6 million tonnes of copper and 8 million ounces of gold. As of 2019, it has six years of remaining operational life as a surface mine. PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT) intends to stay in the markets, notably by developing the Elang Mine 60 km to the east of Batu Hijau, as well as by building a copper smelter to retain its copper concentrate export lice...

Reference: IFC EHS Guidelines
